Brazil's Unusual Bid to Curb Deforestation --- It's planning to legalize squatters who clear the Amazon, hoping they will be better stewards

Author: Trevisani, Paulo; Forero, Juan

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/brazils-unusual-bid-curb-deforestation-planning/docview/2349118530/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Brazil%27s+Unusual+Bid+to+Curb+Deforestation+---+It%27s+planning+to+legalize+squatters+who+clear+the+Amazon%2C+hoping+they+will+be+better+stewards&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-02-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Trevisani%2C+Paulo%3BForero%2C+Juan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Brazil%27s+Unusual+Bid+to+Curb+Deforestation+---+It%27s+planning+to+legalize+squatters+who+clear+the+Amazon%2C+hoping+they+will+be+better+stewards&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-02-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Trevisani%2C+Paulo%3BForero%2C+Juan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: POMBAL, Brazil -- For the past 15 years, Carlos Pacheco has raised cattle in what was once virgin forest. When pastures went bad, he would simply cut deeper into the Amazon, one of millions of farmers who have helped strip away about a fifth of the world's greatest rainforest.
Because he expanded into land he doesn't own, he can't use it as collateral for a loan to buy equipment and fertilizer, nor can he tap the expertise of a government agronomist. That means he uses more land to raise each cow than do legal farmers in the breadbasket of southern Brazil.
It may sound counterintuitive, but Brazilian authorities think giving Mr. Pacheco a deed to the land he farms could curtail deforestation. If he becomes a more efficient farmer, able to produce more on less land, he might hesitate before walking away from depleted pastures and carving new ones. In short, it might discourage him and squatters like him from cutting ever deeper into the jungle.
"If this doesn't happen, we will continue to deforest," said the 49-year-old rancher, the leader of a tightknit group of several hundred settlers on the forest frontier.
The administration of Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro wants to see if he is right. In February, it plans to start handing out deeds to some 300,000 Amazon squatters, with a plan that might help but has raised a howl of disapproval for rewarding bad behavior.
Officials in Brazil's environment ministry think they can improve the well-being of Amazon settlers and curb deforestation and large fires, such as those last year.
"There's more than 20 million people who live in the Amazon and need to survive," said Ricardo Salles, Brazil's environment minister. "If the economic incentive is wrong, the result is wrong."
Defining which economic activity in the Amazon is legal, and where, could also help the state crack down on illegal logging and burning. If farms and ranches had legal boundaries and owners, authorities armed with satellite images could better pinpoint and police rainforest incursions, officials say.
Critics of the plan have plenty of doubts, both about the plan's merits and the government's ability to pull it off. One objection is the idea of rewarding squatters with deeds.
"Illegal land-grabbers and deforesters now have a reason to believe they will go unpunished," said Mauricio Voivodic, who runs Brazil's affiliate of the World Wildlife Fund.
Others doubt the administration's commitment to enforcing environmental laws, not to mention its ability to police a region the size of the western U.S.
One issue is Mr. Bolsonaro himself, whom many environmental activists view as a careless steward. The president, who has jokingly called himself Captain Chainsaw, won election in part by promising to unshackle Brazil's economic potential, even in the Amazon.
He has often railed against environmentalists as agitators, and accused them last year of setting fires in the rainforest, without offering evidence.
The Brazilian Amazon is so vast that it helps regulate global temperatures by absorbing an estimated 5% of all carbon dioxide emissions. When large areas are destroyed, the negative climate effect is twofold -- not only are there fewer trees to absorb carbon from the air, but the trees that have been cut or burned release the carbon locked up in them. Carbon, in turn, raises global temperatures.
Much of the worst destruction occurred from the 1980s to the early 2000s. A swath of the Amazon nearly the size of Spain now is dedicated to crop fields and pastures. In the 12 months through last July, the Amazon lost an additional 3,800 square miles, an area bigger than Delaware, according to satellite-image analysis at Brazil's National Space Research Agency.
That was 30% more than lost in the prior 12 months and the highest deforestation level since 2008, the agency's data showed.
Mr. Bolsonaro says he wants to protect the Amazon by giving its inhabitants the ability to make a living without further large-scale deforestation. Responding to last year's outcry over fires, the president in January created an army task force to help environmental protection agents battle deforestation.
Researchers and policy makers who study the Amazon say an approach that brings legality to an outlaw region -- with its untitled land and endemic corruption -- is the only solution to the sometimes-contradictory goals of controlling deforestation and reducing poverty.
Across three Amazon states, wildcat farmers, ranchers and loggers who are relentlessly exploiting what was once jungle said that unless given alternatives, they were determined to continue their illegal activities, which carry few repercussions.
"Settlers are the people who deforest the most because they have no alternative," said Minervina Silva, a mayor and longtime farmer in the Amazon. "Deforesting is easier when you are doing so clandestinely. Once you're legalized, you stop doing stupid things."
Elsewhere in Brazil, farms initially cut from the wilderness grew to be efficient producers that turned the country from food importer to a leading exporter of meat and grains. In areas where issues of land ownership have been resolved, many farmers have increased production without expanding deeper into the forest, thanks largely to technology, access to capital and state assistance. That shows how intensive agriculture could help slow deforestation in the Amazon, said Dan Nepstad, president of the Earth Innovation Institute, a nonprofit that supports sustainable activity.
He said modern land-use techniques such as feedlots, rotating pastures and fertilizing them permit raising cattle herds on fewer acres. Meanwhile, farmers with access to loans might plant profitable new crops, such as cacao, on some former pastureland.
In Brazil as a whole, cattle numbers are up roughly 32% since 1998, while land devoted to pasture has fallen around 13%, according to the Brazilian Association of Meat Exporting Industries.
Deeper in the Amazon, these trends are less pronounced but very much a reality. "You have had intensification of beef and soy in the Amazon at the same time that deforestation has declined pretty sharply from where it was years ago, even with the recent uptick," said David Cleary, director of global agriculture for the Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit focused on fighting climate change.
The question remains how long might it take Brazil to end predatory farming and the damage that scientists say is pushing the Amazon closer to a point where it is unable to replenish lost forest. The federal government cut funding for the environment ministry by more than 24% last year as part of a fiscal tightening.
Agriculture Minister Tereza Cristina, who is overseeing the process of legalizing land ownership, said Brazil needs to both improve the policing of illegal deforestation and provide deeds and credit to Amazon settlers.
"These people are out there. Am I supposed to move them somewhere else, so they can deforest again?" she said. "Environmental protection must go hand-in-hand with economic development because prosperity, I think, leads to forest preservation."
Though it might seem impossible to sell land without a deed, Amazon settlers make deals that transfer property. Those who have cut trees to produce a pasture or crop field often use it for just a few years and then, when its unfertilized soil has lost nutrients, abandon it or sell it cheap in an informal deal.
Most farmers in the Amazon are poor. Only 15% are in the middle class or above, said Katia Abreu, a former agriculture minister, based on research she did at the ministry.
Even some of the largest Amazon farmers and ranchers have illegal land. Over the decades, 73-year-old cattleman Joao Bueno cut into the forest in Para state to build a network of ranches totaling 45,000 acres, with 28,000 head of cattle.
He has a special document that allows him to produce and sell cattle to a slaughterhouse, but it isn't a title, so it doesn't allow him to use the land as loan collateral. Mr. Bueno said tapping credit would permit him to modernize his operation with fertilizer and techniques common elsewhere, raising three times as many head of cattle on the same acreage.
"Land without documentation is nobody's land, so people take advantage of it to clear forest for pastures," Mr. Bueno said.
The immensity of the task of bringing order in the Amazon is evident in remote outposts such as Jonas Lopes de Souza's farm.
Sinewy, with leathery hands and a weather-beaten face, Mr. de Souza, 43, said his goal is putting food on the table for his wife and three children. He grows cacao and raises cattle on a once-forested plot the size of 55 football fields, about 75 acres.
He readily acknowledged, as he walked in worn-out flip-flops through a pasture, that he would cut and burn his way into the brush and trees when he needs fresh land to plant cacao.
"I slash with the scythe, then comes the big red," Mr. de Souza said with a grin, referring to the fires he sets in the dry season to burn the downed vegetation. "I can't make money keeping the forest."
Para, an Amazon state three times the size of California, is pocked with the small farms of settlers like Mr. de Souza who arrived with the hope of a better life.
Years ago, it was large outfits that fueled much of the deforestation. Now, small settlers are to blame, said Daniel Silva, who leads a team at the Brazilian space agency that analyzes satellite images to spot deforestation.
On the computer screen in his office, he pointed to red dots on an outline of the Amazon. "The smaller those areas, the hardest for us" to pinpoint damage, he said.
Until the deed program, the task of changing settlers' behavior fell mostly to outgunned agents such as Denilson Ferreira of Ideflor-bio, a state agency that promotes sustainable development. His job is teaching farmers how to make better use of land, in the hope they can be productive without cutting deeper into the forest.
The lack of legal ownership complicates his work. "We don't even know for sure how many people live in this region," Mr. Ferreira said.
Meanwhile, employees of the federal environmental protection agency, Ibama, say they have too few resources to go after illegal loggers and corrupt officials who sell fake land titles.
Recently, at the dry-season peak when felled trees are burned, only three Ibama agents were operating in Sao Felix do Xingu, a county the size of South Carolina.
When Ibama found out about a major lumber-smuggling operation, its agents couldn't respond because all three had been deployed to guard several hundred head of cattle seized at an illegal farm. An army unit assigned to help protect Ibama agents when they go on risky operations was left cooling its heels, the soldiers kicking a soccer ball around.
"The state is absent here," said Major Afonso Neto, who was leading the army operation. "People here learn from childhood to slash and burn."

Credit: By Paulo Trevisani and Juan Forero

Business News: Blackstone CEO Urges Action on Climate

Author: Beaudette, Marie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/business-news-blackstone-ceo-urges-action-on/docview/2343396268/se-2?accountid=9883

Full text: DAVOS, Switzerland -- Blackstone Group Inc. Chief Executive Stephen Schwarzman said it is clear that the climate is changing, and businesses need to take action.
"You can't watch the news literally anywhere without seeing giant fires and storms happening on a regular basis," Mr. Schwarzman said at a Wall Street Journal event at the World Economic Forum. "There's little doubt that something very profound appears to be going on, and it ought to be addressed."
Climate change is a hot topic at this year's Alpine gathering of world leaders, executives and activists.
In a speech Tuesday, teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg lambasted politicians, saying they aren't doing enough to address climate change.
Shortly before she spoke, President Trump called on the Davos audience to "reject the perennial prophets of doom and their predictions of the apocalypse."
Mr. Schwarzman said the private-equity company he co-founded 35 years ago is looking across its portfolio of companies to improve sustainability. It is also an item on the checklist the firm runs on each deal it considers.
"Ironically, it ends up being good economics," Mr. Schwarzman said.

U.S. News: Last Decade Was Warmest On Record --- NASA, NOAA ranked 2019 as the second- hottest year in tracking dating to 1880

Author: Robert Lee Hotz

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-last-decade-was-warmest-on-record-nasa/docview/2338897329/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Last+Decade+Was+Warmest+On+Record+---+NASA%2C+NOAA+ranked+2019+as+the+second-+hottest+year+in+tracking+dating+to+1880&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Robert+Lee+Hotz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Last+Decade+Was+Warmest+On+Record+---+NASA%2C+NOAA+ranked+2019+as+the+second-+hottest+year+in+tracking+dating+to+1880&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Robert+Lee+Hotz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The world experienced near-record global temperatures in 2019, federal climate scientists said. The year capped what the scientists said was the warmest decadein modern times.
In an annual climate report, scientists at National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which independently track world temperatures, each ranked last year as the second-warmest since systematic record-keeping began in 1880.
"The decade that just ended is clearly the warmest decade on record," said Gavin Schmidt, director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York. "Every decade since the 1960s clearly has been warmer than the one before."
During 2019, the average temperature across global land and ocean surfaces was 1.8 degree Fahrenheit (0.98 degree Celsius) above the 20th-century mean, with 95% certainty, according to the NASA calculations. The NOAA scientists calculated the average global temperature as 1.71 degrees F (0.95 degree C) above the average for 1901 to 2000. Each agency uses slightly different data sets and techniques to arrive at their results.
Their calculations are in line with a recent assessment by the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service, operated by the European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, which last week ranked 2019 as the second-warmest year on record.
All told, 10 of the warmest years in their records occurred in the past decade, the NOAA and NASA scientists said.
Since the 1880s, the average global surface temperature has risen about 2 degrees F (1 degree C), according to scientists at NASA's Goddard Institute.
Much scientific work attributes rising temperatures to greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide from fossil fuel emissions, agriculture and cement production, and land use changes, though some question the connections. Satellite studies of solar energy output since 1978 show the sun doesn't appear to be responsible for the warming trend observed over the past several decades, NASA scientists have reported.
Atmospheric carbon-dioxide levels increased in 2019, reaching a seasonal peak of 414.7 parts per million (ppm) at NOAA's Mauna Loa Atmospheric Baseline Observatory. It was the seventh consecutive year of global increases in concentrations of carbon dioxide, according to data published by NOAA and Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
The warmest year to date was 2016, when an unusually strong El Nino current in the Pacific Ocean boosted warming world-wide by influencing the formation of high- and low-pressure weather systems, trade winds and rainfall. In 2019, a relatively weak El Nino subsided early, the NASA and NOAA scientists said. Ocean heat during 2019 was the highest on record, NOAA scientists said.
Weather dynamics often affect regional temperatures differently, so not every area on Earth experienced the same temperatures last year.
In 2019, Europe recorded its warmest calendar year, experiencing two of the most intense heat waves in its modern history in June and July, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service, which provides climate analytics to EU member countries. Paris registered a high temperature of 108.7 degrees F (42.6 C) in July, breaking a 72-year-old record by 4 degrees F.
For the entire U.S., NOAA scientists found the annual mean temperature for 2019 was the third-warmest on record.
Alaska experienced destructive wildfires that, with those in California, caused damages in excess of $1 billion, NOAA scientists said. In all, NOAA counted 14 weather-related billion-dollar disasters in the U.S. last year.

Credit: By Robert Lee Hotz

BlackRock Tightens Standards for Firms On Climate Change

Author: Lim, Dawn; Steinberg, Julie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/blackrock-tightens-standards-firms-on-climate/docview/2337744117/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=BlackRock+Tightens+Standards+for+Firms+On+Climate+Change&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Lim%2C+Dawn%3BSteinberg%2C+Julie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=BlackRock+Tightens+Standards+for+Firms+On+Climate+Change&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-15&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Lim%2C+Dawn%3BSteinberg%2C+Julie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: BlackRock Inc. said it would take a tougher stance against corporations that aren't providing a full accounting of environmental risks, part of moves by the investment giant to show it is doing more to address investment challenges posed by climate change.
Among the moves, BlackRock said it would be increasingly disposed to vote against management and boards if companies don't disclose climate change risks and plans in line with key industry standards.
BlackRock is also pulling back from thermal coal producers in actively managed debt-and-equity portfolios by mid-2020, a move that will lead to $500 million in sales. It will expand the range of sustainable investment products as well as double to 150 the number of exchange-traded funds that address environmental, social and governance challenges.
BlackRock is the world's largest asset manager, with about $7 trillion under management. It has risen on the back of index funds that trade on exchanges and through these funds has extended its reach across nearly every company and is part of the retirement accounts of millions of people world-wide. It also sits at the backbone of Wall Street as its software is used by banks to monitor their risks.
The firm said it is putting the focus on sustainability because the costs of climate change have ramifications on the price of assets and the financial ecosystem.
"Climate change has become a defining factor in companies' long-term prospects," BlackRock Chief Executive Laurence Fink said in his annual letter. "The evidence on climate risk is compelling investors to reassess core assumptions about modern finance."
The letter is a reflection of Mr. Fink's towering influence over companies. But it has rankled some rivals who have sometimes grumbled about what they consider to be a moralistic tone.
The rise of index funds transformed three firms into major forces among American corporations and thrust them into the public spotlight. The biggest -- BlackRock, Vanguard Group and State Street Corp. -- hold roughly a fifth of the S&P 500 through funds they run for investors. They can cast critical votes and have the ears of chief executives. How they exercise this power -- or choose not to -- has ripple effects across markets.
All three have faced questions over their responsibilities as shareholders on behalf of investors in funds they run. In years past, these firms have targeted gender diversity in boardrooms among other issues. Lately, there has been increased pressure on them to do more on climate change.
BlackRock's offices around the world have been frequented by activists who blast the firm for being slow to act on green issues. The firm has debated a question internally: How can BlackRock ensure it has public support to operate in the countries where it does business as it continues to grow?
The firm said it would provide more information on data on the carbon footprint and other potentially controversial holdings in its mutual funds. It also said it would disclose more details of its conversations with the companies its funds invest in. BlackRock also recently said it had joined Climate Action 100+, the world's largest group of investors by assets pressuring companies to act on climate change.
The moves come as regulators are scrutinizing funds with environmental and social aims, in an effort to determine whether the claims by various asset managers are at odds with reality.
It is a hot corner in the investment management world. Funds focused on sustainability attracted a surge in interest in the past year. U.S. open-ended funds and exchange-traded funds focused on those strategies took in over $20 billion in net flows in 2019, nearly four times more than in the previous year, according to Morningstar Inc.
BlackRock has its eyes on a bigger presence in that market. That could help it win over younger investors and millennials who want to invest money in line with personal values. The firm wants to increase assets it manages in so-called sustainable strategies to more than $1 trillion from $90 billion today.

Credit: By Dawn Lim and Julie Steinberg

____________________________________________________________

Australia Fires Devour Farms and Forests --- 'We've never seen the length of fires that have been occurring, the scale...and intensity'

Author: Emont, Jon; Glynn, James; Winning, David

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/australia-fires-devour-farms-forests-weve-never/docview/2336163251/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Australia+Fires+Devour+Farms+and+Forests+---+%27We%27ve+never+seen+the+length+of+fires+that+have+been+occurring%2C+the+scale...and+intensity%27&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Emont%2C+Jon%3BGlynn%2C+James%3BWinning%2C+David&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Australia+Fires+Devour+Farms+and+Forests+---+%27We%27ve+never+seen+the+length+of+fires+that+have+been+occurring%2C+the+scale...and+intensity%27&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Emont%2C+Jon%3BGlynn%2C+James%3BWinning%2C+David&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: TUMBARUMBA, Australia -- Neil Hamilton spent New Year's Eve shooting his sheep in the head.
He had begun the morning sipping coffee and eating smoked salmon with guests, when flames erupted from a forested ridge outside his farmhouse in this rainy highlands town midway between Sydney and Melbourne.
Within half an hour, a gale was raging outside. As flames approached, Mr. Hamilton, 59, grabbed a hose attached to a pump on his tractor and sprayed water at the approaching flames.
"It got to the stage that if we stayed outside we would have died," he said.
The fire blew past Mr. Hamilton's home, leaving it undamaged, but he emerged to a changed farm. His orchard, with its quince, nectarine and apricot trees, was a smoldering ruin. Most of his 200 sheep had been reduced to charred lumps.
Around 50 stood around silently, their legs blackened and injured from the fire. Mr. Hamilton took his .22-caliber rifle, and went from one to the next, putting them out of their misery.
Fires have ravaged Australia in recent weeks, burning an area roughly 10 times the size burned in California's historic 2018 wildfire season. The flames have spread with stunning speed, cutting off roads in and out of towns and flushing coastal residents to beaches where they were rescued by sea.
Thousands of homes have burned and more than 25 people have died, with blazes expected to keep burning through Australia's summer into February, if not longer.
Beach towns, ski resorts, and dairy farms have fallen to fires that have eaten more than 26,000 square miles of land -- an area larger than West Virginia. Some experts have said the fires could shave as much as 0.4% off economic growth, mainly in the current quarter, and insurance losses are already estimated at around $686 million, based just on claims made so far, according to the Insurance Council of Australia on Friday. That total is sure to rise as more than 100 fires raged Sunday in New South Wales, the southeastern part of the continent, which has borne the brunt of the disaster.
Around Tumbarumba, dozens of houses and farm buildings have been destroyed. Commercial pine forests, which can take two decades to grow, have gone up in flames. Blueberry fields have been torched, along with vineyards and hazelnut groves.
A dry continent, Australia has a history of wildfires. But this year's fires are different. They started earlier in the season and have spread to places, such as Tumbarumba, that rarely had intense fires in the past.
"We've never seen the length of fires that have been occurring, the scale across the areas and intensity of the fires," said Mathew Crowther, a professor in the school of life and environmental sciences at the University of Sydney.
Australia has become steadily hotter over the past century, with most warming happening since 1950, according to the country's Bureau of Meteorology. Last year was the warmest since records began in 1910, exacerbating a drought in eastern states and creating conditions for bush fires. Tumbarumba, in New South Wales state, got around 40% less rain than in a typical December.
The damage is worsened by decisions that put more people at risk. Rising inner-city home prices push Australians into distant suburbs brushing up against the forest.
The population of Sydney -- ringed by the ocean and national parks -- has risen rapidly in recent years and is projected by government statisticians to expand by up to 25% in the decade through mid-2027. Even faster growth is forecast for Melbourne, which could become Australia's biggest city. Both cities have experienced smoky conditions from the fires.
Younger Australians, like American millennials, are increasingly moving from pricey urban centers to less-dense parts of the country, a trend business analysts refer to as "tree-change." Places like Yanchep, 35 miles from Perth in Western Australia, saw its population double from 2011 to 2016, putting the town of around 10,000 under threat from fires that tore through Yanchep National Park in December.
The population shifts have strained firefighting resources.Some experts say rural Australia needs more dedicated firefighters.
"The heavy lifting is being done by volunteers," said Dale Dominey-Howes, a geographer and disaster-risk-management expert at the University of Sydney. "As Australia's climate destabilizes, we need a larger standing workforce that deals with natural disasters."
Australians and their leaders are questioning whether their way of life must change.
Prime Minister Scott Morrison has said an inquiry will happen once the emergency response ends, looking at everything from hazard reduction to building codes in rural areas. He has set up a $1.4 billion recovery fund and mobilized 3,000 defense-force reservists to provide immediate help, including dropping animal feed to farmers from helicopters, and to begin the lengthy rebuild.
Mr. Morrison's climate policy has been criticized by environmentalists and political opponents for favoring coal-mining interests over efforts to limit emissions. He has said his government aims to bring Australia's emissions down, but without harming economic growth or driving up the cost of electricity. Australia is responsible for around 1.3% of global emissions, according to the Australian Department for the Environment and Energy. China and the U.S. are the world's top two polluters, together accounting for around 40% of global carbon dioxide emissions in 2018, according to research group Global Climate Atlas.
Australia has long used prescribed burning -- fires deliberately lit by authorities in benign weather to rid the forest floor of dry twigs and other fuel -- to reduce the risk of bush fires. More than 1,000 controlled burns were carried out in the past five years to clear more than 1.5 million acres of dead vegetation.
Dry conditions have made the measures harder, because prescribed burns can be more difficult to control, narrowing the window for action, while recent hot and windy weather limits the tactic's effectiveness.
Officials also have had to contend with arson, with two dozen people already charged by New South Wales police with deliberately starting bush fires this season.
The sentiment that rural communities lack proper protection is shared in Tumbarumba, which has a small permanent firefighting team of two trucks and a crew of 10, backed by volunteers.
Robyn Jones, the proprietor of the Tumbarumba Motel, which has housed 60 firefighters during the crisis, said the government severely underinvested in fire response. She said more aircraft should have been available to drop water and spray retardant sooner, and that the state hadn't employed enough workers to maintain the forest. "We just had nothing to stop the fire," she said.
A town of about 1,850 people about 300 miles southwest of Sydney by road, Tumbarumba has been around since the 1800s. More recently, it bet big on forestry, with pine plantations and one of the Southern Hemisphere's largest softwood mills nearby. It has an antiques shop, artists' studio and a single gas station.
Fires have only occasionally been a problem, because Tumbarumba has plentiful rainfall and a temperate climate -- perfect for growing blueberries and grapes for wine.
Mr. Hamilton, the sheep farmer, moved there 2 1/2 years ago after stints in Canberra and Norway, where he worked overseeing climate change research for a nongovernment organization. He and his wife, Grazyna, 61, began building a modernist home to retire in with large windows overlooking pastures.
As fires spread around Australia in December, locals began getting worried. Then, on Dec. 28, lightning struck north of the area, sparking flames.
At the urging of community leaders, most residents peeled away to safer towns. A hard-core group of 200, including Mr. Hamilton, stayed behind to save what they could.
At 12:45 a.m. on New Year's Eve, residents with properties outside of Tumbarumba began getting text messages warning them flames were coming. At 8:15 a.m., Joerg Ernst, the 45-year-old captain of the town's fire and rescue service, got a message saying fire had broken out on Blue Dogs Lane, on the town's fringe.
Mr. Ernst had been working late the night before in a nearby town where winds whipped up by a pyro-convective column -- something like a fire tornado -- had overturned a 10-ton firetruck, killing a volunteer firefighter and injuring three others. This time, he and some colleagues rushed out so quickly that they didn't have time to put on face masks to protect themselves from smoke.
Blue Dogs Lane was ablaze. Mr. Ernst could also see the fire racing up a tree-lined gully toward other properties. The owner of one, clutching a hose, was staring it down with plans to retreat to the basement if defense proved hopeless. Mr. Ernst's truck discharged some water, bolstering the house's protection, before moving on.
Soon, though, an old community hall was completely on fire and the truck was low on water. One crew member needed oxygen after inhaling smoke and had to withdraw.
The flames were consuming other properties. Another crew member realized flames were approaching his own home on Hilltop Road, which he had been building for years. Mr. Ernst recalls his colleague responded stoically, recognizing it was already lost.
In the chaos, fire crews couldn't be sure where the fire front was, and where it was going next. By 2 p.m., the main blaze had veered away from town and was heading up a forested hill, threatening a communications tower.
Area residents took stock.Fires had damaged packing equipment and vehicles at the Costa berry farms, and torched vines at the family-owned Johansen winery.
Another resident, Adam Gatford, found that 20% of his property's 1,000 chestnut trees were blackened, wiping out any expected profit for the season. It will take seven years before their replacements produce a viable crop, the 46-year-old grower said.
Authorities canceled a New Year's Day rodeo, held since 1945. Without power to run his refrigerator, the owner of the historic Union Hotel bar gave his meat to fire crews rather than see it spoiled.
In the days that followed, residents knew the fire danger wasn't over. It was smoldering in forests behind Tumbarumba, susceptible to winds that could make it jump "the box," as local firefighters call active fire areas hemmed in by man-made breaks, like bulldozed earth.
On Jan. 4, authorities warned residents that a wind change would put Tumbarumba back in the line of the blaze. This time, residents got lucky: The inferno steered away from the town center.
Five days later, however, officials told a meeting hall packed with anxious residents that conditions were set to worsen again.
By early afternoon plumes of smoke appeared on Mt. Ikes, overlooking Tumbarumba, heralding the battle to come. Power supply, which had gone down during the New Year's Eve fires, had failed again. The sun was baking, and wind picked up straw off the ground. Patches of yellow grass began spontaneously smoking.
By Friday evening, flames were leaping over man-made breaks, and trees lit up.
An evacuation call went out: Residents in the southern and eastern parts of town were told to gather in an area called the Oval, which had a fire-resistant building near the rodeo grounds.
Others, like Mr. Hamilton, the sheep farmer, stayed in their homes, preparing to fight again.
"We have too much skin in the game" to leave, Mr. Hamilton said. His home isn't insured yet because one section is still under construction. He set his phone alarm each hour during the night, so he could scan the horizon for fires.
Then the wind shifted. By midnight, it pushed fires toward a neighboring town, and residents were told they could return to their homes. Exhausted firefighters, their orange fire suits stained with ash, went back to the Tumbarumba Motel for a few hours of sleep.
The constant threat of more fires was taking a mental toll.
It had taken more than a week for Lucy Henderson, 58, to work up the courage to visit the shell of her homestead several miles outside of Tumbarumba that she has lived in for more than a decade. The fires had reduced the house to a mess of black dust, metal and stone. Ms. Henderson sobbed in front of it.
Her next step would be sift through the wreckage to find her wedding ring. "I've already cried a river of tears over this," she said.
Fires continue to burn out of control in the area. Current advice from Australia's Rural Fire Service is that fires are burning toward Tumbarumba again.

Cherry Blossoms Can't Wait for Spring

Author: Brody, Leslie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cherry-blossoms-cant-wait-spring/docview/2336163237/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Cherry+Blossoms+Can%27t+Wait+for+Spring&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10B&amp;au=Brody%2C+Leslie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Cherry+Blossoms+Can%27t+Wait+for+Spring&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10B&amp;au=Brody%2C+Leslie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Some New Yorkers did a double-take as cherry blossoms flowered in Central Park over the past few days, thanks to unusually mild weather.
Light-pink cherry blossoms are traditionally a sign of spring, when many cities hold festivals in their honor. But a stretch of unseasonably warm days recently has had some species of cherry trees strutting their stuff.
Temperatures hit a record 69 degrees in Central Park on Saturday and made it to 67 degrees Sunday afternoon, according to the National Weather Service.
Admirers passing by a cherry tree budding next to the park's Great Lawn on Friday expressed a mix of delight and concern that it might be yet another reminder of climate change.
"This is gorgeous, but at the same time, is this a sign of the end of time?" asked Isa Julson, a lawyer walking with her 4-month-old baby strapped to her chest. She was accompanied by her brother, Jack Julson, who was visiting from St. Paul, Minn.
"This is a tropical vacation," he said. "I did want to see a snowy Central Park, but it's not going to happen."
A spokesman for the Central Park Conservancy said the Weeping Higan Cherry, now blooming in the park and elsewhere in the city, has flowered during warm spells in winter before, and shouldn't be harmed by doing so now.
Some scientists have been tracking the schedule of spring cherry tree blooms in Washington, D.C., and Kyoto, Japan, to see how a trend toward earlier flowering may be related to climate change.
In the area including New York City and Long Island, the average daytime high for January hit 40 degrees last year, after trending up about 2 degrees overall since 1895, according to the National Centers for Environmental Information at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
In winter, "It's much more likely you'll have stretches of warm weather now than in the 1900s," said David Easterling, a climate scientist at the organization. Such warming is due to increasing greenhouse gases, he said, mainly because of the burning of fossil fuels.
The forecast highs for Central Park this weekend were about 25 degrees above normal, said Cynthia Rosenzweig, head of the Climate Impacts Group at NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies and former chair of the New York City Panel on Climate Change. She said that from Jan. 1 through Jan. 9, Central Park was running about 6 degrees above normal.
"It is startling even for scientists to see how rapidly the climate is changing," she said.
A spokeswoman for the Brooklyn Botanic Garden said one of its cherry species, known as the "ever blooming" tree, flowered in late December a few years ago during a warm stretch. In 2012, the botanic garden's arborist Christopher Roddick expressed concern about having some of its other cherry trees blooming two weeks ahead of expectations, in an article titled "A Budding Crisis?" He warned that some trees that bud early could be damaged if hit by frost, affecting their fruit yields, as well as the birds and insects that depend on their nectar.
As much as some New Yorkers were unsettled by the high temperatures, many celebrated a chance to enjoy it.
"This is glorious," said Sarah Stock, who was thrilled to get to Central Park with her 6-week-old daughter asleep in a stroller. "Long term it's not the best, but for the here and now, we're happy to be out of the house."

Credit: By Leslie Brody

Environmental-Rule Proposal Aims to Speed Major Projects

Author: Puko, Timothy

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/environmental-rule-proposal-aims-speed-major/docview/2334969654/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Environmental-Rule+Proposal+Aims+to+Speed+Major+Projects&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Puko%2C+Timothy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Environmental-Rule+Proposal+Aims+to+Speed+Major+Projects&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Puko%2C+Timothy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON -- President Trump proposed the first comprehensive overhaul of National Environmental Policy Act rules in more than 40 years, saying changes are needed to streamline approval of highways, energy pipelines and other infrastructure projects, as part of his administration's broader efforts to pare environmental regulations.
The proposal was hailed by business groups, energy companies and construction unions but criticized by environmentalists, who said it comes as mounting threats posed by climate change make thorough review of infrastructure projects more critical than ever.
Among the more than a dozen proposed changes to NEPA's environmental-permit rules, the government for the first time would set limits for completion of environmental reviews, which can sometimes take a decade or longer. Full environmental impact statements would need to be completed within two years, while less comprehensive environmental assessments would have to be concluded within one year.
"We want to build new roads, bridges, tunnels, highways bigger, better, faster," Mr. Trump said from the White House, joined by business and union leaders. "These endless delays waste money, keep projects from breaking ground and deny jobs to our nation's incredible workers."
The plan, which is subject to public hearings before it can be approved, faces likely court challenges from environmental groups and Democratic-led states. Some congressional Democrats said Thursday that the proposed rewrite was illegal. But leaders in both parties said the overhaul, if enacted, could mark the administration's most significant change to environmental regulation.
"Forcing federal agencies to ignore environmental threats is a disgraceful abdication of our responsibility to protect the planet for future generations," Brett Hartl, government affairs director at the Center for Biological Diversity, said this week, anticipating the overhaul plan. He called it a "gift to the fossil-fuel industry."
Mr. Hartl and other critics are concerned the overhaul is the latest in a series of Trump administration efforts to limit the government's ability to address climate change.
Recent U.S. government and United Nations reports have sounded increasingly urgent alarms, saying the world must sharply curb greenhouse-gas emissions from fossil fuels to avoid the most catastrophic outcomes. Mr. Trump, a Republican, and his cabinet members have dismissed those warnings or said they don't have legal, effective ways to address them. They have instead moved to ease environmental regulations to help manufacturing and fossil-fuel development.
Industrial interests and building trade unions have said that NEPA, enacted in 1970, has become a tool of obstruction by environmental groups, which energy companies are fighting to build more pipeline capacity amid the recent boom in U.S. oil and gas production.
Sean McGarvey, president of North America's Building Trades Unions, a labor group allied with energy and pipeline companies, praised the administration's NEPA proposal as a way to limit how long some of those disputes can last.
"We are fully supportive of the president's initiative," said Mr. McGarvey, who joined Mr. Trump at the White House Thursday.
Supporters welcomed the move as a long-awaited effort to cut red tape by an administration that has so far failed to deliver on big promises to jump-start infrastructure development. Business groups have said lengthy NEPA reviews are partly to blame for the nearly $1 trillion backlog of transportation projects alone.
"Our country is at a pivotal time for American energy," said Anne Bradbury, chief executive of the American Exploration & Production Council, a trade group for some of the country's largest independent oil-and-gas companies. "The administration's modernization of NEPA removes bureaucratic barriers that were stifling construction of key infrastructure projects needed for U.S. producers to deliver energy in a safe and environmentally protective way."
The National Association of Manufacturers "called for exactly this type of modernization," the trade group's leader, Jay Timmons, said. "Our efforts should be used for building the infrastructure Americans desperately need, not wasted on mountains of paperwork and endless delays."
Mr. Trump said it took more than two decades to finish reviews for a runway at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. He said that it took longer to start construction on a 2.8-mile bridge connection in North Carolina's Outer Banks.
"It took four years to build the Golden Gate Bridge, five years to build the Hoover Dam," Mr. Trump said, citing projects that predated by decades modern environmental standards, or research on the impacts of such projects.
Approval for Mr. Trump's changes isn't certain. Public hearings and review will take months, and many doubt the administration will have time to enact the changes before the Nov. 3 election.
Rep. Raul Grijalva (D., Ariz.), chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, called the rewrite illegal, potentially foreshadowing the lawsuits that could further delay or block an overhaul. He said courts have ruled that NEPA requires consideration of climate change, and any move counter to that could invalidate the proposal.
The battle lines are likely to be drawn in the fine print of the overhaul's mechanics.
Part of the Trump administration's push is to limit the scope of what agencies have to consider, and Mr. Trump said federal duplication of local and state efforts often causes delays.
Some Democrats counter that reviews often drag on now because declines in the government workforce leave fewer people to handle more work. They said insufficient consideration of climate change will only cost taxpayers more in the long run, through higher insurance bills and shorter lifespans for new projects.
"This NEPA rewrite favors big polluters and corporate profits over balanced, science-based decision making," said Sen. Maria Cantwell of Washington, the top-ranking Democrat on the Commerce Committee.
---
Catherine Lucey and Andrew Restuccia contributed to this article.

Credit: By Timothy Puko

Full text: MISSOURI
Firefighter Dies in
Residential Blaze
A Missouri firefighter died after falling through a floor while battling a house fire.
The fire was reported shortly after 11 a.m. Sunday in the laundry room of a home in Peculiar, Mo., which is about 30 miles south of Kansas City, Mo.
Grandview Fire Chief Ron Graham said the firefighter fell through the floor near the front door as firefighters entered the home. The firefighter was taken to a hospital where he died.
The family that lives in the home was able to escape before firefighters arrived.
-- Associated Press
---
CALIFORNIA
Climate Bond Mulled
For Disaster Plans
California lawmakers are set to weigh a $4.2 billion climate bond that would allow the state to borrow money to prepare for natural disasters.
The borrowing proposal, a holdover bill from last year, would have to pass at least one legislative chamber by the end of January to have a chance at becoming law.
Catastrophic wildfires have destroyed thousands of homes, generating billions of dollars in insurance claims and costing taxpayers billions more in cleanup costs. The bulk of the borrowing proposal would go toward reducing wildfire risk throughout the state. It also includes money to protect farmland from climate change, bolster the state's water sources and help coastal communities plan for sea-level rise.
The $4.2 billion price tag could grow as lawmakers discuss adding more projects for things like buying solar batteries and fuel cells to keep the lights on at nursing homes and other vulnerable sites when utility companies pre-emptively shut off electricity.
-- Associated Press
---
CONSERVATION
Counting Whales
From Space Pitched
An aquarium and an engineering firm in Massachusetts are partnering on a project to better protect whales by monitoring them from space.
New England Aquarium of Boston and Draper of Cambridge say whale conservation needs new, higher-tech solutions to protect whales from extinction. So, the pair is working together using data from sources such as satellites, sonar and radar to keep a closer eye on how many whales are in the ocean.
The effort, which the aquarium and firm are calling "Counting Whales From Space," involves gathering data from sources ranging from European space agencies to amateur radio operators to create a probability map of where in the ocean the whales might be, said John Irvine, chief scientist for data analytics with Draper.
-- Associated Press

World News: Austria's Greens To Govern With Right

Author: Pancevski, Bojan

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-austrias-greens-govern-with-right/docview/2331712953/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Austria%27s+Greens+To+Govern+With+Right&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Pancevski%2C+Bojan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Austria%27s+Greens+To+Govern+With+Right&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2020-01-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Pancevski%2C+Bojan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Austria's Conservatives and Greens agreed to form a new government in a move that could inspire similar alliances across Europe, where incumbent center-right parties are looking to harness rising voter interest in the environment to fight off insurgencies led by populist rivals.
The coalition under former Conservative Chancellor Sebastian Kurz was announced by both parties as a marriage between liberal economic reforms, including tax cuts, and new environmental policies driven by the growing popular movement in Europe demanding action against climate change.
The new government, which came together three months after federal elections in late September, is expected to pursue a reformist agenda that could put pressure on European leaders such as Angela Merkel of Germany, who has been criticized at home for failing to address voters' climate-related concerns.
Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in Germany and across Europe calling for action on climate change throughout last year, which saw a record surge of the Green parties in the polls in Germany, Austria and elsewhere. According to polls in Germany, any feasible coalition at the moment would have to include an alliance between Ms. Merkel's Christian Democrats and the Greens.
Mr. Kurz, an outspoken critic of illegal immigration and one of the rising hopes for Europe's conservatives, is now a chancellor-designate. He already served as chancellor until May 2019, when his coalition government collapsed because the leader of his then junior coalition partner, a far-right nationalist, resigned after video emerged of him offering public contracts to a woman he believed to be the niece of a Moscow oligarch. Austria has been under a caretaker government since then.
Though the scandal led to a snap election, Mr. Kurz -- one of the world's youngest leaders at age 33 -- weathered the crisis and achieved a record result for his conservative party in September. Like President Trump and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, Mr. Kurz remodeled his conservative party after his own image before winning the elections. He campaigned on an anti-immigration ticket and a promise to cut taxes and reform Austria's social and welfare systems.
"We achieved a breakthrough," Mr. Kurz told a press conference in Vienna on Wednesday night after the coalition talks. "It is possible to slash taxes and make environment-friendly tax policies. It is possible to protect the environment and protect the borders."
Mr. Kurz said the coalition agreement united what he called the best policies of the conservatives and the Greens. He said his new government would deliver tax breaks and effective environmental and climate policies, while maintaining a hard line against illegal immigration and political Islam.
Werner Kogler, the designated vice chancellor and head of the Greens, said Austria would become Europe's leader in environmental policies.
Concessions that Mr. Kurz's party extracted from the coalition talks include a ban on the Islamic veil for girls younger than 14, according to people familiar with the negotiations, while the Greens got Mr. Kurz to accept an environmental tax for trucks and airplane tickets.

Credit: By Bojan Pancevski

World News: China Still Burns for Coal As Beijing Shifts Priorities

Author: Yang, Stephanie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-china-still-burns-coal-as-beijing/docview/2330016357/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+China+Still+Burns+for+Coal+As+Beijing+Shifts+Priorities&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.16&amp;au=Yang%2C+Stephanie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+China+Still+Burns+for+Coal+As+Beijing+Shifts+Priorities&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.16&amp;au=Yang%2C+Stephanie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: BEIJING -- China's efforts to wean itself off coal are losing steam, as the world's biggest carbon emitter is putting economic growth and energy security above its ambitions to be a leader in combating climate change.
Coal consumption is back near peak levels after rebounding over the past three years, despite China's pledges to make steep cuts in what is the country's most prevalent and polluting source of energy. The country is building more coal-fired plant capacity than the rest of the world combined.
Infrastructure stimulus measures to offset the impact of the prolonged trade war with the U.S. have boosted consumption, while Beijing has taken a softer stance on coal use after a missile attack in September on Saudi Arabia, China's biggest source of oil imports, underscored the country's reliance on foreign energy.
The renewed focus on coal has raised doubts among analysts over China's commitment to cutting carbon emissions and frustrated the European Union, which has leaned on China to uphold the Paris Agreement since President Trump pulled the U.S. out in 2017. While China is on track to meet its goals through 2020 and 2030, its mixed signals on coal suggest Beijing is less willing to pursue green-energy goals and join the EU in setting more-ambitious emission targets.
"China was seen, particularly by the developing and emerging economies, as the leader, saying look at all the wonderful stuff we're doing," said Philip Andrews-Speed, senior principal fellow at the Energy Studies Institute at the National University of Singapore. But the country has continued construction on new coal plants even as it aims to phase out the fossil fuel, he said: "There's a deep contradiction in this."
In an October speech at a National Energy Commission meeting, Premier Li Keqiang called for the development of the coal industry to ensure energy security. The remarks were widely seen as a shift from previous statements and a sign that the government is backing off its anticoal message.
Efforts to boost the economy through infrastructure investment have also driven overall consumption higher, analysts said.
China's steel output reached a record 750 million metric tons in 2019, but will likely come back down in 2020 as housing construction slows, according to Charles Li, associate director at Fitch Ratings. Data from the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air show coal demand has increased by 7% and 11% in metals and chemicals sectors, respectively, this year through October.
"China had a very genuine claim to being a leader on climate change," said Lauri Myllyvirta, lead analyst at the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air. "Now that there has been a domestic shift, that's harder to portray."
In 2014, China and the U.S. agreed to coordinate on carbon-emission cuts in an effort to propel international negotiations. That year, coal consumption fell for the first time in China after peaking in 2013.
"Climate was seen as a key positive area of the relationship between China and the United States and that really gave it additional priority," Mr. Myllyvirta added.
After Mr. Trump announced the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, China initially positioned itself as an emerging leader in the efforts to combat climate change. But without the same pressure from the U.S., some analysts said, China's commitment has waned in the face of other economic and political challenges.
One effect of the trade war between the U.S. and China is an increased emphasis on pursuing energy independence, which has likely contributed to support for coal, said Erica Downs, senior research scholar at Columbia University's Center on Global Energy Policy.
"You have this balancing act going on," Ms. Downs said. "They're still committing to cleaning and greening the energy mix, but it's not always a linear progression."

Credit: By Stephanie Yang

Decade in Review (A Special Report) --- For Business, Climate Change Became Real

Author: Hodari, David

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/decade-review-special-report-business-climate/docview/2327801877/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Decade+in+Review+%28A+Special+Report%29+---+For+Business%2C+Climate+Change+Became+Real&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=R.4&amp;au=Hodari%2C+David&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Decade+in+Review+%28A+Special+Report%29+---+For+Business%2C+Climate+Change+Became+Real&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=R.4&amp;au=Hodari%2C+David&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The debate over climate change intensified over the decade, amid several of the hottest years on record, several extreme weather events and the publication of a wave of reports on warming. That -- along with attention to the issue by policymakers in many countries and increasingly heated rhetoric -- brought the issue to the doorstep of business, in the form of environmental disclosures, carbon pledges and green investment.
Big companies, like Amazon.com and Nestle, set out ambitious -- if long-term -- plans to become carbon-neutral over decades. A few companies shifted their focus, such as Equinor AS, a European integrated oil company that turned toward renewable energy.
Climate activists focused a lot of their energy on companies, saying they have a long way to go. A faster pace, they say, will be necessary not only to prevent the worst effects of climate change, but also to sustain businesses as regulations evolve. "If this is what taking climate change seriously looks like, then we have some real problems," says Lewis Grant, senior equities portfolio manager at Hermes Investment Management. "Most companies recognize man-made climate change, but they're underestimating the risks."
Companies unveiling efforts to address climate change face steep challenges. The transportation industry remains dependent on fossil fuels, for instance. Change is also slow in agriculture. Total emissions from global livestock represent some 14.5% of all human-related greenhouse-gas emissions, according to the United Nations.
Agriculture giants have signed pledges against deforestation and in favor of better soil management and net-zero emissions. But tied up with reducing agricultural emissions is a full-scale change in food culture around the world.
Meanwhile, activist investors drove a multibillion-dollar ESG sector with goals of investing in companies with strong environmental, social and governance practices.
Global investment in renewable power and fuels has risen in recent years, climbing to $289 billion in 2018 from $177 billion 10 years earlier, according to Bloomberg New Energy Finance. That growth hasn't been uninterrupted, though; 2018's figure was down from $326 billion in 2017.
Investment "has changed, and investors are working more closely with companies who are authentic in their efforts to curb climate change, but they've become more vocal and organized with the companies who have not," says Leslie Samuelrich, president of Green Century Capital Management Inc.
---
Mr. Hodari is a Wall Street Journal reporter in London. Email david.hodari@wsj.com.

Credit: By David Hodari

World News: Drought Crisis Leaves Southern Africa High and Dry

Author: Bariyo, Nicholas

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-drought-crisis-leaves-southern-africa/docview/2326752930/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Drought+Crisis+Leaves+Southern+Africa+High+and+Dry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Bariyo%2C+Nicholas&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Drought+Crisis+Leaves+Southern+Africa+High+and+Dry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Bariyo%2C+Nicholas&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Every Monday at 8 p.m. since November, Bulawayo residents have gathered next to their toilets to prepare for a ritual that has come to be known as the big flush -- another sign of a water emergency across southern Africa.
For the 700,000 residents of Zimbabwe's second-largest city, flushing outside government-mandated times puts them at the risk of being fined.
Economies in the region are reeling from a second historic drought in three years, leaving 45 million people facing water and food crises, according to the United Nations. That marks a sharp rise in recent years, the U.N. and other aid agencies said.
In Zambia, a drought that has ravaged the corn harvest is forcing families to survive on wild plants and roots, while in Namibia, 30,000 drought-related cattle deaths have been recorded since April and some 200 elephants have starved to death in national parks along the Zambezi River.
Since December, the volume of water pouring from the Zambezi over the massive Victoria Falls, at the border where Zimbabwe meets Zambia, has fallen more than 50% to its lowest level in 25 years, alarming government officials who have suggested that models predict that the falls could one day run dry.
"The pictures of the Victoria Falls are a stark reminder of what climate change is doing to our environment and our livelihood," Zambian President Edgar Lungu said this month. "No doubt that developing countries like Zambiaare the most impacted by climate change and the least able to afford its consequences."
He has outlined steps his government is taking in an effort to head off the crisis. Zambia, he said, is promoting agricultural practices including the pursuit of drought-resistant food crops, construction of more-resilient roads and water-harvesting facilities, and strengthening the regulation of groundwater resources.
One of the key drivers changing southern Africa's climate is accelerating deforestation, as growing populations are cutting into forests to sell timber to Asian and Western markets. The forests act like giant sponges that absorb carbon dioxide, the heat-trapping gas that contributes to global warming.
Hotter and drier summers have accompanied the loss of forest cover, with temperatures expected to rise at twice the global average in the region across Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi, Namibia and Mozambique. This year, southern Africa has seen its lowest rainfall since it was first recorded in 1981, according to the Botswana-based intergovernmental organization Southern African Development Community.
Last week, South Africa's Weather Service issued a flood warning for multiple provinces following unusually heavy rains, although abnormally hot weather continues in some parts of the country.
"We need to accept that climate change is a reality and it continues to create imbalances in our rainfall patterns and seasonal changes," Lindiwe Sisulu, South Africa's water and sanitation minister, said this month.
The drought problem seems most acute in Zimbabwe, where the extreme weather comes amid an economic emergency.
"The droughts are different now," said Thandiwe Sibanda, a 32-year-old mother of two in the capital, Harare. She hasn't had running water for months and now wakes up at 4 a.m. to fetch water from a community well.

World News: U.N. Climate Talks Fail to Reach Accord

Author: Peker, Emre

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-u-n-climate-talks-fail-reach-accord/docview/2326752861/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+U.N.+Climate+Talks+Fail+to+Reach+Accord&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Peker%2C+Emre&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+U.N.+Climate+Talks+Fail+to+Reach+Accord&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Peker%2C+Emre&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Climate negotiators failed to strengthen targets to cut emissions or to create a global carbon-trading system, two main goals of the 2015 Paris accord, as the impending U.S. exit from the pact exacerbated challenges to cut record-high planet-warming gases.
Delegates from nearly 200 nations sparred for two weeks in Madrid at the annual United Nations climate summit without setting new emissions targets before next year's U.N. convention in Glasgow or creating a framework to reward and encourage efforts to cut emissions.
"Regretfully, after all the hard work that you have all done we couldn't get to an agreement," said Chile's Environment Minister Carolina Schmidt, who presided over the summit that ended Sunday. "The new generations expect more from us."
Outside the conference, activists representing environmentalists, youth groups and endangered communities demanded action to curb global warming. Inside the venue, President Trump and Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's climate skepticism clashed with a European-led coalition pressing for ambitious rules to enforce the Paris pact.
Financing to help poorer countries transition into less-polluting technology also proved contentious. The issue deepened the divide between less-developed countries that account for a fraction of greenhouse-gas releases and economic powers responsible for the vast majority of it.
Many scientists warn that the threat of climate change attributed to human activities is growing more urgent. Long-term effects are being seen in coastal flooding, heat waves and changes in ecosystems, U.S. federal scientists said this year.
The last five years have been the hottest since temperatures have been measured. In September, a scientific panel under U.N. auspices said oceans are warming and ice sheets disappearing and that human communities and wildlife are at risk.
"We lack the ambition needed to avoid this climate emergency," Norway's youth delegate to the U.N. summit, Sofie Nordvik, said Sunday. "Our leaders need to step up . . . we don't have the time."
Major powers that account for more than 75% of human-generated global emissions -- including China, the U.S., the European Union, India and Russia -- risk missing their emissions-reduction goals. Some countries are also taking steps that further undermine the climate pact.
China, the top emitter globally, is adding more coal-fired plants than the rest of the world combined, while also building them internationally. The U.S., the world's second-largest emitter, is rolling back emissions-reducing rules on energy and transport enacted by the Obama administration. U.S. carbon emissions rose 3.4% in 2018, after three years of declines, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
"The world's largest emitters are not pulling their weight, and without them our goal is unreachable," U.N. Secretary- General Antonio Guterres said before the climate summit convened. As talks concluded, he added: "The international community lost an important opportunity."
In an effort to counter the backtracking among major powers, the EU committed on Friday to reaching net-zero emissions by 2050. EU member Poland, however, declined to implement the plan until at least June and demanded financial guarantees to transition its economy, which relies 80% on coal-fired power.
The EU, the world's third-largest emitter, pushed at the U.N. summit for rules on international carbon markets. In the end, European negotiators refused demands from countries including Brazil, India and Australia.
The Brazil-led efforts, European negotiators and climate activists say, would lead to double-counting of emission cuts and usher in a trove of carbon credits granted under the Kyoto Protocol, the Paris accord's predecessor.
Those would contribute to watering down the climate pact and amount to cosmetic emissions cuts without arresting rising temperatures, these people said.
"We are disappointed," the EU delegation said in a Sunday statement. "We cannot support global rules which would undermine environmental integrity."
Despite the setback to a global carbon market, an existing framework suffices for national and regional initiatives, say climate experts. The EU already has the world's biggest emissions trading system, covering energy-heavy industrial plants. This month, the EU and Switzerland linked their carbon markets, signaling a way forward for other countries.
Developing countries need more than $4.4 trillion from 2020 through 2030 to implement measures under the Paris accord.
"Anybody out of the continent saying we should not develop [oil and gas] fields, that is criminal. It is very unfair," Equatorial Guinea's Mines, Industry and Energy Minister Gabriel Obiang Lima said recently.

Credit: By Emre Peker
