City News: Action on Climate Change --- New York outspends other megacities on countermeasures to rising water levels

Author: Robert Lee Hotz

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/city-news-action-on-climate-change-new-york/docview/1768780870/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: While policy makers debate how best to curb global greenhouse-gas emissions that many scientists consider a leading cause of rising temperatures, efforts to adapt to the consequences of climate change have become a growth economy, steadily rising about 27% during the past seven years, the analysts said.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=City+News%3A+Action+on+Climate+Change+---+New+York+outspends+other+megacities+on+countermeasures+to+rising+water+levels&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.15&amp;au=Robert+Lee+Hotz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=City+News%3A+Action+on+Climate+Change+---+New+York+outspends+other+megacities+on+countermeasures+to+rising+water+levels&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.15&amp;au=Robert+Lee+Hotz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   New York City spends more to brace for rising seas and other side effects of climate change than any other of the world's 10 biggest cities -- about $2.2 billion last year -- outstripping spending by London, Paris, Beijing, Mexico City and other megacities, according to an analysis released Monday by researchers at the U.K.'s University College London.
While policy makers debate how best to curb global greenhouse-gas emissions that many scientists consider a leading cause of rising temperatures, efforts to adapt to the consequences of climate change have become a growth economy, steadily rising about 27% during the past seven years, the analysts said.
"Despite the level of political rhetoric in the U.S. and the U.K., cities like London and New York are taking climate adaptation seriously because they realize they have things at risk and things to protect," said the study's lead researcher Lucien Georgeson in London.
The study, reported Monday in Nature Climate Change, is among the first to assess how much cities are spending to prepare for climate change.
To gauge how spending varies globally, Mr. Georgeson and his colleagues looked at climate-related finances during a single fiscal year in 10 of the world's largest cities, as measured by population and gross domestic product: New York, London, Paris, Beijing, Mexico City, Sao Paulo, Mumbai, Jakarta, Lagos and Addis Ababa. The researchers pulled together financial data from hundreds of independent sources.
By their calculation, New York spent more than 100 times as much as Addis Ababa during the 2014-2015 fiscal year under study.
"We found the difference between Addis Ababa and New York to be really striking," said Mr. Georgeson.
On a per capita basis, Paris spent the most of the 10 cities, about $553 per resident. New York spent about half that, about $269 per capita. But Jakarta, Lagos and Addis Ababa, where urban population growth in coming decades is expected to be among the highest, spent less than one-tenth per person the amount funded by New York.
All told, New York City is spending about $20 billion in local, state and federal funding on various climate-change countermeasures that will take many years to complete, city officials said.
About half of that is going toward coastal protection and urban drainage projects, to better shield hospitals, subways, public housing, and power equipment from storm-surge flooding.
"We are, at the same time, investing billions to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions," said Daniel A. Zarrilli, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's senior director of climate policy and programs.
Credit: By Robert Lee Hotz

World News: Vietnam's New Tack in Climate Fight

Author: Hookway, James

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-vietnams-new-tack-climate-fight/docview/1767832017/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The idea behind the Paris pact is that richer countries -- the ones mostly to blame for pollution that scientists say is contributing to rising temperatures and higher sea levels -- should pay to help poorer ones adjust.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Vietnam%27s+New+Tack+in+Climate+Fight&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.9&amp;au=Hookway%2C+James&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Vietnam%27s+New+Tack+in+Climate+Fight&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.9&amp;au=Hookway%2C+James&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   NAM DIEN, Vietnam -- Vietnam's economic planners have set out on what could be their biggest-ever engineering project: A network of walls designed to hold back rising sea levels that are swamping fertile rice-growing regions.
At first glance, it is the kind of multidecade effort that the world's richer countries might throw their weight behind. In Paris in December, industrialized nations committed to providing $100 billion a year to help poorer ones cope with climate change. Vietnam's hulking, concrete sea walls would seem to fit the bill.
Not everyone is waiting to see how the dikes work out.
On a chilly January day recently, Do Van Duy slugged back another shot of rice liquor. It had been a good year for raising fish in the Red River delta of northern Vietnam. He and other villagers in Nam Dien had gathered to toast their success -- and question whether climate change is such a bad thing after all.
"We live better now," said Mr. Duy, who now farms grouper, shrimp and crab in the brackish waters of the delta after giving up rice. "If you can make the switch there's a lot more money to be made."
Nearly three-quarters of households in Nam Dien have abandoned rice farming, said Bui Van Cuong, a fisheries official with the People's Commune in Nam Dien, as saltwater flows farther into the delta's farmland. "The changes are very apparent over the past 10 years," Mr. Cuong said.
The shift is focusing attention on a difficult question: Is it better to invest resources in fighting the effects of climate change, or in helping people adapt?
The idea behind the Paris pact is that richer countries -- the ones mostly to blame for pollution that scientists say is contributing to rising temperatures and higher sea levels -- should pay to help poorer ones adjust. Some of the money is intended to help developing countries acquire cleaner power and limit further rises in the planet's temperature.
What isn't so straightforward is how developing nations should protect themselves or change practices.
Consider Vietnam's Mekong and Red River deltas. Like the Ganges and Nile deltas, they are already feeling the effects of environmental changes. In the lower reaches of the Mekong, saltwater is penetrating as far as 60 kilometers (37 miles) inland during the dry season, according to government meteorologists, killing crops and forcing farmers to leave or find a new way of making a living. Some 30 million people live in the Mekong delta, with 18 million more in the Red River delta.
Vietnam's initial response to the threat: build a wall.
In Nam Dien, construction was completed a few months ago on a 20-kilometer dike designed to slow the flow of saltwater into the area and prevent erosion. It is part of the broader system of dikes and seawalls with which the government aims to defend a centuries-old network of earthen levees. The project will add up to hundreds of miles of walls and take 40 years to build.
That is a long time, though. Some say Vietnam's communist leaders should sharpen their focus on helping farmers such as Mr. Duy adapt to the changing environment.
"Their competitive advantage is changing," said Le Anh Tuan, a director at the Institute for Climate Change Studies at Can Tho University. "The delta might not always be the best place to grow rice, but people can raise shrimp instead."
There are signs the government is listening. Mr. Cuong, the fisheries director, is among a network of officials helping rice farmers switch to raising fish, rather than fighting environmental changes.
It isn't easy. Farmers have to learn a whole new way of working, from filtering water to investing in healthy fingerlings. "The biggest problem is land," says Mr. Cuong, 38.
Farmers typically need to borrow from relatives or local banks to buy large plots of land to accommodate a commercially viable fish pond. On average, a pond is around 2,000 square meters (21,500 square feet) in the Red River delta, and sells for around $90,000 -- a significant sum in Vietnam, where incomes average about $5,600 a year.
If run well, though, fish farms can be three to five times as productive as rice, he says. Living standards have improved as a result, with Mr. Duy and his neighbors earning up to $20,000 a year.
---
Vu Trong Khanh contributed to this article.
Credit: By James Hookway

Subject: Sea level; Flood control; Climate change; Levees & battures; Aquaculture; Agriculture; Farmers; Fisheries; Farms

U.S. News: Climate Agenda on the Line --- Carbon rule's stay marks unusual blow to the president's environmental push

Author: Harder, Amy; Kendall, Brent

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-climate-agenda-on-line-carbon-rules-stay/docview/1764280082/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The Supreme Court's stay of the rule limiting carbon emissions by power plants -- which will remain in place while courts consider more than 30 lawsuits -- is the third instance since last fall of federal courts have halting major new environmental rules.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Climate+Agenda+on+the+Line+---+Carbon+rule%27s+stay+marks+unusual+blow+to+the+president%27s+environmental+push&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BKendall%2C+Brent&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Climate+Agenda+on+the+Line+---+Carbon+rule%27s+stay+marks+unusual+blow+to+the+president%27s+environmental+push&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BKendall%2C+Brent&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Court's unexpected move this week to block a federal carbon-emissions rule was a significant blow to President Barack Obama's environmental agenda, underscoring the unusual way in which that ambitious agenda is now in a state of suspended animation.
Mr. Obama's administration has pushed rules on everything from emissions to waterways to fracking. But the courts have begun to question whether it has exceeded its legal authority, and their final decisions will determine whether Mr. Obama's environmental legacy will be monumental or more modest.
The Supreme Court's stay of the rule limiting carbon emissions by power plants -- which will remain in place while courts consider more than 30 lawsuits -- is the third instance since last fall of federal courts have halting major new environmental rules.
Courts have blocked an Interior Department rule setting stricter standards for hydraulic fracturing on federal lands and an Environmental Protection Agency rule that would bring smaller waterways and wetlands under federal protection. The regulations are in precarious positions less than a year before Mr. Obama leaves office.
"When the pendulum starts to swing toward executive authority, there's going to be a real likelihood that the courts are going to pull back a little bit," said Jim W. Rubin of Dorsey & Whitney LLP, a former environmental lawyer with the Justice Department. The president's environmental legacy "will be determined by what survives court scrutiny."
Behind these cases is a core battle between the executive and legislative branches. Republicans say Mr. Obama, in taking unilateral actions, is acting like a king and not a president. The White House responds that Congress's refusal to act on critical issues like climate change -- or even recognize it as a problem -- leaves Mr. Obama little choice.
While the high court's action is far from final, it raises questions about a landmark international climate-change accord reached last year in Paris that Mr. Obama sees as the centerpiece of his environmental legacy.
Mr. Obama has rolled out nearly two dozen major rules and scores of smaller ones during his tenure, aimed at clamping down on pollution from oil, natural gas and coal, and at compelling industries to shift toward renewable energy sources such as wind and solar.
Similar clashes over alleged presidential overreach are taking place on other hot-button issues. The Supreme Court this spring will consider the president's plan to defer deportation for millions of illegal immigrants. A lower court is considering a suit by Republicans alleging the Obama administration defied Congress in how it paid for part of the Affordable Care Act.
White House officials said they are confident the courts will uphold the EPA rule, and they suggested Mr. Obama won't stop pursuing executive actions despite legal setbacks.
"Litigation over this administration's policies, and in particular Clean Air Act standards, is nothing new," said Dan Utech, deputy assistant to the president for energy and climate change. "In litigation the pathway is not always smooth. But at the end of the day, we prevail. And we are confident we will do so here. The Clean Air Act gives EPA clear authority -- and legal responsibility -- to regulate carbon pollution from the power sector."
The administration's recent legal difficulties follow notable earlier successes. The EPA won a major ruling in 2012 when an appeals court upheld rules setting greenhouse-gas emission standards for automobiles. That court also blessed a central EPA finding that greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide are a danger to public health and likely have been a driver of global warming over the past half-century. The Supreme Court chose not to review those findings.
The tide seemed to turn in mid-2014 as courts began airing concerns about executive authority. The justices chastised the EPA for seeking to expand a clean-air permitting program to include greenhouse gases without clear congressional authorization.
The latest EPA rule would require a 32% cut in power-plant carbon emissions by 2030, based on 2005 emissions levels.
The Supreme Court considers several hard-to-meet criteria for stay requests, including whether the challengers will likely win their case and whether the denial of a stay will result in irreparable harm.
Supporters of both sides said they couldn't recall another instance when the justices intervened to stay a new regulation whose legality had yet to be fully evaluated by a lower court. "It clearly indicates that five justices have grave doubts about EPA's legal authority to do this rule," said Thomas Lorenzen of Crowell & Moring LLP, a former Justice Department lawyer who defended earlier EPA rules.
Credit: By Amy Harder and Brent Kendall

Honest Climate Debate Is Almost Impossible

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/honest-climate-debate-is-almost-impossible/docview/1763312864/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Regarding Patrick Michaels's "The Climate Snow Job" (op-ed, Jan. 25): The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration methodology change appears to introduce potential for significant errors that likely overstate the global-warming trend.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Honest+Climate+Debate+Is+Almost+Impossible&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Honest+Climate+Debate+Is+Almost+Impossible&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-02-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Regarding Patrick Michaels's "The Climate Snow Job" (op-ed, Jan. 25): The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration methodology change appears to introduce potential for significant errors that likely overstate the global-warming trend. Even with that trendline boost, the magnitude of warming since the late 1990s still falls well short of climate science predictions that drive today's environmental policies.
Mr. Michaels argues that signs of global warming and its extreme effects are misinterpreted and exaggerated and therefore far from settled. He may be right from a scientific study and data-analysis standpoint, but do the numbers really matter? Challenging the climate-change consensus gets scientists ridiculed, discredited and bullied into silence. By contrast, manipulation of warming data by using fudge factors, corrupted data or by changing measurement standards is defended, condoned or covered up as trivial foibles in a fight to save the planet from humans.
A battle against climate change represents the greatest global opportunity for expanding government control of lifestyles and achieving social justice through redistribution of the world's wealth. Last year's encyclical on the environment from Pope Francis captured the overriding moral and economic dimensions of climate change and how they eclipse simple statistics. He said: "Humanity is called to recognize the need for changes of lifestyle, production and consumption, in order to combat this warming or at least the human causes which produce or aggravate it." Changes in lifestyle for a greater good must be orchestrated by government. Climate science has to be settled so that moral and economic progress can occur and a more just world order established. Skeptics are spitting into superstorm winds.
Jeff Green
Charlotte, N.C.
---
Before offering the usual round of amens when they read Mr. Michaels's piece, readers should see what is posted on the NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information list of the "Sixteen Warmest Years (1880-2015)." It is easy to find, discusses the impact of El Nino in more detail and shows a very clear pattern of significant warming in the recent past that doesn't depend on El Nino or changes in what temperature measurements are used.
Does Mr. Michaels really believe that the scientists who shared this data are so blindly and conspiratorially wedded to proving global warming that it is OK to only use their data when it supports his case?
Carl Wermer
Essex Junction, Vt.

Cloud Hangs Over Canada's Oil Sands

Author: Dawson, Chester

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cloud-hangs-over-canadas-oil-sands/docview/1759301567/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Nine of the world's top oil companies, including Exxon Mobil Corp., BP PLC, Chevron Corp., ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell PLC, have invested tens of billions of dollars into megaprojects in the province's boreal forests.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Cloud+Hangs+Over+Canada%27s+Oil+Sands&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-01-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Dawson%2C+Chester&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Cloud+Hangs+Over+Canada%27s+Oil+Sands&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-01-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Dawson%2C+Chester&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   CALGARY -- Canada's efforts to curb greenhouse-gas emissions are calling into question oil majors' ability to tap the world's third-largest oil reserves.
The new left-leaning government of the Canadian province of Alberta, which came to power in May after 44 years of conservative rule, has announced it would cap carbon emissions from its oil-sands industry, a move that threatens to strand billions of barrels of crude from supplies so vast that only Saudi Arabia and Venezuela control more.
Nine of the world's top oil companies, including Exxon Mobil Corp., BP PLC, Chevron Corp., ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell PLC, have invested tens of billions of dollars into megaprojects in the province's boreal forests. Combined, those operations account for 23% of these companies' proven crude reserves, according to data from investment bank Peters & Co. -- up from only 5% in 2006.
Marathon Oil Corp., China's Cnooc Ltd., Total SA of France and Norway's Statoil ASA round out the group of global players exploiting Canada's oil sands.
Most of these producers have taken a wait-and-see approach toward the cap, details about which remain to be worked out. Privately, executives at some oil multinationals with oil-sands assets express dismay about the sudden policy shift, and the heads of some smaller companies have voiced their concerns publicly.
"The cap is a long-term issue for province and the country," said Glen Schmidt, chief executive of Laricina Energy Ltd., an oil-sands lease owner. "How will it be allocated to companies who in good faith have purchased rights to produce and invested in technology as we have?" he said.
Canada's federal government defers to its provinces to come up with policy prescriptions to curb overall emissions. Alberta's new climate plan, announced in November, would cap its oil-sands industry's greenhouse-gas emissions at 100 million metric tons a year. The industry currently emits 70 million metric tons of greenhouse gas a year -- about a quarter of the province's overall emissions.
Based on growth projections at the time, Canada's environment ministry said in December of 2014 -- the latest projection available -- that the oil-sands industry is likely to cross that 100 million metric-ton level as soon as 2020.
Shell, which welcomed the policy along with three local Canadian oil-sands producers, said it didn't expect the cap would have a negative impact on its existing operations or force it to take impairments related to its undeveloped reserves. The company said it is confident the advent of new technologies and other policy initiatives would mitigate the impact of a carbon cap.
Oil majors have increasingly been turning to Alberta, helping boost Canadian oil-sands production by 38% over the past five years. Companies such as ConocoPhillips, Exxon and Shell have booked more than one-third of their proven crude reserves from the oil sands, according to the Peters report. Most other known untapped crude reserves are owned by state-owned firms in top oil-producing countries and are largely off limits to private companies.
Oil firms' proven reserves are an important indicator of their ability to grow. Canadian heavy crude may be expensive to extract, but companies point out that other potential sources such as Arctic or deep-water offshore fields are also high cost and, unlike Canada's oil sands, would require extensive exploration to find and substantiate crude oil deposits.
Despite low prices, oil-sands production is expected to increase through 2020 as a result of expansion projects approved years ago. Oil-sands developments cost billions of dollars and take years to build, but produce at stable levels for a decade or more -- unlike short-lived shale-oil wells.
Exxon said last year that 2014 marked the 21st consecutive year it replaced more than 100% of its production. More than half of its newly booked crude reserves -- amounting to some 700 million barrels -- came from oil sands assets in Canada, it said.
However, the recent crude slump -- with oil prices hovering around $30 a barrel -- has hit producers' bottom lines and forced many to abandon or suspend development of new projects. Western Canadian heavy crude costs more to extract than other oil sources because it must be separated from deposits of sand and trades at a discount to other crudes, in part because of the distance it must be transported from remote boreal forests in Alberta. It also is among the most greenhouse gas-intensive to produce. It also trades at a discount: On Friday, Western Canada Select crude oil closed at 25.74 Canadian dollars (US$18.12) per barrel.
The prospect of Alberta's carbon cap looms large because it could thwart development even if oil prices rebound.
The policy presents a real-world test case in a much broader debate now raging among investors and resource companies: Whether a more concerted global effort to reduce greenhouse emissions could keep companies from fully exploiting their resources, diminishing their value to shareholders.
The debate has gained new traction amid the run-up to the Paris climate change accord last month, during which 195 countries united around a document that is effectively a blueprint for how the world will tackle global warming.
Oil industry executives have dismissed the idea that they will be forced abandon undeveloped assets, noting fossil fuels will remain an important energy source for decades to come.
Current volumes of proven crude reserves aren't likely to be affected by Alberta's cap since they reflect projects that already have regulatory approval, most of which are operating or under construction. But companies may find it harder to tap their vast quantities of contingent resources.
"It's more the future projects that are affected," said Keith Braaten, president of Calgary-based reserve auditor GLJ Petroleum Consultants Ltd.

Election 2016: GOP Field Shifts Right on Climate

Author: Harder, Amy; Reinhard, Beth

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/election-2016-gop-field-shifts-right-on-climate/docview/1757195922/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Republicans, not Democrats, first championed market-based systems to control pollution, as a way to avoid more direct regulation. [...]2008, many Republicans supported cap-and-trade.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Election+2016%3A+GOP+Field+Shifts+Right+on+Climate&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-01-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BReinhard%2C+Beth&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Election+2016%3A+GOP+Field+Shifts+Right+on+Climate&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-01-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BReinhard%2C+Beth&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Shortly after a conservative website on Wednesday posted 2008 footage of Sen. Marco Rubio backing a cap-and-trade program to combat climate change, his campaign roared back with a counterattack that included an entire web page aimed at debunking the video.
Mr. Rubio's response revealed how toxic the issue of climate change has become in the Republican Party under President Barack Obama, who has sought to make reducing carbon emissions to alleviate global warming one of his signature accomplishments.
As speaker of the Florida House, Mr. Rubio did vote for a 2008 bill authorizing the state to come up with rules for a cap-and-trade plan, though he raised questions about its cost and effectiveness.
But since running for U.S. Senate in 2010 as the conservative alternative to then-Gov. Charlie Crist, Mr. Rubio has questioned whether climate change is man-made, and opposed potential remedies like cap-and-trade that he says would hurt the economy.
Shifts by Mr. Rubio and some of his rivals recall a past that many in the GOP would like to forget: Republicans, not Democrats, first championed market-based systems to control pollution, as a way to avoid more direct regulation.
Until 2008, many Republicans supported cap-and-trade. Once Mr. Obama won the White House, Republicans swiftly unified against nearly all of his initiatives, including a cap-and-trade bill that would have set limits on carbon emissions and allowed companies to trade pollution credits to comply.
Responding to what they call big-government overreach by Mr. Obama, many Republicans have moved to the right on several other issues as well, including illegal immigration, health-insurance mandates and the Common Core academic standards.
GOP candidates who had generally accepted the scientific consensus on man-made climate change, including former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, have said recently that it is unclear how much, if at all, humans are contributing to warmer temperatures.
The GOP front-runners, Donald Trump and Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas), have been the most consistent in questioning and even denying climate change.
For now, that consistency has worked to their advantage, Republican strategists say, leaving rivals little room to outflank them on the right.
Meanwhile, the three Democratic candidates, including front-runner Hillary Clinton, have consistently pushed for more aggressive climate policies than Mr. Obama's.
Credit: By Amy Harder and Beth Reinhard

A Democrat Finds Common Cause With Cruz

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/democrat-finds-common-cause-with-cruz/docview/1756389549/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The requirement to add this corrosive contaminant to gasoline is the worst current example of government power being used to enrich the few (corn farmers and ethanol producers) at the expense of the many (everyone using gasoline-powered engines), all justified by bogus environmental benefits.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=A+Democrat+Finds+Common+Cause+With+Cruz&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2016-01-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   As a Democrat, I never thought I would say this, but I agree with Sen. Ted Cruz -- on ethanol. As "Cruz Takes on Ethanol In Iowa -- and Vice Versa" (page one, Jan. 7) points out, Mr. Cruz could become the first candidate in either party to oppose the ethanol mandate and win the Iowa caucuses.
It's time to stop catering to the ethanol lobby by endorsing a flawed policy that science shows is worse for our environment and climate than gasoline. If Mr. Cruz prevails in the Iowa Republican caucuses, the handwriting will be on the election-night returns. Bad policy on ethanol isn't good politics anymore, even in Iowa. I wish my fellow Democrats, climate-change champions, would come to the same realization.
When I was a senior adviser in the Gore and Kerry campaigns, the ethanol cause seemed like a win-win. We believed it was good politics in Iowa and good policy, too. The science wasn't there yet showing that ethanol exacerbates the global warming it was supposed to reduce. In his 2009 book on climate change, Al Gore wrote that he made a rare mistake on environmental policy by endorsing corn ethanol as he courted Iowa voters. Mr. Cruz's rationale is obviously different. He instinctively opposes mandates and subsidies of most kinds -- except those benefiting Big Oil. But whatever his motivations, on this issue at least, Ted Cruz is right.
Robert M. Shrum
Los Angeles
---
Kudos to Sen. Cruz for having the guts to take on the ethanol lobby in Iowa. The requirement to add this corrosive contaminant to gasoline is the worst current example of government power being used to enrich the few (corn farmers and ethanol producers) at the expense of the many (everyone using gasoline-powered engines), all justified by bogus environmental benefits.
James G. Russell
Midlothian, Va.

Minimum Wages and the Total U.S. Economy

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/minimum-wages-total-u-s-economy/docview/1751959995/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Whether new jobs are created by this amount of economic stimulus is probably one of the reasons why economic research has different outcomes related to increases in the minimum wage.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Minimum+Wages+and+the+Total+U.S.+Economy&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Minimum+Wages+and+the+Total+U.S.+Economy&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   It is fascinating that an economics professor like David Neumark would analyze an economic policy from a narrow perspective and not consider broad, long-term impacts ("The Evidence Is Piling Up That Higher Minimum Wages Kill Jobs," op-ed, Dec. 16). He reports that a 10% increase in the minimum wage is expected to result in a 1% to 2% drop in employment of low-skilled workers earning the minimum wage. Assuming that his worst case scenario is this 2% loss of jobs in this low-wage group, let's consider the immediate effects. Out of 100 workers two would lose their jobs as a layoff and be eligible for unemployment compensation. The other 98 of these 100 workers would get raises of 10%. The net increase in wages for the entire group will be 7.8%, without including the unemployment compensation for those laid off. Surely Mr.
Neumark would agree that a policy change causing a wage increase over 7.8% for a significant group would be positive for society and a significant economic stimulus for the geographic area affected. Whether new jobs are created by this amount of economic stimulus is probably one of the reasons why economic research has different outcomes related to increases in the minimum wage.
William Pease
Columbus, Ohio
---
Mr. Neumark's recap of economic research that reconfirms the deleterious effect of minimum-wage hikes on jobs was welcome, but do we seriously have to keep convincing the deniers of basic economic principles that raising the cost of anything (that is not addictive or critical for survival) reduces demand for that good or service? Do we really not have enough common sense, logic, elementary understanding of human behavior and evidence to declare that an inverse cost-demand (or price-demand) relationship is settled economics?
Ted Peterson
Richmond, Va.
---
Our current equilibrium (high marginal taxes to support a welfare state for many people at the bottom of the income scale) is neither the only nor probably ideal equilibrium. One can imagine higher minimum wages lowering the number of people drawing supplementary income from federal programs (Medicaid, disability, housing, food and health-insurance subsidies), thus lowering government expenditures, and lowering the justification for high marginal taxes. Lower marginal taxes in turn help expand the economy, increase GDP, wage growth and offset many, if not all, of the jobs lost to higher minimum wages.
A higher minimum wage and lower marginal income tax in conjunction is a policy which might do just that.
Eric Hagemann
Los Angeles
---
After reading Mr. Neumark's piece about the job-killing effects of minimum-wage hikes, I was left with the feeling that if the same standards were applied to economics as to climate change, the science would be settled.
Robert Wilson
Ayer, Mass.
---
The difficulty in sorting out minimum-wage-raise results may stem from labor as investment rather than consumption. Certainly one consumes less as costs rise. But maybe the labor price imbalance is settled in a two-step process. First, the owner attempts to justify the higher wage by reorganizing the work environment to make employees more productive. Then the owner realizes he or she needs fewer of the now more productive employees.
One need only contrast the lower-tech McDonald's I worked in 40 years ago with many more employees and a far simpler menu to see the relentless employment decline in a minimum-wage-forced, more productive work environment.
Mark Maisonneuve
Berkley, Mich.
---
Greece has the highest minimum wage in the world -- enough said.
Andrew Bleke
Atlanta
(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Why Not Set a Minimum Wage of $50 for All?" -- WSJ Jan. 7, 2016)

England Closes Its last Coal Mine

Author: Patterson, Scott

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/england-closes-last-coal-mine/docview/1748541840/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Kellingley, operated by U.K. Coal, is the victim of vast market forces that pushed prices for thermal coal -- the kind used to fuel power plants -- to their lowest level in more than nine years at $45.10 a metric ton, according Rotterdam coal futures traded on the Intercontinental Exchange.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=England+Closes+Its+last+Coal+Mine&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;au=Patterson%2C+Scott&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=England+Closes+Its+last+Coal+Mine&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;au=Patterson%2C+Scott&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   KNOTTINGLEY, England -- The last deep-pit coal mine in the U.K. plans to shut its doors here this week, heralding the end of a centuries-old industry that helped fuel the industrial revolution and build the British Empire.
The shutdown, targeted for Friday, represents a victory for advocates of reducing carbon emissions even before world leaders reached a landmark agreement in Paris this weekend. It also reflects a glut of energy on world markets, from crude oil to natural gas and coal itself.
Coal mines have been closing around the world in the past year, from the U.S. to South Africa to the U.K., as prices plunged. But in no country has the industry witnessed such a dramatic fall from grace as in the U.K., where coal production was once seen as the backbone of the nation's industrial economy, the fuel for everything from steamboats to power plants.
George Orwell, in his 1937 book "The Road to Wigan Pier," wrote: "Our civilisation. . .is founded on coal."
No longer. Deep-mine coal production in the U.K. hit an all-time low of 3.7 million metric tons in 2014, down from a peak of 217 million tons in 1954, according to the U.K.'s Department of Energy and Climate Change. At the time, about 1,330 deep-pit mines accounted for 95% of the U.K.'s coal production.
That number will hit zero with this month's closing of U.K. Coal's Kellingley Colliery, which has been operating since 1965 about a 30-mile drive from the historic city of York. A small number of "open-cast" surface mines in the U.K. will continue to produce.
The Kellingley mine produces 8,000 tons of coal a day and employs 451 people, down from more than 2,000 in the 1970s, the company said. An estimated 30 million tons of coal will remain stranded in the ground.
"The world has moved on," said David Cross, a librarian at the National Coal Mining Museum for England. "But it's a change in the entire basis of the world economy, not merely in this country."
The U.K. already imports most of the coal that fuels its power plants, with imports first surpassing local production in 2001. Russia has been the biggest beneficiary of the U.K.'s increased appetite for imported coal, providing 46% of its thermal coal in 2014, according to the U.K. government. Coal supplies roughly one-third of the energy for electricity generation in the U.K., with natural gas and renewable sources making up the rest.
Kellingley, operated by U.K. Coal, is the victim of vast market forces that pushed prices for thermal coal -- the kind used to fuel power plants -- to their lowest level in more than nine years at $45.10 a metric ton, according Rotterdam coal futures traded on the Intercontinental Exchange. It costs Kellingley about $65 to produce a ton of coal, compared with $45 a ton for imported coal, a company official said.
In the U.S., as cleaner-burning natural gas replaces coal as a fuel for power plants, coal producers have started shipping their product abroad, weighing on demand for more expensive homegrown coal in the U.K. and elsewhere. And with consumption slackening in China and elsewhere, global coal shipments are falling for the first time in 21 years, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Investors have been pulling back from coal, in part because of concerns about global warming, helping push coal miners' stocks into free fall. The Church of England in April said it divested GBP 12 million ($18.3 million) worth of thermal-coal and tar-sands assets, citing concerns about climate change.
The future of coal as a fuel for power was widely discussed in Paris. Environmentalists say the reduction of coal-fired power plants in the European Union has been too slow. The U.K. government has proposed to eliminate all coal-fired power plants by 2025.
To be sure, coal demand is forecast to rise through 2040 unless the world, and China in particular, takes drastic action, according to the International Energy Agency. The coal industry has argued that it is wrongheaded for governments to give up on a plentiful, cheap energy source such as coal and has called for investment in new technologies that would catch carbon at its source, known as carbon-capture storage.
Meaningful action on the climate will be "more expensive, if not impossible, without widespread deployment of carbon capture and storage technology," said Benjamin Sporton, chief executive of the World Coal Association, citing U.N. statistics.
Still, the forces aligning against coal have devastated the U.K. industry, where successive governments -- both Conservative and Labour -- have refused to provide meaningful financial support to coal since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher defeated a miners' strike in the 1980s.
Shaun McLoughlin, Kellingley's mine manager, said he finds the mine's closure "very disappointing."
"But also I understand the economics of it. We're living in a free-market world," he said.
For the miners here, many of whom have spent decades working in dark tunnels to hammer coal from seams hundreds of feet below the ground, the shutdown represents a failure of government policy to support what they see as an important industry for the nation.
Keith Poulson, who represents the National Union of Mineworkers here, said the damage to the local economy from the shutdown will be "massive." He said the government should have helped support the U.K. mining industry during the big decline in coal prices with subsidies, because prices are likely to shoot up again.
"We've been asking for some support to get through these troubled times and the door has been slammed in our face," he said.
Credit: By Scott Patterson

World News: In U.S., Paris Pact Faces Resistance

Author: Colleen McCain Nelson; Mauldin, William

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-u-s-paris-pact-faces-resistance/docview/1748541795/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: GOP lawmakers have launched a multipronged approach to undercutting the president's climate agenda, and most of the Republican presidential candidates have pledged that, if elected, they would undo Mr. Obama's executive actions aimed at curbing global warming.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+In+U.S.%2C+Paris+Pact+Faces+Resistance&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BMauldin%2C+William&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+In+U.S.%2C+Paris+Pact+Faces+Resistance&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BMauldin%2C+William&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   President Barack Obama notched a victory on the world stage with the completion of a global climate accord, but the White House still faces resistance at home as Republicans and some U.S. industries push back against the policies underpinning the deal.
For the president, the agreement forged in Paris by more than 190 nations ends a yearslong quest to craft a new, global approach to curbing climate change and to secure his own environmental legacy. An upbeat Mr. Obama on Saturday hailed what he deemed a historic deal.
The deal was structured in a way that doesn't require congressional approval.
Many Republicans, though, have vowed to unravel the Obama administration's efforts. GOP lawmakers have launched a multipronged approach to undercutting the president's climate agenda, and most of the Republican presidential candidates have pledged that, if elected, they would undo Mr. Obama's executive actions aimed at curbing global warming.
Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush has said he would repeal Environmental Protection Agency rules cutting carbon emissions that form the central component of the U.S. commitment to the global climate accord. Last week, as climate negotiators met in Paris, Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) decried "global warming alarmists" and said there had been no significant warming of the planet during the past 18 years.
Obama administration officials have said they are confident the U.S. will follow through on its climate commitments, even after this president leaves office. On Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry acknowledged the possibility of a Republican president undoing Mr. Obama's executive actions but said he didn't expect that to happen.
"I don't believe you can be elected president of the United States if you don't understand climate change or you're not committed to this kind of a plan," Mr. Kerry said on ABC.
Republicans on Capitol Hill aren't waiting to take aim at Mr. Obama's climate policies. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) described the accord as "nothing more than a long-term planning document."
"The president is making promises he can't keep, writing checks he can't cash and stepping over the middle class to take credit for an agreement that is subject to being shredded in 13 months," Mr. McConnell said, adding that Mr. Obama's commitments would hurt jobs and raise utility rates.
Congressional Republicans already have passed measures challenging federal rules to cut power-plant emissions, but any binding measure would be vetoed by the president. Republicans also have sought to upend the administration's efforts to funnel federal dollars to developing nations so they can tackle climate change as part of a United Nations program. The question of whether to include that funding in a spending bill has been a sticking point in negotiations that were under way on Sunday, congressional aides said.
Democrats say the president is on firm footing as he works to implement the climate deal. "There is no realistic path for our commitments to be undermined," said Sen. Brian Schatz (D., Hawaii).
Still, the administration must navigate an array of challenges to its environmental policies. Two dozen states have sued to stop the EPA regulations aimed at cutting carbon emissions.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and William Mauldin

Climate Deal Leaves Hard Decisions To Countries

Author: Steinhauser, Gabriele; Dalton, Matthew; Spindle, Bill

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/climate-deal-leaves-hard-decisions-countries/docview/1748541775/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Supporters hope the deal will unleash an avalanche of financing and investment from entrepreneurs, companies and international lenders into renewable energy sources, technologies such as electric cars and new ways to capture and store gasses from carbon-intensive fuels such as coal.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Climate+Deal+Leaves+Hard+Decisions+To+Countries&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Steinhauser%2C+Gabriele%3BDalton%2C+Matthew%3BSpindle%2C+Bill&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Climate+Deal+Leaves+Hard+Decisions+To+Countries&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Steinhauser%2C+Gabriele%3BDalton%2C+Matthew%3BSpindle%2C+Bill&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   PARIS -- The landmark climate agreement that more than 190 countries struck in Paris over the weekend ushers in a broad, new international effort to wind down the fossil-fuel era.
But as two weeks of tumultuous negotiations made clear, the pact's success hinges on individual countries making painful choices -- especially in how they produce and consume energy -- that could profoundly shape corporate behavior, financial markets and the global economic landscape.
Paul Polman, chief executive of European-based consumer-goods giant Unilever PLC and an outspoken environmental advocate, said the deal sent an "unequivocal signal to the business and financial communities, one that will drive real change in the real economy."
Others, especially from the fossil-fuel industry and some U.S. companies, were more critical or played down the impact of the agreement. Stephen Eule, vice president for climate and technology at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which lobbies Washington lawmakers on behalf of large U.S. companies, said the deal risks damaging the U.S. economy by pushing the country toward more costly energy from renewable sources.
"The Paris climate conference delivered more of the same -- lots of promises and lots of issues still left unresolved," he said. "The White House's overall domestic strategy of making energy more expensive and less abundant to satisfy international constituencies, many of whom compete against the United States, should worry the business community, American workers and consumers."
Supporters hope the deal will unleash an avalanche of financing and investment from entrepreneurs, companies and international lenders into renewable energy sources, technologies such as electric cars and new ways to capture and store gasses from carbon-intensive fuels such as coal.
Still, Benjamin Sporton, chief executive of the World Coal Association, an industry advocate, said the agreement left room for the coal industry to grow, especially with renewed financing for carbon capture and storage to stop emissions from being released into the atmosphere.
At the core of the agreement, reached Saturday evening in a suburb of Paris, is a collection of voluntary plans submitted by every country to tackle climate change, each reflecting its own economic and political situation. Most of them focus on shifting to renewable energy sources such as solar, wind and, for some, nuclear power and away from carbon-heavy fuels such as coal and oil.
While the plans lay out a monumental challenge, in aggregate they still don't meet the level of cuts in greenhouse-gas emissions that the agreement itself targets. Much of the success of the deal also lies in implementation years from now, by governments that haven't yet been elected. The accord's requirement to review the ambition of the planned cuts to emissions provides what supporters hope will be an open-ended commitment to deeper cuts.
The plans aren't legally enforceable -- a condition the U.S. among others insisted upon -- though the deal does legally bind countries to a periodic review process that backers of the accord hope will prod countries to repeatedly raise their emissions-cutting efforts.
In addition, developed countries have to help provide at least $100 billion annually from a variety of sources after 2020 to help developing countries cut their emissions.
Getting to that agreement was a bumpy path and an outcome that surprised many participants and observers as ambitions in the negotiating rooms grew. A key alliance that sprang up was among a group of small developing nations led by the tiny Marshall Islands, along with Mexico and Colombia -- and the European Union. All wanted a tough agreement that wasn't only legally binding but also aimed for a more aggressive target in curbing the rise in average global temperatures.
The conference's stated goal was to limit global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. The islands wanted a goal of 1.5 degrees, arguing that aiming for the 2-degree target wouldn't be enough to prevent them from being wiped out by rising sea levels, based on most scientific forecasts.
While the U.S. wasn't willing to go that far, it soon joined forces with the alliance, offering to join their calls for a more ambitious target in exchange for acknowledgment that developed nations wouldn't take on the liability for the damage to poor countries caused by rising sea levels and more frequent, more intense storms.
One U.S. demand shaped the conference before it even began: In a divided Washington, Republicans who control Congress vowed to reject anything the Democratic Obama administration sent there for approval. For Todd Stern, who headed the U.S. negotiating team in Paris, that ruled out any legally binding commitment to cut emissions, a major goal of the Europeans and some other countries.
That large caveat thrust a top State Department lawyer into the center of the fray. Susan Biniaz was the arbiter on the critical matter of what would or wouldn't require U.S. congressional authorization during the talks.
The differences were settled in the night between Friday and Saturday, when developed countries agreed to continue leading on financing, leaving large emerging markets like China free to make just voluntary contributions. In return, developing countries accepted regular reviews and checks of their voluntary plans to curb emissions.
---
Carol E. Lee and Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.
Credit: By Gabriele Steinhauser, Matthew Dalton and Bill Spindle

World News: Scientists Praise Accord, but Only if Nations Heed It

Author: Naik, Gautam

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-scientists-praise-accord-only-if/docview/1748541627/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Scientists hailed the Paris agreement on climate change as an important step forward to reducing the most severe impacts of a warming earth -- welcoming mechanisms intended to keep nations ambitious about reducing carbon emissions, but wary about how vigilant they will end up being.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Scientists+Praise+Accord%2C+but+Only+if+Nations+Heed+It&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Naik%2C+Gautam&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Scientists+Praise+Accord%2C+but+Only+if+Nations+Heed+It&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-14&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Naik%2C+Gautam&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Scientists hailed the Paris agreement on climate change as an important step forward to reducing the most severe impacts of a warming earth -- welcoming mechanisms intended to keep nations ambitious about reducing carbon emissions, but wary about how vigilant they will end up being.
"Climate change will continue, but now at a much-reduced pace this century relative to what it would be without an international agreement and adherence to it," said Jeffrey Kargel, a researcher at the University of Arizona.
The agreement, signed by more than 190 countries, aims to keep the warming well below 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, and stakes out the more ambitious goal of keeping it 1.5 degrees below.
The countries also agreed to ratchet up their level of emission reductions every five years, starting in 2018.
"If they increase their emission cuts after 2025, we'll see more reductions in temperature," said Simon Lewis, an environmental scientist. "We'll see . . . if that occurs."
The danger is that countries' pledges to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions may yet falter. Legislaturescould fail to ratify the pact, or future governments might undo pledges made by their predecessors.
Richard Allan, climate scientist at the University of Reading, added: "Paris has delivered a plan, next begins the hard bit: action."

World News: Aid Question Holds Up Deal on Climate --- Paris talks go into overtime as poorer countries say pledges from rich aren't solid

Author: Steinhauser, Gabriele; Dalton, Matthew

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-aid-question-holds-up-deal-on-climate/docview/1748081103/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: According to the draft, governments will commit to hold the average rise in global temperatures "well below" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) and "pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees C." That was a victory for small island states that say a 2-degree warming would result in rising seas swallowing their lands and depriving their citizens of homes and livelihoods.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Aid+Question+Holds+Up+Deal+on+Climate+---+Paris+talks+go+into+overtime+as+poorer+countries+say+pledges+from+rich+aren%27t+solid&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;au=Steinhauser%2C+Gabriele%3BDalton%2C+Matthew&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Aid+Question+Holds+Up+Deal+on+Climate+---+Paris+talks+go+into+overtime+as+poorer+countries+say+pledges+from+rich+aren%27t+solid&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-12&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;au=Steinhauser%2C+Gabriele%3BDalton%2C+Matthew&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   PARIS -- Setting the rules for how developed nations will pay for poorer ones to respond to climate change was the key obstacle to a deal late Friday, as negotiators haggled past the scheduled deadline of international talks here.
Beyond that dispute, a group of climate scientists said the latest draft on Friday showed serious inconsistencies and would require much deeper cuts to emissions than currently foreseen.
Officials were seeking a compromise between poor nations demanding assurances that the money will be there and rich nations pushing wealthier developing nations, such as China, to pay part of the bill. They were also grappling with U.S. concerns about requirements to provide finance, given the difficulties of getting spending legislation through the U.S. Congress.
The persistent disagreements over money on Friday suggested difficulties on Saturday morning, when French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius, who is leading the talks, aimed to release a final draft.
"Everything comes back to the provision of finance, the predictability of finance, the scaling-up of finance," said Nozipho Mxakato-Diseko, a South African official who represents more than 100 developing nations in the talks. "That's the test of this agreement."
Mr. Fabius said he expected a deal on Saturday. "The conditions have never been this favorable," he said.
A draft released by Mr. Fabius on Thursday night eliminated many disagreements that had hobbled talks so far, but left open how much financial help the world's poorest governments can expect to get to adjust to rising temperatures, and whether developing countries will be required to measure and report emissions as accurately as rich states.
According to the draft, governments will commit to hold the average rise in global temperatures "well below" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) and "pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees C."
That was a victory for small island states that say a 2-degree warming would result in rising seas swallowing their lands and depriving their citizens of homes and livelihoods.
Yet a panel of five climate scientists -- convened at the site of the Paris talks -- said the rest of the draft agreement didn't back up that promise. To keep global temperatures from rising more than 1.5 degrees, man-made emissions of carbon dioxide have to be reduced to zero by 2050, the scientists said.
"You cannot say we'll stay under 1.5 [degrees] on the one hand and not say anything on decarbonization on the other hand," said Steffen Kalbekken, director at the Norway-based Centre for International Climate and Energy Policy. "Otherwise it is meaningless."
Unlike earlier drafts, which included plans to cut global greenhouse-gas emissions by up to 95% by 2050 from 2010 levels, the draft text saw emissions peaking "as soon as possible," giving developing countries extra time.
In the second half of the century, the world should reach "greenhouse-gas emissions neutrality," the draft text said. That means emissions would be so low that they could be absorbed by the earth's natural mechanisms, such as plants and oceans, or new technologies such as carbon capture and storage.
"There is an inconsistency between near-term and long-term ambition," said Joeri Rogelj, a scholar at the Energy Program of the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Austria.
National pledges to limit greenhouse-gas emissions fall far short of reaching even the less ambitious goal in the draft text and would still see global temperatures rise by around 3 degrees from preindustrial levels, according to U.N. and other scientists.
The draft agreement foresees governments reassessing their emissions pledges every five years, but this review process doesn't start early enough, the scientists in Paris said. Under the draft, the first full global stocktaking of emissions wouldn't happen until 2023. By then, the scientists said, emissions will likely have surpassed the maximum allowed under any existing 1.5-degree scenario.
Officials familiar with the latest negotiations among national delegations said there was still some pushback on the review mechanism and the overall targets of the deal.
India, one of the world's biggest CO2 emitters, was still lobbying for the reviews to be voluntary and, along with Saudi Arabia, wanted to eliminate the reference to the 1.5 degree target, said Bas Eickhout, a European Parliament member for the Dutch Green Party following the talks.
In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Ms. Mxakato-Diseko said the draft of the climate-change deal was too vague about who will pay for developing nations to limit greenhouse-gas emissions and protect themselves from impacts of climate change.
"You get vague language such as 'finance will be provided' -- by whom?" she said.
Credit: By Gabriele Steinhauser and Matthew Dalton

World News: Compromises Make Climate Deal More Possible

Author: Dalton, Matthew; Steinhauser, Gabriele

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-compromises-make-climate-deal-more/docview/1747534646/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Hopes now rest on whether Europe, the U.S. and some of the world's poorest nations can compromise with a group of developing countries that are resisting calls to shoulder more of the burden in the fight to limit global warming.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Compromises+Make+Climate+Deal+More+Possible&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.14&amp;au=Dalton%2C+Matthew%3BSteinhauser%2C+Gabriele&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Compromises+Make+Climate+Deal+More+Possible&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-11&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.14&amp;au=Dalton%2C+Matthew%3BSteinhauser%2C+Gabriele&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   PARIS -- Nations moved closer to a global climate deal that has eluded them for more than 20 years, as compromise emerged on some of the most controversial issues facing negotiators at a summit here, even as other problems remain unresolved.
A new draft unveiled on Thursday showed that an agreement is in sight, after 11 days of talks did little to bridge differences that have bedeviled negotiators since nations first agreed to pursue an international climate-change deal in 1992.
"They are obviously much closer to the finishing line," said Alden Meyer of the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group.
Perhaps the biggest breakthrough came in the overall target guiding the cuts in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that nations would enact under the proposed agreement. The draft says nations will limit the increase in average surface temperatures to "well below" two degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) since the dawn of the industrial era, and "pursue efforts" to limit warming to 1.5 degrees.
Still, other issues remain, such as financing for the developing world and how the burden of fighting climate change should be divided between rich and poor nations, with little time left in the talks to find solutions. Hopes now rest on whether Europe, the U.S. and some of the world's poorest nations can compromise with a group of developing countries that are resisting calls to shoulder more of the burden in the fight to limit global warming.
The developing-nation group, known as Like-Minded Developing Countries, represents the hard core of opposition to the U.S., the EU and other developed nations. It includes developing-nation giants such as China and India, oil-producing states such as Saudi Arabia and staunch critics of the West such as Iran, Venezuela and Bolivia.
Members of the Like-Minded group didn't comment on the new draft as talks moved behind closed doors on Thursday evening.
European officials voiced cautious praise of the new text. The new draft is "looking better, bolder," said one official, but cautioning that more work needed to be done on ensuring all governments accurately measure and report their emissions.
Countries most vulnerable to climate change insist on the 1.5-degree target, arguing that any more warming would result in catastrophic damage from rising sea levels and increased storm intensity. The United Nations says the globe has warmed about 0.9 degree since the late 19th century.
Tony La Vina, a senior negotiator for the Philippines, which represents a group of countries most at risk from climate change, said the proposed language on 1.5 degrees appears broadly acceptable.
French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius, who is leading the negotiations, and other French officials put together the draft based on hours of nonstop negotiations among the 195 nations gathered at the Paris climate summit. It is still uncertain if the compromises drafted by Mr. Fabius will be acceptable.
Thursday's draft also sets greenhouse-gas neutrality as a goal for the second half of this century. That means nations have agreed to commit to cut their fossil-fuel emissions to such a low level that the Earth's natural mechanisms for absorbing these gases -- through plants and other means -- can offset man-made emissions.
While the EU and the U.S. have narrowed differences with some of the poorest nations in recent days, much of the Like-Minded group opposes committing to more ambitious emissions-reduction targets or to provide financing for poor nations to respond to climate change. Their priority must remain fighting poverty within their borders, they say.
Thursday's draft wouldn't require developing countries to provide financing for climate-change projects in the poorest nations, a provision that may draw objections from developed nations.
Mr. Fabius gave ministers 2 1/2 hours to examine the text before deciding whether the French proposals are acceptable, but talks were expected to continue long into the night.
Credit: By Matthew Dalton and Gabriele Steinhauser

World News: King Coal Hard to Dethrone

Author: Moss, Trefor

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-king-coal-hard-dethrone/docview/1747224510/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: In most of the developed world, competition from natural gas and environmental regulations have crippled the coal industry, bankrupting companies and snuffing out jobs in the U.S. and Europe.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+King+Coal+Hard+to+Dethrone&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;au=Moss%2C+Trefor&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+King+Coal+Hard+to+Dethrone&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-12-10&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;au=Moss%2C+Trefor&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   MANILA -- The Philippines is set to open 23 coal-fired power plants over the next five years to meet rising electricity demand, illustrating the challenge climate-talk negotiators face in crafting a deal that reduces carbon emissions.
A new draft of the agreement released Wednesday -- after almost 10 days of talks among 195 nations -- showed that some fundamental points remain up in the air, including how much money developing countries should get to help switch away from fossil fuels.
The U.S. announced it would double aid to help poor countries adapt to the effects of climate change, to at least $860 million by 2020, in a signal that rich governments will stick to their part of the deal.
Governments also still haven't decided by how much temperatures should be allowed to increase, or whether emerging economies will take on more responsibilities.
In most of the developed world, competition from natural gas and environmental regulations have crippled the coal industry, bankrupting companies and snuffing out jobs in the U.S. and Europe. But in the Philippines and in dozens of other developing countries, coal remains an essential fuel for building more prosperous societies.
The commodity is cheap and abundant, supplying about 40% of the world's energy, according to the International Energy Agency. But coal is also responsible for a third of all carbon emissions, and its use is projected to rise -- especially in Asia.
Environmentally minded leaders, especially from the West, want to curb coal use. But many developing countries, aware that it fueled the industrialization of the U.S. and Europe, argue that coal is key to their future too.
Manila's building bonanza will make it Asia's most coal-dependent country by 2035 as a percentage of its energy mix, according to IHS Energy Insight, a research company. Government officials say the booming economy needs the coal plants to offset declining domestic reserves of natural gas.
The government's position is at odds with the country's self-image as environmentally progressive. A third of the country's power is now generated by renewable sources, chiefly geothermal and hydroelectric.
Filipinos became acutely conscious of climate change after scientists blamed global warming for the intensity of Typhoon Haiyan, which killed over 7,000 people and ravaged the country's central provinces two years ago.
At the climate talks in Paris, the Philippines is leading a 20-nation group, the Climate Vulnerable Forum, comprising countries such as Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Vietnam that are most at risk from rising temperatures.
Before arriving, President Benigno Aquino III pledged the Philippines would reduce its carbon emissions 70% by 2030.
"We all have to do as much as we can," Mr. Aquino told Asia-Pacific leaders in Manila in November. "Countries have to contribute the maximum."
The Philippine government said in its Paris pledge that the 70% cut would be conditional on financial assistance and the transfer of green technology from more-developed nations, but that ambitious reductions could be made in various sectors, including energy.
Yet, according to IHS, the Philippines will nearly triple its fleet of coal plants by 2020, while doubling the amount of CO2 to 70 million metric tons a year by 2025.
The Philippines is hardly the only country depending on coal.
Vietnam plans to double its coal plants to 40 by 2022 to tide it over until a generation of nuclear generators comes on line. Indonesia is encouraging more coal-fired plants to support its mining industry.
China added an extraordinary 39 gigawatts in new coal-fired capacity last year, according to official data, enough to power millions of homes. Even Japan is building dozens of new coal plants in the wake of the Fukushima disaster.
But while the use of coal in countries like China and India has yet to peak, the commodity is projected to be a smaller proportion of their total fuel mix in the coming decades.
Credit: By Trefor Moss
