U.S. News: Coal Hub Spurs City Brawl Rail-terminal project lauded by Oakland officials is opposed by environmental groups

Author: Lazo, Alejandro

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-coal-hub-spurs-city-brawl-rail-terminal/docview/1722832340/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: While he has sounded an alarm on climate change -- recently telling a Vatican symposium that 90% of the world's coal must remain unused to evade the perils of global warming -- as governor he has angered environmentalists by allowing the expansion of hydraulic fracturing in the state.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Coal+Hub+Spurs+City+Brawl+Rail-terminal+project+lauded+by+Oakland+officials+is+opposed+by+environmental+groups&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Lazo%2C+Alejandro&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Coal+Hub+Spurs+City+Brawl+Rail-terminal+project+lauded+by+Oakland+officials+is+opposed+by+environmental+groups&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-19&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Lazo%2C+Alejandro&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   OAKLAND, Calif. -- A proposal that could make this city a gateway for Utah coal to be shipped overseas has become a political flash point and put pressure on Gov. Jerry Brown, a former mayor known for his warnings on climate change, to come out against the project.
The proposed deal would grant four coal-producing counties in Utah rail access to a major commodities shipping terminal under development on city land, adjacent to the Port of Oakland, in exchange for a $53 million investment. City officials hope the redevelopment plan, on an old Army base, would bring thousands of jobs to a city that still has pockets of poverty and violence even as the region's tech sector booms and housing costs rise.
California ports in Stockton, Richmond and Long Beach export coal, but because of climate change and pollution concerns, such terminals have become highly contested on the West Coast. Environmentalists, who have defeated similar proposals in Oregon and Washington, have filed suit against the city, the project and developers. They are now calling on Mr. Brown, a Democrat, to speak out forcefully against coal being shipped through his former city.
"We are hopeful that he won't let his hometown of Oakland become a thoroughfare for dirty coal," said Jessica Dervin-Ackerman, conservation manager with the local chapter of the Sierra Club.
Mr. Brown declined to comment on the Oakland terminal. While he has sounded an alarm on climate change -- recently telling a Vatican symposium that 90% of the world's coal must remain unused to evade the perils of global warming -- as governor he has angered environmentalists by allowing the expansion of hydraulic fracturing in the state.
The master developer of the project is Phillip Tagami, a local businessman with close ties to Mr. Brown, who is credited with sparking a revitalization of the city's downtown when he served as mayor from 1999 to 2007. Mr. Brown is an investor with Mr. Tagami in an Oakland office building, according to an economic disclosure form filed by the governor. During Mr. Brown's gubernatorial administration, Mr. Tagami served as chairman of the state's Lottery Commission and as a member of its Medical Board; he left the administration in 2013.
The terminal, which would sit at the end of an existing track network, would be managed by Terminal Logistics Solutions, a company that is looking to partner with the Utah counties to export commodities including coal. "It is important to realize that this is an opportunity for Oakland," Jerry Bridges, the company's chief executive, told City Council members last month.
Mr. Tagami said he has spoken with Mr. Brown about the project, assuring him the terminal was designed to accept a wide variety of goods and has passed all necessary environmental reviews. The project, dubbed Oakland Global, is expected to bring in as much as $2.9 million in annual property taxes for the city, schools and other local governments, and has already created more than 2,300 jobs, he said.
"This is a local issue, and I think he respects it as that," Mr. Tagami said.
Utah backers say the state's coal burns more efficiently and has a lower sulfur content than coal from elsewhere, though experts say it doesn't necessarily emit less carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas produced by industry.
The state has sought new markets for its coal as energy companies and utilities in the U.S. have moved toward natural-gas plants and renewable forms of energy due to stricter federal pollution rules. While coal mining represents a fraction of Utah's economy, it has long been a source of jobs for counties in the central and southeastern part of the state. Statewide production of coal last year was near a 30-year low amid lower demand from Nevada and California. The Oakland terminal would give the Utah counties four million to five million tons of annual shipping capacity and access to overseas markets including Asia, where coal is in greater demand than in the U.S.
"This is what I call ultraclean coal, and it has a place in the world markets," said Jae Potter, a commissioner in Utah's Carbon County. "It has a place in developing countries."
But the idea of coal being shipped through Oakland has roiled politics in the city of about 414,000. Among those concerned is Mayor Libby Schaaf, a former aide to Mr. Brown. "We will not have coal shipped through our city," Ms. Schaaf wrote to Mr. Tagami in an email that was made public.
Oakland's City Council, which held a contentious hearing on the issue last month, is considering an ordinance to ban coal at the terminal. The Sierra Club argues coal dust has been linked to decreased lung capacity, childhood bronchitis, asthma, pneumonia, emphysema and heart disease. Mr. Bridges, of Terminal Logistics, told council members that any coal shipped through the city would be covered, eliminating the risk of coal dust.
Mr. Tagami said no restrictions should be imposed on which commodities the terminal can export and that doing so could harm the project's success.
Credit: By Alejandro Lazo

Business News: Maritime Emissions Cut Urged

Author: Phillips, Erica E

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/business-news-maritime-emissions-cut-urged/docview/1721535784/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The ITF, a research arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said the United Nations' International Maritime Organization should impose the standards across the maritime industry -- from container shipping lines to tanker operators -- and set up requirements including a carbon tax.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Business+News%3A+Maritime+Emissions+Cut+Urged&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.7&amp;au=Phillips%2C+Erica+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Business+News%3A+Maritime+Emissions+Cut+Urged&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.7&amp;au=Phillips%2C+Erica+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   The International Transport Forum called Monday for global, enforceable regulations for the maritime industry to reduce carbon emissions by half over the next 35 years and to zero by 2080.
The ITF, a research arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said the United Nations' International Maritime Organization should impose the standards across the maritime industry -- from container shipping lines to tanker operators -- and set up requirements including a carbon tax.
ITF analyst Olaf Merk recommended that the IMO, which regulates shipping emissions, submit regular reports on the industry's progress toward meeting the goals.
The call comes ahead the U.N.'s conference on climate change in December in Paris. The conference will bring together representatives from governments, nongovernmental organizations and U.N. agencies, with the goal of reaching a legally binding deal to limit global warming.
"It would be odd if countries are expected to adhere to emission targets but not the shipping sector, especially since it would be impossible to apportion shipping emissions to countries," the ITF said in a policy brief.
In 2012, the shipping industry contributed 800 million metric tons, or 2.2%, of world-wide carbon emission, according to the ITF.
Mr. Merk said the industry could take steps such as slowing ship speed, ensuring ships are fully used, designing more efficient ships and using alternative fuel sources to meet the targets. ITF recommended setting a carbon tax of $25 per metric ton of carbon dioxide.
Credit: By Erica E. Phillips

City News: N.Y. Unveils Climate Change Plans

Author: Orden, Erica

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/city-news-n-y-unveils-climate-change-plans/docview/1720382090/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Appearing alongside former Vice President Al Gore, a Democrat, at an event at Columbia University, the governor said the state would take several major steps to combat climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=City+News%3A+N.Y.+Unveils+Climate+Change+Plans&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.17&amp;au=Orden%2C+Erica&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=City+News%3A+N.Y.+Unveils+Climate+Change+Plans&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.17&amp;au=Orden%2C+Erica&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo hasn't always earned the praise of his fellow Democrats on issues central to the party, but on Thursday he added his voice to one of its core concerns -- climate change.
Appearing alongside former Vice President Al Gore, a Democrat, at an event at Columbia University, the governor said the state would take several major steps to combat climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. He called the measures a matter of survival, not political importance.
"Climate change is not about making society better. Climate change is an issue of society's sustainability," Mr. Cuomo said. "To deny that climate change is real is to defy reason."
At the news conference, the second climate-change event in which Mr. Cuomo has participated in less than a week, the governor said the state would sign the "Under 2 MOU," a memorandum of understanding among states, provinces and cities to keep the earth's average temperature from increasing two degrees Celsius by 2100.
The agreement is intended to demonstrate the commitment of those who sign it to the participants in the United Nations climate negotiations in Paris in December.
Mr. Cuomo also said the state would attempt to help build a broader North American carbon market with other states, including California and parts of Canada.
The governor's efforts in this area mark the third time recently in which Mr. Cuomo has turned his attention to national issues.
Last month Mr. Cuomo, alongside another Democratic, Vice President Joe Biden, said he would seek to give New York the highest minimum wage in the country. And in the past week, the governor has repeatedly advocated for national gun-control legislation, saying congressional Democrats should threaten to shut down the federal government over the issue.
Though climate change itself hasn't been a central focus of his administration, Mr. Cuomo's first term was marked by the governor's deliberations over high-volume hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, a practice Mr. Cuomo's administration ultimately decided it wouldn't permit in New York.
Still, environmentalists found cause for concern with some elements of the governor's plans. While praising Mr. Cuomo's commitment to the climate change, the executive director of Environmental Advocates of New York, Peter Iwanowicz, said the plans lacked specifics.
"What is still not clear, however, is whether the governor's goals are fully appreciated within his administration or what his plans are to achieve them," Mr. Iwanowicz said.
Credit: By Erica Orden

Business News: Carbon Issue Splits Energy Industry

Author: Kent, Sarah; Harder, Amy

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/business-news-carbon-issue-splits-energy-industry/docview/1719892325/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The chief executives of Royal Dutch Shell PLC and Exxon Mobil Corp. laid out contrasting visions this week for reducing fossil-fuel emissions, illustrating a divide between American and European energy companies ahead of a United Nations climate-change summit.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Business+News%3A+Carbon+Issue+Splits+Energy+Industry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-08&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;au=Kent%2C+Sarah%3BHarder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Business+News%3A+Carbon+Issue+Splits+Energy+Industry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-10-08&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;au=Kent%2C+Sarah%3BHarder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   LONDON -- The chief executives of Royal Dutch Shell PLC and Exxon Mobil Corp. laid out contrasting visions this week for reducing fossil-fuel emissions, illustrating a divide between American and European energy companies ahead of a United Nations climate-change summit.
Rex Tillerson, CEO of U.S.-based Exxon, said Wednesday that innovation, free markets and competition were the best tools for curbing emissions. His remarks came a day after Ben van Beurden, chief of Anglo-Dutch giant Shell, said technology wouldn't be enough to bring about emissions cuts, and that governments needed to step in.
Both executives were speaking here at the Oil and Money conference, co-hosted by Energy Intelligence and the International New York Times.
The differing messages show that the oil industry hasn't come up with a unified response to climate change, even as its leaders become increasingly vocal about it in the run-up to the U.N. summit in Paris. Nearly 200 countries are expected to participate in the Nov. 30 to Dec. 11 meeting, which is designed to hammer out a way to reduce carbon emissions enough to slow climate change.
Messrs. Tillerson and van Beurden agreed on many issues, including that renewable-energy sources like solar can't meet the demands of a quickly industrializing world with a growing population. Both also would back putting a price tag on carbon emissions, an idea expected to be discussed in Paris, but Mr. Tillerson's support was more qualified.
Mr. van Beurden, like many of European energy executives, was more explicit in calling on governments to intervene, and "take the opportunity to put a price on carbon." "By taking the costs of tackling climate change and air pollution into account, carbon-pricing systems will drive the right behavior of consumers and producers," Mr. van Beurden said.
Mr. Tillerson took a different stance, saying technological advances launched the American shale boom, producing an abundance of natural gas that has helped curb U.S. emissions.
Those reductions, he said, were made without a U.S. policy on carbon pricing. Mr. Tillerson said he would accept a carbon tax if it was "revenue neutral," which, according to Exxon's website, means it would be "offset by tax reductions in other areas."
The divergence between American and European energy executives in their approach to climate change has played out elsewhere this year.
The chiefs of the biggest European oil companies signed an open letter in June calling for a carbon-pricing system to be instituted globally. Mr. van Beurden, who helped coordinate the letter, said American companies were invited to join, but declined.
The American Petroleum Institute, which represents hundreds of U.S. oil and gas companies, including Exxon, Chevron Corp., and European companies like Shell, didn't sign the letter.
American companies don't plan to participate in meetings next week in Paris among European energy companies including Shell, BP PLC and French oil giant Total SA and state-oil companies from Saudi Arabia and Mexico to discuss climate-change initiatives.
Credit: By Sarah Kent and Amy Harder

Subject: Climate change; Carbon; Emissions; Petroleum industry; Energy industry; Natural gas utilities

Full text:   SRI LANKA
U.N. Council Urges
Foreign Role in Probe
The United Nations Human Rights Council called for foreign judges and prosecutors to take part in Sri Lankan efforts to try those accused of crimes during and after the country's civil war.
U.N. investigators last month issued a report detailing "egregious violations" by both sides in the decadeslong conflict, including indiscriminate attacks on civilians, torture and rape of detainees, and extrajudicial killings.
The compromise resolution passed by the council was backed by Sri Lanka's government as well as by the U.S. Colombo has been eager to ensure that domestic authorities are in charge of investigations and prosecutions.
-- Gordon Fairclough
---
INDIA
Government Makes
Pledge on Emissions
India pledged to reduce the intensity of its carbon emissions and boost the share of electricity produced from sources other than fossil fuels to 40% by 2030, making it the final major economy to submit a target for a global climate pact.
The world's third-largest carbon polluter filed its climate action plan to the U.N. climate secretariat late Thursday, the deadline for pledges before a December conference in Paris, where governments are supposed to adopt a landmark deal to fight climate change.
The government said it would cut the rate of emissions relative to gross domestic product by 33%-35% by 2030 from 2005 levels. It said India has already reduced its carbon intensity by 12% since 2005.
The carbon intensity goal will allow India's emissions to grow as its economy expands but at a lower rate than now.
-- Associated Press
---
CUBA
Delegations Fail to
Resolve Direct Flights
The U.S. and Cuba are continuing work on re-establishing direct scheduled commercial flights, a State Department official said, though it isn't likely technical and regulatory challenges can be overcome for services to be launched this year.
A U.S. delegation met with Cuban counterparts in Havana this week for two days of technical consultations.
The Obama administration has been exploring an informal arrangement that would allow fliers to book flights direct with airlines rather than via package tour operators, despite the decades-old congressional ban.
-- Doug Cameron

Full text:   SYDNEY -- BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, says a global agreement on climate-change action would slow but not stop demand growth for most of the commodities it produces.
Revealing projections for the first time as December's Paris Climate Conference nears, BHP Chief Commercial Officer Dean Dalla Valle assured investors in London Tuesday that the company has "stress-tested" its global resources business, which includes coal mines and oil fields.
The test: Could BHP withstand policy shifts that would follow an agreement limiting carbon emissions to cap global average temperatures at no more than 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above preindustrial levels?
The conclusion, according to the BHP report: "Even in an orderly or rapid shift to a 2-degree world, we forecast growth in long-term demand for most of our commodities."
Credit: By Rhiannon Hoyle

World News: Obama to Press Growth, Climate at U.N. --- President to advance foreign-policy goals at General Assembly amid new challenges

Author: Lee, Carol E

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-obama-press-growth-climate-at-u-n/docview/1716883274/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: "Because in doing so, we recognize that our most basic bond -- our common humanity -- compels us to act."

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Obama+to+Press+Growth%2C+Climate+at+U.N.+---+President+to+advance+foreign-policy+goals+at+General+Assembly+amid+new+challenges&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Lee%2C+Carol+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Obama+to+Press+Growth%2C+Climate+at+U.N.+---+President+to+advance+foreign-policy+goals+at+General+Assembly+amid+new+challenges&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Lee%2C+Carol+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   President Barack Obama's appearance at the United Nations this week is essentially his last opportunity to use the high-profile global platform to press his foreign-policy agenda, which is facing new challenges as he enters his final year in office.
Increasingly complex dynamics in a volatile Middle East will test Mr. Obama, while he tries to advance his longer-term policy goals on issues such as global development and climate change.
Russia's more aggressive posture in Syria and Iraq is overshadowing Mr. Obama's three days in New York for the U.N. General Assembly. On Monday, Mr. Obama is scheduled to meet with President Vladimir Putin for the first time in more than two years.
The president is also grappling with finding a U.S. role in a global migrant crisis spawned by Syria's civil war.
He is set to address the General Assembly on Monday, a speech that will serve as a road map for how he intends to approach the remaining 16 months of his term. He is expected to appear again next autumn but will have only a few months remaining in office.
Mr. Putin also is scheduled to address the world body on Monday, and the Middle East will be central to the U.S. and Russian leaders' high-stakes talks.
But Mr. Obama's schedule in New York, from Sunday to Tuesday, reflects a president looking to make strides in other policy areas. On Sunday, he addressed a U.N. meeting on global development concerns.
Mr. Obama urged other wealthy nations to contribute more to such issues, particularly the refugee crisis.
"We suffer no illusions of the challenges ahead. But we understand this is something that we must commit ourselves to," Mr. Obama said. "Because in doing so, we recognize that our most basic bond -- our common humanity -- compels us to act."
He said global development issues will be part of his work after he leaves office in January 2017, and he used a speech on Sunday on global development to push another priority, saying "development is threatened by climate change."
On Monday, Mr. Obama also will meet with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The intent of the meeting, for the White House, is to further Mr. Obama's push on climate change.
The White House also announced Mr. Obama will meet with Cuban President Raul Castro on Tuesday, their first since the U.S. and Cuba formally restored diplomatic relations in July. Mr. Castro is attending the U.N. General Assembly for the first time.
Mr. Obama is hoping to advance U.S.-Cuba relations to the point of where he makes a trip to the island nation himself next year.
The diplomatic thaw with Cuba represents one of Mr. Obama's foreign-policy accomplishments. Another, a nuclear deal with Iran reached in July, isn't likely to be followed by a meeting with that country's leaders, administration officials said
Mr. Obama will also meet on Monday with President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan.
---
Felicia Schwartz contributed to this article.
---
What to Expect on Monday
-- Brazil's Dilma Rousseff, President Barack Obama, China's Xi Jinping, Vladimir Putin of Russia, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani and France's Francois Hollande address the General Assembly. Cuba's Raul Castro is also scheduled to speak, in his first assembly address; he is set to meet with Mr. Obama on Tuesday.
-- President Obama and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi meet for the third time this year as they seek to strengthen economic and strategic ties in the face of an increasingly assertive China.
-- A heads-of-state lunch hosted by U.N. Secretary General Ban-Ki Moon could see the first interaction between Messrs. Obama and Putin since a brief encounter in November, ahead of a much-anticipated 5 p.m. summit. Iran won't attend the luncheon.
-- President Obama called a 3 p.m. meeting to advance the U.S. push to increase the U.N.'s force of peacekeepers.
-- Messrs. Obama and Putin are set to meet at 5 p.m., as the Russian leader stakes out an assertive and agenda-shaping policy in the Middle East.
-- On Monday evening, foreign ministers from Iran and the six countries that negotiated the nuclear deal will meet for the first time since the July 14 agreement to chart out implementation.
Credit: By Carol E. Lee

World News: Leaders Tackle Development Goals

Author: Fassihi, Farnaz

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-leaders-tackle-development-goals/docview/1716883244/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Some of the goals are easier to achieve, experts say, such as eradicating extreme poverty and improving sanitation. Since the year 2000, when similar goals were set by the U.N., the number of people living in extreme poverty has been reduced by half.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Leaders+Tackle+Development+Goals&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Fassihi%2C+Farnaz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Leaders+Tackle+Development+Goals&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Fassihi%2C+Farnaz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   UNITED NATIONS -- The messages from world leaders and celebrities gathered here this weekend centered on an ambitious idea: Nations need to tackle 17 goals, including eradicating poverty and controlling climate change, to sustain a better future for the planet and its population.
The cost is $3 trillion and the deadline 2030.
The U.N.'s Sustainable Development Summit kicked off on Friday with 154 countries attending and opening remarks by Pope Francis, a song by Shakira and a call to action by Nobel Peace laureate Malala Yousafzai. It closed on Sunday when President Barack Obama spoke, dismissing skeptics who warn that the U.N.'s global development goals are too broad and costly.
Mr. Obama added his own warning, saying that if the goals are to be implemented, nations need to confront three threats: bad governance, inequality and climate change.
"For peace to have meaning it must be translated to bread, rice, health and education," Mr. Obama said.
Some of the goals are easier to achieve, experts say, such as eradicating extreme poverty and improving sanitation. Since the year 2000, when similar goals were set by the U.N., the number of people living in extreme poverty has been reduced by half.
The more challenging changes will be the most costly ones, such as climate-change regulations, and securing women's rights, for instance in cases of child marriage.
Although 193 countries have adopted the goals, they aren't legally binding and there is no system in place to hold governments accountable if they ignore the recommendations. Some independent observers are worried that countries will pick and choose among the goals and thus jeopardize the project's sustainability.
"The key to the success of these goals is an integrated approach," said Lucilla Spini, head of science programs at International Council for Science, who participated in the conference. "You need to have a comprehensive look. You can't pick one without the other, it won't work."
The U.N. developed the goals over the past three years with significant input from member states and private-sector and nongovernment organizations.
Funding will be another major challenge for developing nations that will mostly have to rely on donated funds through private sector or wealthier countries. Mr. Obama reiterated the U.S.'s commitment to the developing world and highlighted that investing in infrastructure in Africa would enable it to fulfill its development potential and benefit the world.
China's President Xi Jinping said his country would invest $2 billion in developing countries and set up an additional $12 billion fund, mostly for Africa, by 2030.
Other world leaders drew connections between domestic challenges and meeting these goals. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said his priority was eradicating extreme poverty. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said extreme poverty, persecution and war had flooded Europe with refugees and migrants.
"Each and every one of us should work and must work to implement the agenda, so that people all over the world can live a life of dignity," Ms. Merkel said.
Credit: By Farnaz Fassihi

The Pope in America: Pope Ends Visit on a Conciliatory Note --- Sidestepping fiery rhetoric, pontiff urges dialogue in message to a divided country

Author: Rocca, Francis X

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pope-america-ends-visit-on-conciliatory-note/docview/1716883050/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: [...]he deprived both liberals and conservatives of sound bites they might have employed to advance their respective agendas.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=The+Pope+in+America%3A+Pope+Ends+Visit+on+a+Conciliatory+Note+---+Sidestepping+fiery+rhetoric%2C+pontiff+urges+dialogue+in+message+to+a+divided+country&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Rocca%2C+Francis+X&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=The+Pope+in+America%3A+Pope+Ends+Visit+on+a+Conciliatory+Note+---+Sidestepping+fiery+rhetoric%2C+pontiff+urges+dialogue+in+message+to+a+divided+country&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Rocca%2C+Francis+X&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   PHILADELPHIA -- During his landmark six-day visit to the U.S., Pope Francis used a soft sell to convey a conciliatory message on topics such as immigration, climate change and inequality, setting aside the fiery rhetoric that had polarized the U.S. faithful, church leaders and politicians before his arrival.
The pope largely glossed over divisive issues, staying on safer ground as he preached a message of dialogue to a deeply divided country. As a result, he deprived both liberals and conservatives of sound bites they might have employed to advance their respective agendas.
"He helped us to see that this polarization that exists in our society, certainly among our politicians and even within the church, this isn't the way we ought to be," said Bishop Gerald F. Kicanas of Tucson.
Before his arrival, the pope's strong language on capitalism, social justice and climate change had made him a sharply divisive figure. Liberals championed his defense of the environment and denunciation of economic inequality, while conservatives blasted his rhetoric on the free-market system and lamented his softer approach to moral issues such as divorce.
As recently as July, the pope blamed many of the world's ills on "corporations, loan agencies, certain 'free trade' treaties, and the imposition of measures of 'austerity' that always tighten the belt of workers and the poor." He described money as "the dung of the devil."
But he left that language behind on his arrival in the U.S., making little reference to capitalism except to laud the "spirit of enterprise."
In his speech before Congress, he spoke about progress in poverty reduction and the potential for technology to curb man-made harm to the environment. He didn't repeat his call in his June encyclical on the environment to combat global warming by reducing use of fossil fuels.
The pope's references to immigration consisted of homespun appeals to the immigrant experience -- including his own, as the son of an Italian who moved to Argentina -- urging his audience to identify with the hopes of Latin American migrants coming north in search of a better life and asking: "Is this not what we want for our own children?"
Even when appealing to the liberal agenda, he was subtle. In the congressional address he paid tribute to American heroes including Abraham Lincoln and Martin Luther King Jr. But he also celebrated Dorothy Day, founder of the Catholic Worker movement, and Thomas Merton, a poet and Cistercian monk who championed interreligious dialogue and nuclear disarmament.
He trod lightly over sensitive ethical questions such as same-sex marriage, abortion and divorce.
In a speech to U.S. bishops in Washington, he warned against the "temptation to give in to fear, to lick one's wounds, to think back on bygone times and to devise harsh responses to fierce opposition."
"Harsh and divisive language does not befit the tongue of a pastor, it has no place in his heart," the pope told the bishops.
That was a clear call for the American bishops to shift away from their approach under St. John Paul II and Pope Benedict XVI, who encouraged a more confrontational attitude on the most widely contested church teachings.
The pope did send the bishops important signals of support in their struggle with the Obama administration over the contraception mandate in the health law, and in looming conflicts over whether the U.S. Supreme Court's July ruling recognizing a right to same-sex marriage will require Catholic institutions to hire or extend employee benefits to same-sex spouses.
The pope used his first speech on U.S. soil, delivered to President Barack Obama, to warn Americans to "preserve and defend [religious] freedom from everything that would threaten or compromise it." The next day, he paid a surprise visit to the Little Sisters of the Poor, whose demands for a "conscience" exemption to the contraception mandate have made them heroines in the bishops' religious-freedom campaign.
"His messages on religious freedom have been very, very welcome," said Archbishop William E. Lori, chairman of the U.S. bishops' conference's committee on religious freedom. "That's going to help because his witness to faith is so credible and people are so open to what he has to say."
When asked why the pope didn't issue stronger statements against same-sex marriage, Vatican spokesman Father Federico Lombardi said the pope "avoided particular polemics or discussion because he comes [with] a positive message."
Meanwhile, the pope's major opportunity to address ordinary Americans -- a prime-time telecast at a celebration of the family Saturday evening -- gave him the chance to put forth a passionate defense of the traditional family as a monogamous union of a man and a woman.
But when the pope spoke, he entirely ignored those topics. He gave the most relaxed address of the visit, mixing in jokes about mothers-in-law. "Families have difficulties, families quarrel, and sometimes plates can fly," he said. "But the family is like a factory of hope."
Credit: By Francis X. Rocca

World News: China, U.S. to Move on Climate

Author: Colleen McCain Nelson; Mauldin, William

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-china-u-s-move-on-climate/docview/1716197935/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The announcements Friday will detail their strategies for reaching emissions targets, the officials said, and aim to bolster efforts to complete an international accord to reduce global carbon-dioxide emissions, which is meant to be wrapped up in December.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+China%2C+U.S.+to+Move+on+Climate&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.13&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BMauldin%2C+William&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+China%2C+U.S.+to+Move+on+Climate&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.13&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BMauldin%2C+William&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- The U.S. and China will announce steps in their efforts to combat climate change, including a pledge by China to begin by 2017 a program to cap some emissions and put a price on carbon, senior Obama administration officials said Thursday.
The announcements Friday will detail their strategies for reaching emissions targets, the officials said, and aim to bolster efforts to complete an international accord to reduce global carbon-dioxide emissions, which is meant to be wrapped up in December.
Chinese President Xi Jinping's decision to put a price on national CO2 emissions with a cap-and-trade system would mark the first time China has launched such an initiative.
Obama administration officials said the emissions-trading system would encompass sectors that produce a substantial amount of air pollution, including the paper, steel and cement industries.
Chinese officials have said they aimed to introduce a national emissions-trading program by 2017, following on programs in cities such as Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.
The plan to be announced Friday would represent an evolution from these regional test programs, and mark a significant policy undertaking by the Chinese, U.S. officials said.
Asked about a potential climate deal late Thursday, Lu Kang, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, declined to give details of what the two presidents might announce.
Friday's expected announcements come after months of discussions among U.S. and Chinese officials, as the Obama administration tries to build momentum ahead of United Nations climate-change negotiations in Paris later this year.
The announcements were expected to include domestic policy proposals from each country, climate-related finance commitments and what officials called a "common vision" for the international agreement. China also will announce a significant contribution to finance efforts in developing countries, they said.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and William Mauldin

Pope Issues Challenge to Congress

Author: Rocca, Francis X; Peterson, Kristina; Hughes, Siobhan

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pope-issues-challenge-congress/docview/1716197923/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: According to the Vatican spokesman, the omission was accidental and the Vatican would publish the missing words in the official text of the speech.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Pope+Issues+Challenge+to+Congress&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Rocca%2C+Francis+X%3BPeterson%2C+Kristina%3BHughes%2C+Siobhan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Pope+Issues+Challenge+to+Congress&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Rocca%2C+Francis+X%3BPeterson%2C+Kristina%3BHughes%2C+Siobhan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- In the first-ever address by a pontiff to a joint meeting of Congress, Pope Francis urged a divided legislature -- and nation -- to "confront every form of polarization" in seeking solutions to some of society's most pressing problems.
In an hour-long speech Thursday delivered in English, the pope urged lawmakers to take action to protect the environment, welcome immigrants and reduce economic inequality. The message challenged some Republican positions on those issues, especially immigration, a topic that has sharply divided Congress as well as candidates for president.
His address, though, was clearly calibrated for his audience, which welcomed him with an excitement and warmth unusual in the Capitol. His rhetoric was softer than what he often employs on these issues -- language that has earned him particular criticism in the U.S.
"I too am a son of this great continent, from which we have all received so much and toward which we share a common responsibility," he said.
The Argentine pope, who later in the day traveled to New York for the next leg of his six-day tour, lamented economic inequality and told the audience of senators, representatives and Supreme Court justices to be more accepting of immigrants, combat pollution and abolish the death penalty -- all positions more popular with Democrats. Rep. Nydia Velazquez (D., N.Y.) let out a loud whoop and rose from her seat after the comments on capital punishment.
But Pope Francis -- who has scorned money as the "dung of the devil" and rejected laissez-faire economic policies, which he says rely on faith in a "deified market" -- eschewed such harsh language Thursday. Instead, he echoed defenders of capitalism by stating that the "harnessing of the spirit of enterprise" is an essential element in the "creation and distribution of wealth."
Though he has written of an "exponentially" growing gap between rich and poor, he struck a more optimistic tone, saying that "much has been done in these first years of the third millennium to raise people out of extreme poverty."
Pope Francis didn't read the strongest words on the subject in his prepared text: a warning that politics "cannot be a slave to the economy and finance." According to the Vatican spokesman, the omission was accidental and the Vatican would publish the missing words in the official text of the speech.
The pope addressed immigration in a less confrontational way than he has done in Europe, where he has denounced indifference to the fate of migrants who have drowned trying to cross the Mediterranean. He instead appealed to the foreign heritage of most of his listeners, identifying himself as the "son of immigrants, knowing that so many of you are also descended from immigrants."
"On this continent, too, thousands of persons are led to travel north in search of a better life," he said. "Is this not what we want for our own children?"
Later in New York, Pope Francis presided over a service at St. Patrick's Cathedral. He began his remarks by expressing sorrow for the deadly stampede in Mecca on Thursday, and in his homily praised Catholic nuns, drawing applause. He also referred to the Catholic priest sex-abuse scandal, saying the clergy "suffered greatly in the not-distant past by having to bear the shame of some of your brothers who harmed and scandalized the Church in the most vulnerable of her members."
In his Washington address, the pope omitted any specifics in his remarks on the environment, one of the pope's best-known and most controversial causes -- including his earlier call to combat climate change by reducing the use of fossil fuels -- and spoke only generally of the need to "avert the most serious effects of the environmental deterioration caused by human activity."
The pope reserved his strongest rhetoric for a condemnation of the arms industry, whose profits he said were "drenched in blood, often innocent blood."
In several cases, the pontiff touched only delicately on sensitive areas. In an apparent reference to same-sex marriage, he expressed his "concern for the family, which is threatened, perhaps as never before, from within and without." Republicans as well as many U.S. church leaders have called on the pope to speak more boldly on issues such as homosexuality and abortion.
He repeated the call of previous popes and U.S. Catholic bishops for abolition of the death penalty and then hinted at his own more radical proposal, to end life imprisonment. A "just and necessary punishment must never exclude the dimension of hope and the goal of rehabilitation," he said.
The presence of the popular pope inspired a rare show of bipartisanship in the Capitol, especially among the one-third of lawmakers who are Catholic, including House Speaker John Boehner (R., Ohio) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.), both of whom appeared elated to see the pontiff. Other Catholics in the audience included Vice President Joe Biden, Secretary of State John Kerry and Chief Justice John Roberts.
After the speech, Democrats focused on the policy challenges posed by the pope, while Republicans sought to play down their legislative disagreements with him.
"The pontiff reaffirmed that we are in a time of crisis: The moment to act on climate change is now," said Sen. Chris Murphy (D., Conn.)
House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) noted the pope's decision Wednesday to pay an unscheduled visit to the Little Sisters of the Poor, a Catholic religious order that operates nursing homes. The Vatican spokesman said the visit was a "sign of support" for the nuns' demands, so far unsuccessful, for a conscience exemption to the contraception mandate in the federal health law.
Before leaving the Capitol, Pope Francis appeared on a balcony to greet the enormous crowds outside, who erupted in cheers. Mr. Boehner, standing beside him, seemed overcome with emotion.
Speaking in his native Spanish, Pope Francis asked the crowd for their prayers, adding that nonbelievers were welcome to send him "good wishes."
He then closed with a few words in English: "God bless America."
The pope later met with homeless people at Washington's St. Patrick's Church, where he offered consolation for their "unjust and painful situations."
The pope will address the United Nations General Assembly on Friday.
Credit: By Francis X. Rocca, Kristina Peterson and Siobhan Hughes

Abstract: Heather Haddon --- STATE DINNER Obama, Xi to Dine On Lamb, Lobster After what's expected to be a tense day of talks Friday on topics including cyber and maritime security, Chinese President Xi Jinping and President Barack Obama will dig into Colorado lamb, Maine lobster and other dishes incorporating American and Chinese culinary traditions at an elaborate state dinner.

Full text:   2016 ELECTION
Trump Not a Believer
In Climate Change
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said he doesn't believe in climate change and that measures to fight it would "imperil the companies in our country."
The New York real-estate developer said in a CNN interview Thursday that bad floods and other abnormal weather patterns have happened in the past, and the media is fixated too much on the issue.
"You can't watch the news anymore. It's always weather," said Mr. Trump, who added China hasn't done anything to address climate change.
"I believe in clean air. Immaculate air," Mr. Trump said. "But I don't believe in climate change."
-- Heather Haddon

STATE DINNER
Obama, Xi to Dine
On Lamb, Lobster
After what's expected to be a tense day of talks Friday on topics including cyber and maritime security, Chinese President Xi Jinping and President Barack Obama will dig into Colorado lamb, Maine lobster and other dishes incorporating American and Chinese culinary traditions at an elaborate state dinner.
Expect business leaders, politicians and some celebrities to be at the dinner, though the White House was tight-lipped Thursday about who would be among the about 210 invited guests. An official list will be released Friday.
Lee Daniels, director of "The Butler," a movie loosely based on the life of a former White House staffer, said earlier this week that he'd be among the guests. Pop singer Ne-Yo, who has said his father is of African American and Chinese descent, will provide entertainment after dinner.
-- Felicia Schwartz

Pope Takes On Big Issues --- On U.S. trip, pontiff speaks about climate change, immigration, religious freedom

Author: Lee, Carol E; Colleen McCain Nelson; Rocca, Francis X

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pope-takes-on-big-issues-u-s-trip-pontiff-speaks/docview/1715858110/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The pope's remarks, delivered in English, also gave credence to GOP arguments in Congress and on the campaign trail that some of Mr. Obama's core policies infringe on Americans' religious freedoms, such as his support for the Supreme Court ruling in favor of gay marriage.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Pope+Takes+On+Big+Issues+---+On+U.S.+trip%2C+pontiff+speaks+about+climate+change%2C+immigration%2C+religious+freedom&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Lee%2C+Carol+E%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson%3BRocca%2C+Francis+X&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Pope+Takes+On+Big+Issues+---+On+U.S.+trip%2C+pontiff+speaks+about+climate+change%2C+immigration%2C+religious+freedom&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-24&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Lee%2C+Carol+E%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson%3BRocca%2C+Francis+X&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- Pope Francis, during a day wrapped in ceremonial fanfare for the first public events of his landmark U.S. visit, challenged America's political and Catholic leaders, bringing a pointed yet conciliatory message to a country embroiled in debates over climate change, immigration, gay marriage and religious freedoms.
On each issue and at each stop on Wednesday -- from the White House to Mass at the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception to a speech to U.S. Catholic bishops -- the pope urged dialogue over opposing views, while standing firm on the Church's moral teachings.
He even waded into a fraught legal struggle between Catholic institutions and the federal government by paying an unplanned afternoon visit to an order of nuns. Pope Francis visited the Little Sisters of the Poor in what his spokesman called a "sign of support" for their demands, so far unsuccessful, for a conscience exemption to the contraception mandate in the health-care law.
By the end of a day that included cheering crowds as he paraded along the National Mall in his open-air popemobile, Pope Francis had both defended and challenged the positions of Democratic and Republican politicians -- and even U.S. bishops.
He endorsed climate-change initiatives President Barack Obama and fellow Democrats support and many Republicans oppose, saying "it seems clear to me also that climate change is a problem which can no longer be left to our future generation."
"When it comes to the care of our 'common home,' we are living at a critical moment of history," the 78-year-old pontiff said.
The pope's remarks, delivered in English, also gave credence to GOP arguments in Congress and on the campaign trail that some of Mr. Obama's core policies infringe on Americans' religious freedoms, such as his support for the Supreme Court ruling in favor of gay marriage.
A "truly tolerant and inclusive" society respects Catholics' "deepest concerns and their right to religious liberty," the pope said, noting the church's rejection of "every form of unjust discrimination," a phrase found in the Catechism of the Church in regard to "homosexual persons."
The pope arrived in Washington on Tuesday, following a visit to Cuba. He will address a joint session of Congress Thursday morning -- the first pontiff to do so. Later in the week, he travels to New York, where he will address the United Nations General Assembly. He closes his trip with a visit to Philadelphia over the weekend, including a Mass on Sunday expected to draw more than a million pilgrims.
The Argentine pontiff set the tone for his first-ever visit to the U.S. at the start of his first full day. "As a son of an immigrant family, I am happy to be a guest in this country, which was largely built by such families," he said at the start of brief remarks during an elaborate White House welcoming ceremony.
The comments came as immigration is under fierce debate in the 2016 presidential race and as efforts to pass an overhaul of the system have stalled in Congress due to party divisions.
"Our mission as bishops is first and foremost to solidify unity," he said. "This service to unity is particularly important for this nation, whose vast . . . resources impose significant moral responsibilities" for world "peace, prosperity and integration."
Later, in a speech to bishops, Pope Francis again touched on the issue of immigration, calling for special attention to the influx of Latin-American immigrants in the Catholic Church -- a group that is the main driver of growth of the faith in the U.S. He told the bishops that they may be challenged by such diversity but that these immigrants have resources that should be shared.
The pope largely avoided the scandal that has seriously undermined the U.S. church -- sexual abuse of minors by priests. He made only a brief reference to the problem in remarks to the bishops, thanking U.S. church leaders for working to ensure that such crimes won't be repeated while making no mention of punishing abusive priests or church leaders who covered up incidents. The pope is expected to meet victims of sex abuse during his visit.
The pontiff, through his policy pronouncements, presented himself as a unifying figure in a deeply divided country.
Democrats and Republicans, who are at odds in current policy debates, agree on their admiration of Pope Francis. The pope's White House arrival ceremony drew Democratic and Republican lawmakers alike, and GOP presidential candidate Jeb Bush attended Mass with the pontiff.
Both parties sought to highlight areas where the pope bolstered their views while playing down areas where he didn't.
Mr. Obama thanked Pope Francis for his key role in supporting his effort to restore U.S. diplomatic relations with Cuba and highlighted the pontiff's endorsement of his climate-change initiatives.
"Holy Father, you remind us that we have a sacred obligation to protect our planet -- God's magnificent gift to us," Mr. Obama said.
Mr. Obama's aides hope the pope's support of initiatives to combat climate change will boost the chances of a broad agreement at an international meeting on the problem this December in Paris.
The pope, who in a major encyclical published last May threw his support behind those arguing that human activity is contributing to climate change, has been unusually forthright in saying he hopes the Paris meeting will produce new solutions.
Republicans, by contrast, seized on the pope's comments on religious freedom and gay marriage.
"I was encouraged that Pope Francis began his first speech in the U.S. by expressing appreciation for America's founding principles, especially religious liberty, and the importance of traditional marriage, family and the sanctity of life to our culture," said Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R., Kan.). Sen. James Lankford (R., Okla.) said he was "grateful to hear Pope Francis bring up the importance of religious liberty."
Yet it is unclear the pope's message will change the tone of policy debates in Washington.
"Everybody wants a clean planet, everybody wants to take care of those who are less fortunate," said Rep. Tom Rooney (R., Fla.). "I believe this pope is saying the right things about how I should live my life as an individual and how I should raise my children. How that translates into public policy, I just think is very different."
Thousands of people turned out for the pope on Wednesday. The day began with Mr. Obama welcoming the pope at the White House, where more than 11,000 were gathered on the South Lawn.
After the public event, Mr. Obama gave Pope Francis a tour of the White House and the two met privately for 40 minutes, without aides, in the Oval Office.
They discussed a range of issues, according to the White House, including the moral responsibility to offer refuge to people who are forced to flee their homelands and the right of all people to practice their faith.
The pope ended his day by celebrating an outdoor Mass where he proclaimed Father Junipero Serra, the friar considered the father of California's missions, a saint.
---
Kristina Peterson and Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.

The Pope in America: Obama to Tread Lightly With Pope --- President will focus on issues such as Cuba, climate, which he and the pontiff agree on

Author: Lee, Carol E

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pope-america-obama-tread-lightly-with-president/docview/1714543188/se-2?accountid=9883

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- When Pope Francis becomes the third pontiff to visit the White House, President Barack Obama plans to use the moment to advance core components of his policy agenda.
He'll have to tread carefully, however, as the effort to capitalize on the high-profile meeting is diplomatically sensitive.
Unlike in meetings with other foreign leaders, Mr. Obama won't be trying to shape the pontiff's views before or during his Wednesday appearance at the White House. Instead, White House officials are looking at ways to tweak the president's message to more closely align with the pope's pronouncements on issues where they already overlap, including two central to the president's second-term agenda: combating climate change and renewing U.S. relations with Cuba.
Mr. Obama's push on both issues has drawn criticism from Republicans. But Pope Francis has advocated for similar actions on climate change and played a key role in facilitating the historic thaw between Washington and Havana.
The White House also announced, in advance of the pope's arrival, a more robust response to the refugee crisis that has mostly stemmed from the civil war in Syria, including a decision to accept 10,000 additional Syrian refugees during the next year, an increase of 30,000 in the U.S. intake of refugees overall and additional humanitarian aid.
Pope Francis has called on Europe's Catholics to accept refugees and met with one family at the Vatican before flying to Havana last weekend.
The challenge for Mr. Obama, though, is to seize on those overlapping views without appearing to be overly political in doing so.
"Anybody who tries to use Pope Francis is going to be disappointed, and that goes for the right and the left, in the church and outside the church, because while he is consistent in his defense of human life and human dignity, we are not," said John Carr, director of the Initiative on Catholic Social Thought & Public Life at Georgetown University.
The pope looks askance at political gamesmanship, which means the administration will be moving cautiously.
"This is a huge moment," said Christopher Hale, executive director of Catholics in Alliance for the Common Good. "Pope Francis and the president share many values." Yet Mr. Hale, who helped the Obama campaign with Catholic outreach, warned that the pontiff "has a profound aversion to being used as a political football to push people's agendas."
That, in part, is why much of the White House's public campaign to use the papal visit to promote Mr. Obama's policies actually is set to unfold in the days after the meeting.
"We are very sensitive that what makes [the pope's] statements powerful is that they come from him. They don't come from our requests," said Ben Rhodes, one of Mr. Obama's closest foreign-policy advisers.
Mr. Obama and the pope also differ on issues such as abortion and gay rights, and the White House hopes to play down those differences. The pope also has been a critic of U.S. consumerism and capitalism.
Mr. Obama will be one of just three presidents to host a pope at the White House. President Jimmy Carter received Pope John Paul II in 1979, and President George W. Bush welcomed Pope Benedict XVI in 2008.
Credit: By Carol E. Lee

World News: Obama, Xi Advance Climate Deal --- Ahead of leadership summit, U.S. and China plan parallel emission reductions

Author: Mauldin, William; Colleen McCain Nelson

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-obama-xi-advance-climate-deal-ahead/docview/1712452918/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: For the world's highly developed economies, a top goal of the agreement expected in Paris in December is signing up fast-growing emerging markets, which have avoided the burden of reducing emissions in previous agreements organized by the United Nations.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Obama%2C+Xi+Advance+Climate+Deal+---+Ahead+of+leadership+summit%2C+U.S.+and+China+plan+parallel+emission+reductions&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Mauldin%2C+William%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Obama%2C+Xi+Advance+Climate+Deal+---+Ahead+of+leadership+summit%2C+U.S.+and+China+plan+parallel+emission+reductions&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Mauldin%2C+William%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Next week, President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping will add to earlier pledges to cut greenhouse-gas emissions with specific guidance on what the two countries will do at home to keep climate change at bay, officials said.
The United States and China announced Tuesday that cities, states and provinces in both countries would commit to taking parallel steps to address climate change.
The participating Chinese cities and provinces, which represent about 25% of total urban emissions in that country, will offer plans to have their emissions peak sooner than the national target of 2030.
Beijing and Guangzhou, two of China's largest cities, will aim for their peak emissions to come as early as 2020.
Climate officials and leaders from both countries are meeting in Los Angeles this week to lay out the steps the regions will take and to set the groundwork for next week's summit between the two presidents.
U.S. officials said the Obama-Xi summit is part of an effort by the two biggest polluters -- which account for more than a third of global greenhouse-gas emissions -- to demonstrate progress on meeting the terms of a bilateral accord reached in November.
White House press secretary Josh Earnest said Tuesday that Mr. Obama would use next week's meeting to discuss additional opportunities for U.S.-China cooperation on cutting carbon pollution.
The U.S. commitments are coming from states such as California and Connecticut and an array of cities including Atlanta, Boston, Los Angeles, Washington, Seattle, and Houston.
The U.S. pledged last year to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions by between 26% and 28% by 2025, compared with 2005 levels, while China said it would make sure its emissions peak by 2030 or earlier.
To achieve its goal, the Obama administration this summer finalized new rules for coal power plants.
Some prominent Republicans in Congress say the moves will damage the U.S. economy and are moving to block the rules in court; they are seeking to undermine Mr. Obama's authority to conclude a binding agreement among nearly 200 nations, which is meant to come to a head in Paris later this year.
"Last year was a year for setting goals and targets," said Brian Deese, a senior White House adviser who specializes in climate issues. "This year needs to be a year of implementation."
The Chinese cities' commitment to early peaking highlights the country's efforts to achieve its national target as early as possible, Mr. Deese said, and the joint U.S.-China actions show the seriousness of the effort to meet the terms of the countries' agreement.
The cities, states and provinces that sign the declaration and pledge to address climate change also will track and report their emissions on a regular basis. Such commitments create a measure of accountability, Mr. Deese said.
For the world's highly developed economies, a top goal of the agreement expected in Paris in December is signing up fast-growing emerging markets, which have avoided the burden of reducing emissions in previous agreements organized by the United Nations.
The U.S.-China climate discussions will spill into a range of wider discussions among countries gathering later this month at the U.N.
China's move last year reassured environmentalists about Beijing's commitment, but India and other emerging markets haven't submitted their own proposals for cutting emissions through the Paris accord.
Republicans in Congress say China got off easy by agreeing to start reducing emissions only in 2030. A slowing Chinese economy and rebalancing away from heavy manufacturing could allow China to achieve the goal much earlier without significant costs, according to some climate experts.
A survey this summer by the China Carbon Forum, an independent organization that promotes efforts to curb climate change in China, found that 82% of industry experts say China will reach its emissions peak before 2030, with 39% saying before 2025 and 16% before 2020.
Mr. Earnest, the White House press secretary, said the pledges announced Tuesday signaled that China's emissions could peak before 2030.
Environmentalists have cheered China's commitment to boosting green energy, a shared goal U.S. officials say will likely come up during Mr. Xi's visit.
The two leaders may also tackle some of the thorny unresolved issues of the international climate talks, including poorer countries' insistence that developed economies help finance their transitions at a cost of around $100 billion a year for all countries combined.
"Anything that signaled a preparedness to find some common ground on the outstanding issues would be welcomed," said Jo Tyndall, New Zealand's climate-change ambassador, in Washington last week.
Credit: By William Mauldin and Colleen McCain Nelson

Climate, Not Russia, The Real Arctic Threat

Abstract: Climate change is the result of past accumulations and increasing CO2 emissions. [...]reducing those emissions is the principal security effort he should be engaged in, starting with getting the U.S. to enact a carbon fee and dividend program.

Full text:   I'm amazed at Sen. John McCain's inability to understand that the real dangers facing the U.S. are the forces causing the melting of Arctic ice, which are far more threatening than Vladimir Putin's theatrical posturing ("The Real Arctic Threat," op-ed, Sept. 2).
Sen. McCain's failure to extrapolate from the current melting to the dangers of extreme climate change, for which no other threat compares, underscores that he is utterly unprepared for the new world we are in. Climate change is the result of past accumulations and increasing CO2 emissions. Therefore, reducing those emissions is the principal security effort he should be engaged in, starting with getting the U.S. to enact a carbon fee and dividend program. A tax on carbon emissions buttressed by a tariff on imports from countries without a comparable program would result in the rest of the world quickly following suit and ending Mr. Putin's imperialistic ambitions.
Alan Wright
Roslindale, Mass.

U.S. News: Both Sides Dig In on California Climate Push

Author: Lazo, Alejandro

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-both-sides-dig-on-california-climate/docview/1709975640/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: [...]if you're in the business of selling a product that the state says we want you to sell half as much, obviously they're going to do everything they can to prevent that."

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Both+Sides+Dig+In+on+California+Climate+Push&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Lazo%2C+Alejandro&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Both+Sides+Dig+In+on+California+Climate+Push&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=Lazo%2C+Alejandro&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   SACRAMENTO, Calif. -- Democrats in California, which already has the toughest climate-change rules in the U.S., are pushing to strengthen them drastically, an effort that has spurred business groups to mount an intense opposition campaign.
A proposed state law would cut petroleum-fuel use by 50%, require utilities to get half their power from renewable sources, and increase energy efficiency in buildings by 50% -- all by 2030, using 2016 levels as the starting point. A second measure would mandate an 80% reduction in state greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050, from 1990 levels.
The bills are backed by Democratic Gov. Jerry Brown and billionaire environmentalist Tom Steyer, who say that California must begin taking serious steps to curb its use of fossil fuels.
Business organizations and the energy industry say the effort would hurt the state economy and hit residents' wallets.
Both measures have passed the California Senate, though none of the 14 Republicans in the 40-member body voted for them. Bob Huff, the former state Senate minority leader, called reducing greenhouse gases a "noble" goal, but said "those gases don't end at California's border."
The legislation would have to be approved by the California Assembly, where Democrats also dominate -- though some have withheld support over concerns about their economic impact, making the bills' fate too close to call, observers say.
While the energy sector doesn't have a specific projection for how much the proposed policies would cost the state economy, a June study commissioned by the petroleum industry estimates 184,100 Californians received a total of $23.3 billion in pay and benefits from the oil and gas industry in 2013.
Both sides of the issue are stepping up their game.
An opposition campaign from the oil industry is warning state residents in television, radio and mail advertisements that the mandates would result in fuel rationing and driving restrictions.
"If you can afford a Tesla [electric car], then this message won't really matter to you," a woman says in one of the television ads for the group California Drivers Alliance, which is backed by the Western States Petroleum Association.
Mr. Brown has raised his rhetoric in response, saying on the shores of Lake Tahoe in August that "the oil industry is in deep trouble" because it sells a "product that is highly destructive." At another event in Oakland last month, the governor said climate change has exacerbated the state's wildfires and refuted the oil industry's argument, saying: "This is not about rationing. As a matter of fact, if you're in the business of selling a product that the state says we want you to sell half as much, obviously they're going to do everything they can to prevent that."
The governor said he is working with the bills' critics, which include the California Chamber of Commerce, but said he has "no intention of backing down."
The measures don't lay out specific ways to reach the targets; the details would be left to California's Air Resources Board. The hope is that setting the goals would spur industry innovations, including in zero-emissions vehicles and biofuels.
The Western States Petroleum Association spent $2.5 million lobbying California lawmakers through the first half of the year on a host of legislation, including the two climate-change bills, lobbying reports show. Tupper Hull, a spokesman for the group, said the petroleum-reduction mandate was "a very poorly conceived and reckless attempt to slash how much fuel is available for Californians to use."
The new legislation would add to California's efforts to fight climate change, which include populating the state's freeways with electric cars and other low-emission vehicles, increasing biofuels in gasoline and building a high-speed train line.
California produces about 1.5% of the world's greenhouse-gas emissions. But the state has long been a bellwether on environmental regulations, passing laws that are copied by other states and become templates for federal environmental rules.
President Barack Obama recently cited the state's proposed 50% curb on petroleum use by motor vehicles as an example of how states could act to combat climate change. Among the proposals' biggest backers is Mr. Steyer, a former hedge-fund manager who has become one of the Democrats' most generous donors nationally and has begun using his fortune to shape environmental policy in California.
Mr. Steyer spent $29.6 million to bankroll an initiative in 2012 that uses corporate taxes to fund energy upgrades at schools and other buildings. His NextGen Climate organization has spent close to $730,000 lobbying California lawmakers on legislation including the two climate-change bills, lobbying records show.
"If we can afford to get our message out, our message wins," said Mr. Steyer.
Severin Borenstein, a professor at the University of California, Berkeley's Haas School of Business, said he sees reducing petroleum fuel use by 50% in the state as a "long-shot," requiring major advances in biofuels, or a rapid expansion of low-emission vehicles. Other experts say the goals are achievable.
"This focus on California reducing our own greenhouse gases, without really thinking hard about how the rest of the world is reducing greenhouse gases, is misguided," Dr. Borenstein said. "I think what we should refocus on is this: helping develop the technologies that China and India, and the rest of the developing world, would actually adopt."
Credit: By Alejandro Lazo
