Abstract: The false threat of climate change caused by the use of fossil-fueled power plants and CO2 release is documented by the current 18-plus-year lack of change in the global temperature record as provided by NASA satellites, even as atmospheric CO2 has increased over 10%.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Powering+Up+for+the+Future+in+a+Climate+of+Uncertainty&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   The correct headline for the Aug. 29 letters responding to Daniel Yergin's "Power Up" essay isn't "Green, 'Alternative' Energy Is Moving to the Big Time" but "Green Part-Time Energy." Utility-scale green electricity exists as adjunct energy only because it is on a grid with full-time electricity producers. As the green movement kills full-time electricity producers, starting with coal, substituting so-called solar and wind "alternatives" will kill civilization as we know it. Think of reading essays at night by the light of candles.
Storage of green energy can work for homes and other small nonutility applications, as Richard Factor writes about Arizona. In sunny Arizona, a reasonable-size battery can bridge the electricity gap from sunsets to sunrises. In New England, where five or more days can pass without a visible sunrise, battery sizes must grow by a factor of five or more. Universal utility-scale storage has yet to be invented.
George F. Steeg
Potomac Falls, Va.
---
Paul Bledsoe's letter demonstrates his skills as political propagandist and environmental activist. Devoid of a single credible reference, his letter purports to solve the fact of eternal climate change. His letter speaks of authoritative dogma, not scientific argument.
"Capturing carbon dioxide" isn't the answer. The Energy Department pulled support in February for FutureGen Industrial Alliance Inc., a public-private partnership to build a coal plant that would store its CO2 emissions. A similar project in Kemper County, Miss., is now projected to cost almost $5.6 billion, not the estimated $2.4 billion. Such plants require a secondary power-generation source to supply the approximate 40% additional energy to drive the CO2 compression and burial scheme.
The false threat of climate change caused by the use of fossil-fueled power plants and CO2 release is documented by the current 18-plus-year lack of change in the global temperature record as provided by NASA satellites, even as atmospheric CO2 has increased over 10%. It is now over 10 years since a Category 3 or higher hurricane has hit the U.S. mainland. Two cycles of declining sunspot activity suggest a cooling trend. The droughts in the West are well-known to be cyclical.
The true disaster for the Paris climate meeting is the lack of credible evidence for supporting the climate scare story.
Charles G. Battig
Scientists and Engineers for Energy and Environment
Charlottesville, Va.

World News: Catholics in U.S. Split on Families

Author: Audi, Tamara

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-catholics-u-s-split-on-families/docview/1708737865/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Roman Catholics in America overwhelmingly believe it is best to raise children in a household with a married mother and father, but most also consider families composed of unmarried or same-sex couples acceptable, according to a survey released Wednesday.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Catholics+in+U.S.+Split+on+Families&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;au=Audi%2C+Tamara&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Catholics+in+U.S.+Split+on+Families&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;au=Audi%2C+Tamara&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Roman Catholics in America overwhelmingly believe it is best to raise children in a household with a married mother and father, but most also consider families composed of unmarried or same-sex couples acceptable, according to a survey released Wednesday.
The survey by the Pew Research Center sought to capture how practicing and nonpracticing U.S. Catholics viewed family issues in advance of Pope Francis' visit this month. He is set to address Congress and the United Nations and spend a weekend in Philadelphia.
Pope Francis has emphasized themes of inclusion, alleviating poverty and protecting the environment, and is seen as attempting to steer the church away from clashes over divisive social issues. Some Catholic leaders in the U.S., especially those appointed by earlier popes, remain outspoken against same-sex marriage, artificial contraception and abortion.
The findings show Catholic views roughly mirror the sentiments of other Americans on divorce and homosexuality, though Catholics as a whole tend to be more disapproving.
About 84% of Catholics say it is acceptable for children to be raised by unmarried parents, according to the study of more than 5,000 adults surveyed in May and June. Almost half -- 48% -- say that situation is as good as any other, while 35% say it is acceptable but not ideal.
Of those who attend Mass weekly, 36% say it is unacceptable for a same-sex couple to raise children, while 25% say it is acceptable but not as good as other family situations. In contrast, almost half of Catholics who attend Mass less than once a week say a same-sex couple raising children is not only acceptable, but just as good as any other family arrangement, the survey found.
A Knights of Columbus-Marist poll released last week found that 43% of Catholics say same-sex marriage is wrong. Among Catholics who attend church weekly, the number rises to 59%.
In the Pew poll, 83% of Catholics say it is acceptable for children to be raised by divorced parents, though 52% say that situation isn't as good as others.
The poll also found 57% of Catholics -- and 73% who attend Mass weekly -- believe it is sinful to have an abortion, compared with 48% of the general public.
Separately, Pew researchers said the survey "suggests that Pope Francis may have a difficult time persuading Catholics in the U.S. to adopt his philosophy about excess and his focus on the environment."
The poll found nearly 60% say working to help the poor is "essential" to Catholic identity, while only 29% say working to address climate change is an essential part of their Catholic identity.
Credit: By Tamara Audi

U.S. News: Shrinking Glacier Is Backdrop to Obama's Message

Author: Colleen McCain Nelson

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-shrinking-glacier-is-backdrop-obamas/docview/1708737713/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: In a Wall Street Journal/ NBC News poll conducted earlier this year, 34% of respondents said addressing the issue of climate change should be an absolute priority this year.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Shrinking+Glacier+Is+Backdrop+to+Obama%27s+Message&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Shrinking+Glacier+Is+Backdrop+to+Obama%27s+Message&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-09-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK, Alaska -- President Barack Obama hiked to a shrinking glacier Tuesday, traveling to this icy expanse to deliver a visual message to the country: This is what climate change looks like.
Mr. Obama spent the day in the Kenai Mountains, exploring Exit Glacier, which has receded as the planet has warmed, touring the area by boat and even taping a segment for an outdoor adventure show.
The president's arguments were familiar, but the White House is hoping that a change in scenery will help galvanize support for combating global warming. His visit comes as public consensus in the U.S. is growing that the earth is heating up and that people are responsible.
"This is as good of a signpost of what we're dealing with when it comes to climate change as just about anything," Mr. Obama said as he stood about a quarter-mile from the glacier, which he called spectacular. "It sends a message about the urgency we're going to need to have when it comes to dealing with this."
In a Wall Street Journal/ NBC News poll conducted earlier this year, 34% of respondents said addressing the issue of climate change should be an absolute priority this year. More people -- some 37% -- said the issue could be delayed until next year, and 27% said addressing climate change shouldn't be pursued.
During his hike, the president marveled at both the natural beauty of the state and the threat to this glacier, which is 10% smaller than it was in 1950.
Still, as the president tours the nation's largest state by area through Wednesday, his message to Alaskans is more nuanced than the one-note narrative aimed at the American public.
Climate change has to be addressed, Alaska's leaders have told Mr. Obama, but so, too, does the state's $3.5 billion deficit and its sagging oil revenues.
In this state, where oil is central to the economy and sea levels are rising, permafrost is melting, and wildfires are multiplying, the complexities of the president's climate and energy policies are on stark display. Mr. Obama is calling for aggressive action to combat climate change even as he acknowledges that the U.S. economy must rely on oil and gas for now.
Many Alaskans have urged Mr. Obama to clear the way for more energy development. The administration recently approved a permit allowing Royal Dutch Shell to drill in the Arctic Ocean.
Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska) has excoriated the administration's efforts to set aside as wilderness more than 12 million acres in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, where petroleum reserves are plentiful. She argued earlier this year that the administration has delivered a kick to the gut of the state's economy by treating Alaska like a "nice little snow globe."
White House officials said they spoke with stakeholders and communities before the president's visit to ensure that the administration understood the challenges facing Alaska.
David Biette, director of the Polar Initiative at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, said climate change is an important issue, but he cautioned against using Alaska as little more than a stage set to make a visually compelling argument.
"I don't think we treat Alaska as a serious state," Mr. Biette said. The president "shouldn't use Alaska as a backdrop for climate change. What's in it for Alaskans?"
The president's historic visit -- Mr. Obama will be the first sitting president to travel north of the Arctic Circle -- has been celebrated by many in Alaska. Gov. Bill Walker, an independent, said it was exciting to see a president make his state a destination and "not just a low-on-fuel stop."
He added, though, that the state faces serious issues beyond climate change. "We're about 90% tied to the price of oil," he said, noting that plummeting revenues have led to cuts in services.
While climate change has gotten top billing this week, the White House has rolled out other policy announcements, including the decision to rename North America's tallest mountain, returning Mount McKinley to its traditional Alaska Native moniker, Denali.
The White House also said it would accelerate the acquisition of a replacement icebreaker, which the Coast Guard uses to support Arctic scientific research and other work.
"We want to make sure our grandkids can see this," Mr. Obama said of Exit Glacier.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

U.S. News: Climate Change Builds as 2016 Campaign Issue

Author: Harder, Amy

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-climate-change-builds-as-2016-campaign/docview/1708127248/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: In early August, the Environmental Protection Agency issued the first-ever federal regulations to cut carbon emissions from power plants.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Climate+Change+Builds+as+2016+Campaign+Issue&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-31&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Climate+Change+Builds+as+2016+Campaign+Issue&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-31&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   President Barack Obama's trip to Alaska's Arctic on Monday likely will reverberate much farther south, on the 2016 presidential campaign trail, where global warming is expected to emerge as a key issue.
His visit to the region, the first ever for a sitting president, coincides with a growing public consensus that the earth is heating up and that humans have something to do with it.
A July report from the Pew Research Center found that 72% of American adults say there is "solid evidence" of global warming. Of those respondents, 46% said the warming trend is "mostly due to human activity," compared with 22% who blamed it mostly on "natural patterns."
Democrats are particularly convinced human behavior is driving climate change, emboldening Hillary Clinton and her primary rivals to prescribe more aggressive solutions than those pushed by Mr. Obama.
The crowded Republican field remains divided on the issue, although public opinion is prompting some candidates to address it in more substantive ways.
In past presidential elections, climate change was a second-tier topic. Mr. Obama has made clear that he views this issue as central to his legacy and his actions are serving as a benchmark for the candidates.
In early August, the Environmental Protection Agency issued the first-ever federal regulations to cut carbon emissions from power plants. It also is regulating carbon emissions from cars and trucks and is working on rules cutting emissions of methane from oil and gas drilling.
Mr. Obama's Arctic visit will be the latest in a series of trips and speeches the president has been making to build momentum toward a United Nations conference this year where world leaders will decide whether to agree to cut global carbon emissions. While in the region Monday through Wednesday, Mr. Obama plans to visit villages in Alaska that the White House says are threatened by climate change.
Mrs. Clinton has described Mr. Obama's rules for power plants as "the floor, not the ceiling" in addressing climate change. She also opposed the Obama administration's recent approval of a permit for Royal Dutch Shell to drill in the Arctic Ocean, a decision environmentalists have criticized.
"I think Secretary Clinton has made a decision to prioritize climate change in her campaign," said Michael Brune, executive director of the Sierra Club. "You have polling consistently showing Americans want more action on climate change."
Former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Mrs. Clinton's rivals in the Democratic primary, oppose the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, which is awaiting a decision from Mr. Obama's administration.
Mrs. Clinton, who as secretary of state oversaw the earlier stages of the review, has declined to take a position on the pipeline, although she recently expressed frustration about how long -- nearly seven years -- it has taken to review the project.
Donald Trump, who is leading the GOP presidential field, tweeted this month that if elected, he would approve Keystone immediately because it would have "no impact" on the environment. All the other GOP candidates support it, too.
"The environment is an important issue," said John Feehery, president of Quinn Gillespie Communications and a former House GOP adviser. "It's something that Republicans have to improve their messaging on, especially when you're talking about younger voters."
Most of the Republican candidates have shied away from speaking on the issue, as deep divisions remain within the party about the science behind climate change and, if they agree it's occurring, its causes.
Mr. Trump has said he doesn't think climate change caused by human activity is real, though he hasn't spoken publicly on the matter recently.
"This very expensive GLOBAL WARMING b------- has got to stop," Mr. Trump tweeted on Jan. 1, 2014, one of his more recent posts on the subject. "Our planet is freezing, record low temps, and our GW scientists are stuck in ice."
A spokeswoman for his campaign declined to comment last week on his position, saying Mr. Trump "will address these issues over the next several weeks."
Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who has equivocated on climate change in the past, said in a statement to The Wall Street Journal last week that human activity has contributed to climate change and he would address it as president.
Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina is the only GOP candidate who actively has talked about the need to address climate change.
"Here's a question you need to ask everybody running as a Republican: What is the environmental policy of the Republican Party?" Mr. Graham said on CNN in June. "When I ask that question, I get a blank stare."
Credit: By Amy Harder

Green, 'Alternative' Energy Is Moving to the Big Time

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/green-alternative-energy-is-moving-big-time/docview/1707976817/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Unlike large generation plants, enormous wind turbines and especially nuclear reactors, all of which require years of planning, personal and small industrial solar installations can be planned and installed in a month or so, and the rate of these installations is likely to accelerate rapidly.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Green%2C+%27Alternative%27+Energy+Is+Moving+to+the+Big+Time&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Green%2C+%27Alternative%27+Energy+Is+Moving+to+the+Big+Time&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Daniel Yergin ("Power Up," Review, Aug. 22) is precisely right that new energy technologies have historically taken many decades to become price competitive and widely deployed. But climate change is a far more profound threat than any previous energy challenge. Climate change requires more profound and urgent policy responses than past transitions. We know how to cut emissions. Some combination of pricing carbon, regulation of emissions and efficiency, incentivizing alternatives and capturing carbon dioxide is needed. To be most effective, these policies must be adopted by all major emitting nations, which is why gaining an agreement at the climate negotiations in Paris this December is essential. Yes, oil, natural gas and coal will continue to have a role, if reduced, in our economies. But alternatives must be deployed, and quickly, because complacency in the face of climate disaster isn't economically or morally acceptable.
Paul Bledsoe
Arlington, Va.
Mr. Bledsoe was communications director of the White House Climate Change Task Force under President Clinton.
---
Dr. Yergin's prediction of slow and steady growth in solar from about 1% this year up to 4% to 9% of total global electricity by 2040 seems far short of the mark. As is already happening here in Arizona, and no doubt in other sunny states, the utilities are seeing their income from customers with rooftop solar greatly diminish. They understandably are fighting back by charging not just for electricity, but separately for connection to the grid. Maintaining the grid infrastructure is an enormous expense to utilities, and must be recovered from rate payers. Rooftop solar power can be infrastructure-free, just as many homeowners have their own wells and septic systems. As the utilities necessarily increase their connection charges to compensate for the newly disconnected, ever more people will think that utility power is a bad deal and also disconnect. This will ultimately result in electric utilities holding sway only in urban or perpetually cloudy areas. Unlike large generation plants, enormous wind turbines and especially nuclear reactors, all of which require years of planning, personal and small industrial solar installations can be planned and installed in a month or so, and the rate of these installations is likely to accelerate rapidly.
Richard Factor
Sedona, Ariz.
---
I feel current "sustainability" ideas are on the wrong track. I don't think solar energy is sustainable because it takes too much energy to manufacture the panels and auxiliary equipment needed. Nuclear-power plants operate 24/7 and are, cradle to grave, the lowest CO2 energy sources. Their 100% duty cycle, compared with about 20% for solar, means less capital investment and less grid-management capital infrastructure. Solar and wind have about 30-year life expectancies compared with 60 to 120 years for new nuclear installations, again, reducing capital costs in both energy units and dollars.
Richard J. McDonald
Albany, Calif.
(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Powering Up for the Future in a Climate of Uncertainty" -- WSJ Sept. 5, 2015)

California's Prop. 39 Is a Winner

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/californias-prop-39-is-winner/docview/1705938735/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: By embracing policies like Prop. 39 that grow our economy and cut carbon pollution, California is building on the more than 430,000 advanced energy jobs that already exist in the state -- and leading the world in the fight against climate change.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=California%27s+Prop.+39+Is+a+Winner&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=California%27s+Prop.+39+Is+a+Winner&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-22&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   In your Aug. 19 editorial "Tom Steyer's Stimulus" you mischaracterize the success of Proposition 39, the California ballot measure I co-chaired with George Shultz and Kevin de Leon in 2012. In truth, hundreds of millions of dollars in extra funds are now flowing to California schools because of this law.
Prop. 39 closed a corporate tax loophole for companies that ship local jobs to other states. Schools are using the money for much needed upgrades to their energy systems. In the first 16 months of the program, our schools saved $25 million in annual energy costs, leaving more money for books, teachers and playgrounds. Despite the misleading math in the initial reporting, we've also created thousands of jobs -- and this is just the beginning. Many schools are in the planning stages of much bigger construction projects, which will mean more jobs and more savings.
Just as important, this transition to clean energy will help protect our air, water and the health of our children by cutting pollution. Energy savings through efficiency, along with clean technologies like solar and wind, are also critical ways to address the moral challenge of our time -- climate change.
Critics complain that Prop. 39 was supposed to generate even more money and jobs by now, but let's count up the figures after the work is done. For decades, Big Oil has denied basic science in their fight against policies that combat climate change. But now it seems they've moved on to simply denying basic math.
The record is clear: By embracing policies like Prop. 39 that grow our economy and cut carbon pollution, California is building on the more than 430,000 advanced energy jobs that already exist in the state -- and leading the world in the fight against climate change.
Tom Steyer
San Francisco

Full text:   GERMANY
Intelligence Worker
Charged With Treason
German prosecutors charged an intelligence agency worker with treason for allegedly passing documents to U.S. and Russian spies, in a politically explosive case that prompted Berlin to expel the top U.S. spy official from Germany more than a year ago.
In an indictment that was filed last week at Munich's higher regional court and made public Thursday, the Federal Prosecutor's office charged a 32-year-old man identified as Markus R. on two counts of treason, breach of official secrecy and bribery.
According to the charges, the alleged informant for the Central Intelligence Agency came into contact with U.S. spies in 2008 and, in exchange for payment of at least 95,000 euros ($106,000), passed official documents and information about Germany's intelligence activities to the CIA until his arrest in July 2014.
Prosecutors said Markus R. also approached the Russian secret service in mid-2014 and passed three documents to Russia's general consulate in Munich.
The CIA, the Russian Foreign Ministry, and the Russian Federal Security Service didn't respond to requests for comment.
Markus R. had worked for Germany's foreign intelligence service, known as the BND, since 2007, according to the indictment. Beginning in 2008, he oversaw mail distribution and filed classified documents for a BND department that coordinates relations with foreign intelligence agencies.
-- Harriet Torry
---
EUROPEAN UNION
Top Official Says
Climate Deal in Danger
A planned global deal to keep average temperatures from rising more than two degrees Celsius to contain climate change is under threat unless more countries submit emission-reduction targets, the European Union's energy and climate commissioner said.
"The window of opportunity . . . is closing fast," Miguel Arias Canete said on Thursday.
With just over three months to go until the Paris Climate Conference, which is meant to come up with a follow-up agreement to the Kyoto Protocol, 56 out of more than 190 countries, representing 61% of global greenhouse-gas emissions, have submitted targets for reducing these emissions, Mr. Canete said.
While that is up from the 35 nations that submitted targets under the Kyoto deal, targets are still missing from some big economies, including Argentina, Brazil, India, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia and Turkey.
The EU last fall agreed to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions 40% by 2030 from 1990 levels. The U.S., which never ratified the Kyoto Protocol, has submitted a plan to cut emissions between 26% and 28% from 2005 levels over the next 10 years.
In 2010, about 200 governments agreed to reduce emissions to ensure that global temperatures didn't rise by more than two degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels.
-- Gabriele Steinhauser
---
RUSSIA
Putin Ally Departs
As Head of Railway
Russia replaced the head of state-owned Russian RailwaysVladimir Yakunin on Thursday, the first major shake-up in the country's upper echelons of power since the country fell into recession this year.
Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said he had accepted the resignation of 67-year-old Mr. Yakunin, a longtime friend of President Vladimir Putin, and appointed a relatively unknown deputy transport minister in his place.
Mr. Yakunin had run Russian Railways, the country's largest commercial employer with around one million people, for more than a decade. He has been nominated for a seat in Russia's upper house of parliament, a largely ceremonial post.
-- James Marson

EPA Rules Take Aim At Methane Emissions

Author: Harder, Amy

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/epa-rules-take-aim-at-methane-emissions/docview/1704459235/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday will propose the first-ever federal regulations to cut methane emissions from the nation's oil and natural-gas industry, according to people familiar with the move, which is part of President Barack Obama's climate agenda.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=EPA+Rules+Take+Aim+At+Methane+Emissions&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=EPA+Rules+Take+Aim+At+Methane+Emissions&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday will propose the first-ever federal regulations to cut methane emissions from the nation's oil and natural-gas industry, according to people familiar with the move, which is part of President Barack Obama's climate agenda.
The EPA is expected to propose regulations aimed at cutting methane emissions from the oil and gas sector by 40% to 45% over the next decade from 2012 levels, said a person familiar with the plan. That was the goal the agency said earlier this year it would pursue when it first unveiled its plans.
The move is part of a broader regulatory agenda Mr. Obama is pursuing as he seeks to make addressing climate change a legacy of his time in the White House. Earlier this month, the EPA issued final rules cutting carbon emissions from power plants 32% by 2030 based on emissions levels from 2005.
Tuesday's announcement reflects the Obama administration's middle-ground approach toward the oil and gas industry. The Interior Department said Monday it has issued a permit to Royal Dutch Shell PLC to drill for oil and natural gas in the Arctic Ocean, providing the company a long-sought victory and angering environmentalists.
Meanwhile, with the onset of the fracking boom, concerns over methane, a potent greenhouse gas, have grown within the administration. Methane has a warming effect on the planet more than 20 times greater than carbon dioxide, according to the EPA.
Mr. Obama directed his administration to address methane emissions as part of the climate plan he announced in June 2013.
Oil and gas companies sometimes inadvertently emit methane during different parts of the production and transmission process.
By capturing the methane, companies both cut down on the emissions and are able to capitalize on additional product, since methane is the primary component of natural gas.
The plan is sure to draw fire from some energy companies who argue that new regulations will require the installation of costly mitigation systems, as low oil prices pinch profits across the industry.
Companies will be required to install technology that prevents methane from being inadvertently leaked and to monitor their operations for possible leaks. Many companies are already using this kind of equipment, according to industry executives and the EPA.
Thanks largely to hydraulic fracturing, since 2005, domestic oil production has nearly doubled and natural-gas production has risen by about 50%, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
Methane emissions from the sector have dropped roughly 15% over that period through 2012, according to EPA data, but the agency estimates that these emissions will rise 25% over the next decade if steps aren't taken to cut them.
The agency is expected to complete the rules in 2016, after a public comment period.
In announcing its intent to regulate methane emissions from the oil and gas industry earlier this year, EPA said it would propose rules on new oil and gas wells only, a move that environmentalists say falls short of what is needed to address climate change.
"It's very clear we are going to need regulation for existing sources in order to achieve the 40% to 45% reduction," said Mark Brownstein, vice president of the climate and energy program at the Environmental Defense Fund, on a call with other environmental groups Monday previewing the rule. "The question will then be, how far down the road does this particular regulation take us to address existing sources?"
Many executives in the oil and gas industry say any regulation is unnecessary because they are reducing methane emissions already, though some company officials have said cutting such emissions could help them save money and wouldn't impose a prohibitive cost.
The American Petroleum Institute, the nation's largest trade group representing all parts of the oil and gas industry, has said it could support further regulation of new drilling wells for volatile organic compounds, smog-forming pollutants, a regulatory step that would indirectly cut methane emissions.
The EPA in 2012 issued a regulation requiring such cuts from natural-gas wells that have been hydraulic fractured, an extraction technique where large amounts of water and sand, and small amounts of chemicals, are injected deep underground to unlock oil and natural gas trapped in shale rock formations.
API opposes the EPA's move to directly regulate methane emissions from new sources, because that could lead to a requirement to regulate the emissions from existing sources, which would affect hundreds of thousands of wells, according to Howard Feldman, director of regulatory and scientific affairs at API.
Credit: By Amy Harder

____________________________________________________________

Flap Over FEMA Flood Map --- New York City protests federal risk assessment and offers smaller zone; 'puts us in a hard place'

Author: Ramey, Corinne

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/flap-over-fema-flood-map-new-york-city-protests/docview/1704304676/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: (WSJ August 19, 2015) Two years ago, the Federal Emergency Management Agency issued a new flood map for the New York City region, one that substantially expanded what's known as the "100-year floodplain" -- areas where there is at least a 1% chance of flooding in any given year.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Flap+Over+FEMA+Flood+Map+---+New+York+City+protests+federal+risk+assessment+and+offers+smaller+zone%3B+%27puts+us+in+a+hard+place%27&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.13&amp;au=Ramey%2C+Corinne&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Corrections & Amplifications
The name of the Association of State Floodplain Managers was incorrectly given as the Association of Floodplain Managers in an article on Monday about a new flood map for the New York City region.
(WSJ August 19, 2015)
Two years ago, the Federal Emergency Management Agency issued a new flood map for the New York City region, one that substantially expanded what's known as the "100-year floodplain" -- areas where there is at least a 1% chance of flooding in any given year.
FEMA's map, a preliminary document still subject to final approval and its first significant update since 1983, would expand the number of city residents in the 100-year floodplain by 83% to 400,000. It nearly doubles the number of structures in the zone to 71,500.
Now, the city is challenging FEMA's map, saying it overstates the risk of flooding in much of the expanded flood zone, unnecessarily imposing insurance and other costs on homeowners. In late June, the city released the results of its own analysis, conducted by consulting firm Arcadis, which produced a smaller flood zone, one the city says is more reasonable than FEMA's.
Whichever interpretation prevails, the city's appeal has sparked a debate about balancing home affordability against flood risk, and the outcome has potentially huge economic stakes for homeowners, businesses and neighborhoods near the water's edge.
"It's critically important to get these as accurate as possible," said Daniel Zarrilli, director of the Mayor's Office of Recovery and Resiliency, which appealed the FEMA map. "A lot of other issues of policy come from what is on these maps."
The city's map would remove about 26,000 structures and 170,000 people from FEMA's floodplain, potentially sparing them a steep increase in insurance costs. Homeowners in a 100-year zone are effectively required to buy flood insurance -- especially if they have a federally backed mortgage -- and the premiums can cost $5,000 to $10,000 a year, Mr. Zarrilli said. Inclusion in a flood zone "can have a devastating impact on neighborhoods," he said.
It also likely lowers a home's value and raises the income required to qualify for a federally backed mortgage. In addition, flood maps determine building codes, which influence the cost and structural requirements for new construction or renovations on waterfront land.
FEMA expects to begin talks with the city in coming weeks, said Andrew Martin, the agency's regional representative. If the city and FEMA can't agree, the city or FEMA can request a review by the Scientific Resolution Panel, an independent body based in Washington, D.C., or the dispute could end up in federal court.
New York City isn't the only jurisdiction appealing FEMA's map. Mr. Martin said the agency has received 190 comments and appeals from communities across New York and New Jersey, 60% of them backed by scientific or engineering data, he said.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, for example, is challenging the extent of FEMA's floodplain at Newark International Airport, authority officials said.
Jersey City will submit a letter of support for New York's appeal, said its mayor, Steven Fulop. "Our own review shows that as many as 28,000 Jersey City residents have inaccurately been placed in the 100-year flood zone and might unnecessarily face vastly increased flood insurance," he said in a statement.
Some elected officials and neighborhood advocates support New York City's appeal, albeit with reservations.
"It was necessary for the city to do it, to try to keep that affordability for homeowners," said Donovan Richards, a City Council member who represents parts of Queens. "But we also have to be cautious, and not shrink the map to the extent that if another storm comes, these homeowners would not have been in the flood zone."
Others question whether city officials, eager to maintain affordable housing for their constituents, underestimate the risk of natural disaster.
"There is a lot of talking in the formal appeal about how aggressive New York City is being in terms of climate change," said Chad Berginnis, executive director of the Association of Floodplain Managers, a professional association. "Yet they are almost regressing to old data and old methods, and not wanting to look at sea-level rise and climate change."
In New York City's appeal letter, Mr. Zarrilli said the city takes climate change seriously and is adapting buildings, telecommunications, transportation and other infrastructure to withstand severe weather events.
While it is important for flood maps to reflect the best science, the city's appeal creates uncertainty, notes Caroline Nagy, policy manager at the Center for NYC Neighborhoods, which advocates for affordable Homeownership.
"It puts us in a hard place," she said, "because it's hard to help people get prepared because you don't know what the map will be like or when it will be implemented."
Affected homeowners are well-acquainted with the anxiety that comes with living in flood-prone areas.
High insurance bills could "wipe out the middle class in the beach communities," said Larry Scheiber, a salesman who lives in Belle Harbor, Queens. "Speaking with my friends and neighbors, people are aware of [the appeal], but looking at the bills that come in, you're looking at what's right in front of you."
In the Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook this month, residents Andrea and Stephen Kondaks showed off new flood vents in their 1860s house. They hope the vents will lower their flood-insurance premium.
"There is a lot of anxiety in terms of flood-insurance increases," Ms. Kondaks said. "We're all sitting here saying, 'What is it, what are you threatening us with? Is it $7,000, is it $5,000? What's the number?' "
Credit: By Corinne Ramey

EPA's Plan: Little Gain for High Legal, Economic Cost

Abstract: Environmental Defense Fund President Fred Krupp's "A Clean-Energy Breakthrough" op-ed, Aug. 4) is utter nonsense, starting with the inarticulate term "carbon pollution" (soot?) that ultimately morphs into "climate pollution" (whatever that is).

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=EPA%27s+Plan%3A+Little+Gain+for+High+Legal%2C+Economic+Cost&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-13&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Environmental Defense Fund President Fred Krupp's "A Clean-Energy Breakthrough" op-ed, Aug. 4) is utter nonsense, starting with the inarticulate term "carbon pollution" (soot?) that ultimately morphs into "climate pollution" (whatever that is). If one means carbon dioxide, then say it and be clear about it.
The Clean Air Act is a health-focused law, not a climate-focused law. Carbon dioxide at 400 or 500 parts per million isn't going to kill me, my children or my grandchildren, let alone have any adverse health effects. Only if and when we come to understand the relative importance to climate change of natural variability and human-influenced effects, then perhaps we can consider legislation. We aren't even close to that understanding, and as time moves forward the "settled science" is becoming more unsettled.
The EPA's endangerment finding is on increasingly shaky ground (especially if we could actually see the science behind it). There has been no warming over the last 18 years despite one-fifth of all human CO2 emissions in history going into the atmosphere. The climate models are increasingly diverging from the observed temperature record; they fail the engineering test of usability through a lack of validation and verification. We are wrenching the energy economy around on such a basis?
What about the "competitively priced clean energy" that is supposed to becoming commonplace? That seems to be uncommon here in California where we enjoy well above average electricity rates for our renewable portfolio standard. Did I mention the carbon tax on transportation fuels?
Expect more nonsense from the green full-court press ahead of the Paris climate talks in December. Every ill on the news will be linked to climate change between now and then.
Mark Strauch
Livermore, Calif.
---
Mr. Krupp makes clear that the government should be run by a few bureaucrats and not Congress and the people. The only accurate statement he makes about the EPA's Clean Power Plan is that "the countries that move the fastest toward clean energy . . . will have the healthiest air." The reason isn't what he thinks, though. It will be because the cost of manufacturing will be so expensive due to high energy costs that the remaining U.S. manufacturing companies will continue to move to countries that aren't hallucinating over the man-made global-warming madness (i.e., Mexico, all of Asia, etc.).
That Mr. Krupp can extol this plan while the EPA violates the Constitution and the rights of states shows clearly that the Obama administration is really no different than the late Hugo Chavez of Venezuela. And then Mr. Krupp extols the U.S. agreement with China where they both agreed to setting climate goals. He fails to mention that China isn't going to start to reduce CO2 levels until 2030.
Mr. Krupp states "millions of Americans joined the fight for these standards." Who are these millions of Americans? They sure aren't people who care about manufacturing jobs, electrical bills, governance by fiat or upholding the Constitution.
Don Venderbush
Terrace Park, Ohio
---
This plan trades U.S. economic loss in the next several years for vague economic gains in future decades. The truth is that this federal government takeover of our energy economy will have no significant effect on global climate change.
Patrick Lanpher
St. Augustine, Fla.
---
Mr. Krupp mentions that clean-energy investments create three times as many jobs per dollar invested as fossil-fuel investments. This is a bad thing. If energy can be created with fewer laborers, those laborers can pursue more productive endeavors elsewhere in the economy, while paying less for energy. Investments in sweatshops where laborers sew by hand "deliver" more jobs per dollar than investments in sewing machines.
Gavin Roberts,
Denver
---
I have one question for Mr. Krupp. Did you get to keep your doctor?
Guy Randolph
Savannah, Ga.

U.S. News: EPA Rule Sets Up Fight Ahead of Global Talks

Author: Colleen McCain Nelson; Harder, Amy

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-epa-rule-sets-up-fight-ahead-global/docview/1700876458/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: The final Environmental Protection Agency rule requires a 32% cut in power-plant carbon-dioxide emissions by 2030 from 2005 levels, which is a more ambitious target than the draft rules proposed last year.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+EPA+Rule+Sets+Up+Fight+Ahead+of+Global+Talks&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BHarder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+EPA+Rule+Sets+Up+Fight+Ahead+of+Global+Talks&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;au=Colleen+McCain+Nelson%3BHarder%2C+Amy&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama's announcement Monday of an aggressive plan to cut carbon emissions from U.S. power plants launched what will be a monthslong push that the administration hopes culminates in a global climate accord later this year.
While the first-ever limits on carbon emissions are a crucial component of the president's domestic agenda, the regulations also are integral to Mr. Obama's efforts to position the U.S. as a leader on the world stage. Nearly 200 countries are working toward completing a climate deal in Paris in December. The issue also is expected to be high on the agenda when Mr. Obama meets with Pope Francis next month, on the heels of a papal encyclical calling for a cultural revolution to combat climate change.
U.S. power plants account for just 5% of global carbon emissions. But administration officials have said that if the U.S. leads on this issue, other nations would follow, and the new plan allows the president to show progress at home.
"If we don't do it, nobody will. The only reason that China is now looking at getting serious about its emissions is because they saw that we were going to do it, too," Mr. Obama said Monday at the White House. "When the world faces its toughest challenges, America leads the way forward."
The limits on carbon emissions are a central component of the U.S.'s pledge to its international partners to cut greenhouse gases by a range of 26% to 28% by 2025, from 2005 levels. The final Environmental Protection Agency rule requires a 32% cut in power-plant carbon-dioxide emissions by 2030 from 2005 levels, which is a more ambitious target than the draft rules proposed last year.
In the absence of a plan to cut carbon-dioxide emissions in the U.S., the president would have a "difficult row to hoe" as he seeks cooperation of other world leaders, said Heather Zichal, a former Obama adviser on energy and climate change.
"You've now got Obama going to Paris with a plan that has aggressive emissions reductions," she said. "Without that, I don't see how the United States would be credible."
Republicans, though, have criticized both the emissions regulations and the president's push for an international pact. When the administration struck a climate agreement with China in November, Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and other Republicans said the deal made China do nothing until at least 2030 and that U.S. regulations would hurt America's economy much sooner.
Mr. McConnell, the Senate majority leader, said Monday that the administration's rules wouldn't meaningfully affect the global climate, adding that "they could actually end up harming the environment by outsourcing energy production to countries with poor environmental records like India and China."
Mr. Obama has been pointing toward Paris for months, framing the negotiations as a historic opportunity to complete a pact with nearly 200 nations and reduce greenhouse-gas emissions world-wide. He has put the issue front and center in his talks with world leaders, building consensus on climate action at the Group of Seven summit in June and securing new commitments from Brazil earlier this summer.
A spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington, D.C., said Monday that China is pursuing climate initiatives on its own and praised its relationship with the U.S. on this issue.
Whether Mr. Obama will win enough political support for his plan at home -- as well as legal rulings upholding the EPA rule -- remains a question. Even if the president prevails on the domestic front, that doesn't guarantee success internationally.
Norine Kennedy, vice president for environment and energy for the United States Council for International Business, said the administration's ambition in reducing carbon emissions is commendable. But thorny issues, such as agreeing on a plan to verify countries' emissions cuts and finding sources of money to aid developing countries in reducing emissions, still must be resolved before Paris, she said.
Many Republicans and other opponents have said they would explore ways to warn other countries that the president might not be able to deliver on his promises to slash emissions. Some also are pursuing legal and legislative strategies aimed at derailing the EPA regulations, which could prove problematic for meeting the U.S.'s international commitments.
A group of 15 state attorneys general said minutes after Mr. Obama's announcement of the rule that they intend to file a lawsuit challenging it. Sen. Shelley Moore Capito (R., W.Va.) said a Senate committee would soon take up legislation she has sponsored to delay the rule's compliance deadlines until all litigation is resolved and give governors the ability to opt out of the plan if they determine the rule would crimp their economy or reliability of the electric grid.
Experts also said a GOP win in the 2016 presidential election could call into question the regulations' long-term prospects and the U.S.'s Paris commitments.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Amy Harder

Power-Plant Emissions Rules To Alter, Challenge Industry

Author: Harder, Amy; Colleen McCain Nelson; Smith, Rebecca

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/power-plant-emissions-rules-alter-challenge/docview/1700639988/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: Industry experts say cutting carbon emissions 32% by 2030 will require billions of dollars in investments for new transmission lines that accommodate more solar and wind power and new pipelines to feed natural-gas-fired power plants, as coal becomes less important as a fuel.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Power-Plant+Emissions+Rules+To+Alter%2C+Challenge+Industry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson%3BSmith%2C+Rebecca&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Power-Plant+Emissions+Rules+To+Alter%2C+Challenge+Industry&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-08-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Harder%2C+Amy%3BColleen+McCain+Nelson%3BSmith%2C+Rebecca&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- A new rule mandating the first-ever federal limits on power-plant carbon emissions aims to change the way Americans make and consume electricity, accelerating a shift already under way toward cleaner fuels, renewable energy and consumer-generated power.
The regulations, which will be unveiled by President Barack Obama at a White House event Monday, are part of a broader push by the administration to position the U.S. as a leader in tackling climate change. The Environmental Protection Agency regulations are central to the administration's submission to an international climate conference set for December in Paris.
White House officials say Mr. Obama views addressing climate change as part of his legacy. He announced an aggressive climate deal with China in November and has put the issue high on the agenda in meetings with world leaders in recent months. The president also will discuss climate change with Pope Francis during his visit to the U.S. next month, following the pope's release of an encyclical on the issue in June.
"This rule enhances in important ways our ability to achieve the international commitments that we have made," Brian Deese, a senior adviser to Mr. Obama, told reporters Sunday.
But divisions at home cast some doubt on the administration's ability to fully implement the regulations, which were released in draft form a year ago.
Industry officials say they are worried about the plan's cost and timetable. Republicans in Congress and states hardest hit by the plan say they will fight it. More than a dozen states and the coal industry have vowed to sue the EPA, and several states have threatened to refuse to comply with the rule.
The rule would require a 32% cut in power-plant carbon dioxide emissions by 2030 from 2005 levels, an increase from the 30% target proposed last year. EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy said Sunday the rule would result in an estimated annual cost of $8.4 billion by 2030 and have total benefits, including public-health benefits, of $34 billion to $54 billion per year by then.
The regulations require states to draft their own plans to reduce power-plant emissions to reach an overall carbon reduction target nationwide. States would have to put in place compliance plans by 2018 and meet their first targets for reductions by 2022. As with the draft rule released last year, the EPA would impose a federal plan on states that don't comply, according to the administration.
The final rule calls for the nation to get 28% of its electricity from renewable resources by 2030, versus roughly 13% last year. Industry experts say cutting carbon emissions 32% by 2030 will require billions of dollars in investments for new transmission lines that accommodate more solar and wind power and new pipelines to feed natural-gas-fired power plants, as coal becomes less important as a fuel.
U.S. electric utilities have already taken steps to shift to less carbon-intensive fuels, and they worry about the degree to which their whole system will need to be upgraded to accommodate more renewable energy, much of it generated by customers with solar panels or other equipment.
The industry, experts said, expects to spend more than $100 billion next year on capital projects, and will adjust its spending programs to reflect the new rules even as court challenges proceed.
"Utilities already are moving in that direction by retiring coal plants and adding renewables," said Nick Akins, chief executive of Ohio-based American Electric Power Co., one of the nation's biggest utilities, which has been a major user of coal. Though some states may object to the EPA rule, he said, most utilities "will be reaching out to our states and be very factual and objective and see if we can comply."
Executives worry about the EPA plan's cost, in part because it could result in shutting power plants that aren't yet paid off, Mr. Akins said, meaning consumers will have to pay for assets that aren't providing benefits.
Administration officials said Sunday they had taken industry concerns into account in the year since the draft was released. Most significantly, the final rule pushes back the first year that states must begin complying, to 2022 from 2020.
In another nod to industry concerns, the final rule would help encourage nuclear power generation, which doesn't emit any carbon and accounts for about 20% of the U.S.'s electricity.
Nuclear reactors under construction in Tennessee, South Carolina and Georgia will get credit toward compliance with the rule, a change from the proposal, according to the administration. Nuclear plants that boost their output also will get more credit.
One industry concern is the final rule seeks to prevent a wholesale shift to natural gas. Over the past few years, utilities have been burning more gas, which produces 50% less carbon emissions than coal but still more than zero-emitting sources like wind and nuclear power. That shift has been helped along by the domestic boom in gas production since 2008 aided by new drilling methods such as hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.
The 2014 draft rule relied on a large and early shift from coal to natural gas. The final regulations would remove that assumption and instead create a new program to encourage states to deploy more renewable energy and energy efficiency by giving credits toward compliance on such projects that begin construction early on.
Analysts at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. said the rule would increase utility consumption of natural gas by 7.1 billion cubic feet a day, or 32%, enough to lift national demand for it by about 10%. The big loser -- the coal industry -- will see consumption drop 23% by 2020, adding to the crisis already rocking mining. Some opponents have labeled the rule a "war on coal."
"We'll hear the same tired plays from the same special-interest playbook, but the American people know better," Ms. McCarthy said.
To date, states including California and nine in the Northeast have been in the minority in devising programs to trim carbon dioxide emissions blamed for climate change.
The new rule "will act like an accelerant," said Ted Craver, chief executive of California-based Edison International, parent of Southern California Edison. "Now all the states will have to grapple with the need to reduce carbon emissions."
Electric-grid operators would need to make sure their systems can handle power flowing from decentralized sources, such as millions of rooftop solar systems and thousands of wind turbines.
Utilities have been shutting coal plants for several years to satisfy other EPA rules. Since 2011, Duke Energy Corp. says it has retired 40 older coal units in the Carolinas and the Midwest and replaced them with super-efficient coal units or gas-fired plants at a total cost of $9 billion.
Credit: By Amy Harder, Colleen McCain Nelson and Rebecca Smith

Full text:   ENVIRONMENT
Companies to Vow
To Cut Emissions
More than a dozen U.S. companies on Monday will pledge to invest more than $140 billion in efforts to cut carbon emissions as part of a new Obama administration initiative leading up to the United Nations climate change summit later this year.
Bank of America Corp., General Motors Co., Cargill Inc. and Alcoa Inc. are among the companies set to sign onto a pledge to address climate change at a White House event Monday with Secretary of State John Kerry and White House adviser Brian Deese.
Monday's announcement, which also includes tech giants Google Inc., Apple Inc. and Microsoft Corp., is one part of an expansive effort by the Obama administration to address climate change and make it a legacy of President Barack Obama's time in the White House.
As soon as next week, the Environmental Protection Agency is set to issue final rules cutting carbon emissions from U.S. power plants.
-- Amy Harder
---
VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS
Workers in Nine States
Take a Strike Vote
Verizon Communications Inc. workers in nine states have voted to go on strike if necessary over a dispute about a new contract, a union official said at a rally on Saturday.
"Our members are clear and they are determined," said Dennis Trainor, an official with the Communications Workers of America union. "They reject management's harsh concessionary demands."
At the rally in New York, the CWA said that 86% of Verizon workers who voted in a recent poll backed strike action if required.
The contract covers employees in nine states from Massachusetts to Virginia who work for Verizon's wireline business, which provides fixed-line phone services and FiOS Internet service. It also affects wireline workers in Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island, as well as in Washington, D.C.
Verizon spokesman Rich Young said the company had made the unions "a solid proposal that recognizes the changing communications landscape and offers a path toward success."
-- Associated Press
---
UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
U.S. Seeks Damages
In Sikorsky Inquiry
The Justice Department is seeking up to $148 million in damages and fines from United Technologies Corp. over allegations that units of its helicopter business overbilled the U.S. Navy for spare parts.
The company had previously disclosed the complaint against two subsidiaries of Sikorsky Aircraft, the helicopter unit. In a filing Friday, United Technologies said it was notified July 13 that the Justice Department had opened a criminal complaint into the matter.
Sikorsky makes helicopters for commercial and military use, including the Black Hawk.
The investigation comes as United Technologies hopes to complete its announced sale of Sikorsky to Lockheed Martin Corp. for $9 billion. United Technologies said it is cooperating fully and doesn't think it is likely to lose the case.
A Lockheed Martin spokesman said: "We were made aware of the issue during our due diligence and negotiation process and we will continue to monitor the issue in close collaboration with UTC."
At issue is whether the two units of Sikorsky were within their rights to include profit and overhead in billings to the Navy from 2006 to 2012, when the company had a contract to supply spare parts for two types of fixed-wing training aircraft.
-- Ted Mann

U.S. News: New Clinton Emails Spark Warning --- Watchdogs contend that the transmissions contain potentially classified information

Author: Tau, Byron

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-new-clinton-emails-spark-warning/docview/1698871100/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: (WSJ July 29, 2015) A third batch of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's emails is scheduled to be released this week despite warnings from internal government watchdogs that "hundreds of potentially classified emails" could be among them and a conclusion that the State Department already had posted classified material publicly as part of previous email releases.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+New+Clinton+Emails+Spark+Warning+---+Watchdogs+contend+that+the+transmissions+contain+potentially+classified+information&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-07-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Tau%2C+Byron&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Corrections & Amplifications
Two internal government watchdogs and the State Department are arguing over whether former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, during her time in office, sent or received emails containing then-classified information on her personal email server. A U.S. News article Monday about the emails incorrectly called it an intergovernmental argument.
(WSJ July 29, 2015)
A third batch of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's emails is scheduled to be released this week despite warnings from internal government watchdogs that "hundreds of potentially classified emails" could be among them and a conclusion that the State Department already had posted classified material publicly as part of previous email releases.
The next tranche of Mrs. Clinton's emails is set to be posted Friday by the State Department, the third significant release of emails from Mrs. Clinton's time in office from 2009 until 2013. The release highlights the intergovernmental argument about whether she sent or received information that was classified at the time on her personal email server.
In another development that is likely to further the dispute about her use of a personal server rather than the government system, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman said Saturday that she plans to testify in October before the Republican-led panel investigating the 2012 attack on a U.S. diplomatic facility in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador Christopher Stevens.
Republicans on the Benghazi Select Committee are expected to question Mrs. Clinton about both the Benghazi attack, as well as her email server arrangement. Mrs. Clinton's spokesman said the Democratic presidential front-runner would answer questions on both topics during the public hearing. Republicans on the panel said a firm date had not yet been set.
Last week, an inspector general probe concluded that Mrs. Clinton had then-classified material stored on her own personal server. A State Department spokesman stood by the department's longtime assertion that no material sent or received by Mrs. Clinton was classified at the time it was transmitted, and that the department sometimes needs to retroactively classify information. He said that "to our knowledge, none of them [the emails] needed to be classified at the time."
On a campaign swing in Iowa over the weekend, Mrs. Clinton told reporters, "The facts are pretty clear: I did not send nor receive anything that was classified at the time."
A probe by the Intelligence Community Inspector General found four emails in a small sample of the total emails in Mrs. Clinton's archive that contained information that was classified when they were sent and remains classified to this day.
In a letter last week, the inspector general complained about the vetting process used to clear the emails and about the classified information contained in Mrs. Clinton's communications.
The inspector general's office said Sunday that it couldn't discuss whether the classified material it found was sent or received -- or both -- using Mrs. Clinton's server.
"We carefully used 'transmit' to not indicate either sent or received," said a spokeswoman for the inspector general's office.
A Wall Street Journal report said the inspector general had concluded Mrs. Clinton sent four emails using her personal email server that contained classified information.
In a statement released Friday and cosigned by the State Department inspector general, the intelligence inspector general concluded: "This classified information should never have been transmitted via an unclassified personal system."
Mrs. Clinton has insisted that her email arrangement was legal and that she has turned over all her work-related material to the State Department. She also has maintained that she knew the classification laws during her time in office and didn't violate them.
On Sunday in Iowa, Mrs. Clinton sought to elevate the issue of climate change in the presidential race as she announced two "bold national goals" to expand clean-energy production. She pledged she would take steps to ensure that within a decade, the U.S. would produce enough clean, renewable energy to power every home in the country. And she set a target of half a billion solar panels installed in the U.S. by the end of her first term.
The announcements were the start of what the Clinton campaign said would be a months-long rollout of a broader energy and climate strategy. The focus on these issues allows Mrs. Clinton seeks to draw sharp contrasts with GOP presidential candidates.
Republican presidential candidates have voiced varying degrees of skepticism about whether human activity plays a role in climate change. Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas), for example, has compared those who have raised concerns about climate change to "flat-Earthers."
---
Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.
Credit: By Byron Tau

Full text:   NEW YORK
De Blasio to Attend
Conference at Vatican
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio will go to Rome on Monday, where he will meet with Pope Francis and give a speech on climate change at the Vatican, the mayor's aides said Wednesday.
The mayor will join 65 other mayors from around the U.S. and the world at the Vatican-sponsored conference Modern Slavery and Climate Change: the Commitment of the Cities. The mayors of Boston, Seattle, New Orleans, San Francisco and Portland, Ore., are expected to attend.
Mr. de Blasio will deliver a speech on the city's climate-change plan, called OneNYC, and the role the mayor says it will play in addressing income inequality.
The cost of the trip will be covered by New York City, a de Blasio spokeswoman said.

Attacker Steals Gun

An off-duty New York City police officer was attacked and robbed of her service revolver inside her Bronx apartment building early Wednesday, police said.

Realistic Climate Goals, More Jobs and Lower Taxes

Author: Anonymous

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/realistic-climate-goals-more-jobs-lower-taxes/docview/1694908952/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: If agreed this November when the Montreal Protocol parties meet, the HFC amendment would provide on the order of 10% of the mitigation needed to stay below the 2 degrees C guardrail that, if surpassed, will bring dangerous and potentially irreversible climate impacts.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Realistic+Climate+Goals%2C+More+Jobs+and+Lower+Taxes&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-07-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Realistic+Climate+Goals%2C+More+Jobs+and+Lower+Taxes&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-07-09&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Anonymous&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Regarding former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg's "Realistic Goals for the Paris Climate Conference" (op-ed, June 29): The Paris process is reaching out to embrace other efforts to address climate change. This includes efforts to reduce conventional air pollution -- black carbon soot and urban smog -- which saves lives today and cuts the rate of climate change in half tomorrow. It also includes phasing down hydrofluorocarbon refrigerants under the Montreal Protocol. This effort was initiated by low-lying countries concerned with rising sea levels and more powerful storm surges, and is now being championed by the Africa group of 55 countries, as well as the U.S. and Europe.
If agreed this November when the Montreal Protocol parties meet, the HFC amendment would provide on the order of 10% of the mitigation needed to stay below the 2 degrees C guardrail that, if surpassed, will bring dangerous and potentially irreversible climate impacts.
Further mitigation would come from efficiency gains in room air conditioners catalyzed by the phase down of the refrigerants. This could potentially double the climate prize and would be a sizable down payment for the Paris agreement.
The past success of the Montreal Protocol wasn't easy as chemical companies invested in CFCs fought for several years to discredit the science, which later won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry for Mario Molina, Sherwood Rowland and Paul Crutzen. But Mayor Bloomberg is correct that focusing on a specific part of the climate problem with a tailor-made solution, as the Montreal Protocol does, is easier than trying to solve the whole of climate change in one go.
Durwood Zaelke
President
Institute for Governance & Sustainable Development
Washington
---
Our best hope for the United Nations climate change conference in Paris is that absolutely nothing happens. Mr. Bloomberg holds up Portugal as one of the economic powerhouses we should try to emulate with clean energy. Portugal has an unemployment rate of 13%, with a much higher unemployment rate for young adults. I would think a former mayor of New York would understand that what we really want are jobs and low taxes. We can all be sure that neither of those two things will be a goal or outcome of any climate conference.
The last time I was in New York City, I don't recall seeing any windmills or solar panels, and I certainly didn't see any New Yorkers protesting for the privilege of paying three times more for their electricity.
David Jung
Chicago

Abstract: The announcement is a major victory for Mr. Obama, who has supported renewed relations with Cuba since his 2008 presidential campaign and made the issue a core component of his second-term foreign policy agenda.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.%2C+Cuba+Agree+to+Reopen+Embassies&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2015-07-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Schwartz%2C+Felicia%3Bde+Cordoba%2C+Jose%3BLee%2C+Carol+E&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
